text: Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, I'm Mwakamba, how can I assist you today? I'm Peace from Mkalama, Singida. I have a concern about my daughter, Nen, she's 14 years old. Lately, there have been some difficult situations at home due to parental conflicts that escalated into a divorce and custody disputes. The tension is affecting her greatly. I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through this, Peace. It's crucial we find ways to help Nen cope with the changes happening in her life. Can you tell me more about how she's been handling things? Has she been expressing any feelings or exhibiting any unusual behavior? Since the divorce proceedings began, I've noticed that Nen has become quieter and more withdrawn. She used to be outgoing and social but now she prefers to spend most of her time alone. She's also been having trouble sleeping and frequently wakes up in tears. It breaks my heart to see her like this. I understand how hard this must be for you, Peace. It's important to remember that it's okay for Nen to feel upset and confused during this time. I recommend engaging a therapist who specializes in child psychology to help guide both Nen and yourself through these challenging moments. Mwakamba, thank you for listening. I appreciate your advice and will look into finding a therapist as soon as possible. Do you have any recommendations on how to find one in Singida? I'm glad that you're seeking help for Nen, Peace. In regards to locating a therapist in Singida, I would suggest reaching out to local mental health facilities or asking for referrals from your family doctor. If there are no options available locally, consider looking online for psychologists

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Saida. I can offer you a listening ear and some guidance if needed. I understand that you have concerns about a child, could you please tell me more about the situation? I'm Azizi from Misungwi, Mwanza. There's a 7-year-old boy named Asani who lives with us and I've noticed some changes in his behavior recently. He seems withdrawn, less energetic than usual, and often cries for no apparent reason. That sounds concerning, Azizi. It's great that you've reached out for help. Has Asani experienced any major life changes or stressors lately? For example, moving homes, a family member passing away, or a change in school? Unfortunately, yes. We recently lost his grandfather, who was like a father figure to him. Since the funeral, I believe his grief has been overwhelming for him. He's also started a new school and is having trouble adjusting. I see. It's normal for a child to experience sadness after losing someone close, but it does sound like Asani might be struggling more than usual. Would you consider reaching out to a local grief counselor or psychologist who specializes in helping children cope with loss? They can provide additional support and guidance during this difficult time. That's a good idea. I will look into finding a professional that can help him. Thank you for your advice, Saida. It means a lot to me and Asani. I appreciate the support from someone who understands our situation. You're very welcome, Azizi. Remember, it's okay to ask for help when we need it. If you have any other concerns or questions in the future, don't hesitate to contact us again. Take care of yourself and Asani. Goodbye

Hello, child helpline? Hi there, I'm Rhoda. How can I assist you today? I'm Neema from Iringa Mjini, Iringa. There's a concern regarding Martina, an 11-year-old girl living in our neighborhood. She appears to be neglected physically. Can we discuss this situation? Of course, Neema. Let's talk about what you've observed and how long it has been going on. I'd like to understand the context better. Martina lives with her grandparents since her parents moved away for work last year. Her grandmother rarely prepares meals for her, and when she does, it's usually insufficient. Martina often goes to bed hungry. This has been happening consistently for several months now. Additionally, Martina's clothes are worn out and ill-fitting. I see. It sounds like Martina may be experiencing physical neglect. I appreciate your concern and taking action in this situation. Can you tell me more about Martina's behavior or any changes you've noticed lately? How does she seem to cope with her circumstances? In the past few weeks, Martina has become increasingly quiet and withdrawn. She avoids eye contact and seems preoccupied most of the time. Her school performance has also dropped significantly. I feel that this situation is affecting her emotionally and academically. I understand your concerns, Neema. It's important to take action in cases like these. Let me walk you through some steps we can take to help Martina. First, it may be beneficial for you to report this issue to local authorities or organizations that specialize in child welfare. I can provide resources and guidance on how to do so. Secondly, I would recommend reaching out to Martina's school counselor to discuss her situation and express your

Hello, child helpline? Hi there, I'm Anza. Can I help you with something today? Yes, I need to speak about a concern regarding a child. My name is Yaro, and I'm from Korogwe, Tanga. The child in question is Anga, who is 14 years old. I've noticed that she seems unusually withdrawn and sad lately. She often spends long hours alone in her room and seldom wants to interact with anyone. Her grades at school have dropped significantly as well. It's important to note that Anga has a family history of depression, so I believe it may be related. I'm worried she might be experiencing symptoms herself. I want to emphasize how much her well-being means to me and the community here in Korogwe. We've tried talking to her, but it seems like words just bounce off her. It breaks my heart seeing such a vibrant girl feeling so down. Thank you for listening to me. I know this is difficult for both of us, but I feel helpless and need guidance on how best to approach this situation. I appreciate your understanding, Anza. This means the world to me and Anga's future. Can you help me understand what steps should be taken next? I completely understand your concern, Yaro. It's great that you're reaching out for help. In cases like these, it's crucial to address the issue promptly. I suggest speaking with a mental health professional who can assess Anga's condition and provide appropriate treatment if needed. In addition, encourage open communication between Anga and her family members, emphasizing empathy and understanding. It's essential for everyone involved to create an environment where she feels safe expressing her feelings. Lastly, keep the lines of communication open

Hello, child helpline? Hi there, I'm Furaha. How can I help you today? I'm Ishara from Kati Unguja, Kusini Unguja. There's a concern about my 17-year-old son, Motogusinile. He's been experiencing bullying, but not the traditional kind. It's cyberbullying. I'm truly sorry to hear that, Ishara. Cyberbullying can be particularly tough because it can follow a child even when they're away from school or friends. Can you tell me more about what Motogusinile has been going through? Yes, of course. He's been receiving hurtful and threatening messages on social media platforms. The bullies are anonymous, which makes it even harder for him to deal with. I've tried talking to him about it but he becomes very upset and doesn't want to discuss it much. Ishara, that must be incredibly distressing for both of you. It's important to remember that your son is not alone in this. Cyberbullying is a growing concern, especially among teenagers. I can provide some guidance on how to approach the situation and offer support to Motogusinile. Firstly, it's essential to ensure his safety online. If he hasn't already, encourage him to set his social media accounts to private, only accepting friend requests from people he knows personally. Additionally, remind him never to share personal information online. In terms of emotional support, let Motogusinile know that it's okay to talk about his feelings and encourage open communication. Encourage him to save any evidence of the bullying messages so they can be reported if necessary. Furthermore, I would suggest contacting the school to inform them of

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, I'm here to help. My name is Caroline, I'm 17 years old and I'm from Mkalama in Singida. I need your help. I ran away from home a few days ago because of my parents. They don't understand me or my dreams and they always argue with each other. I feel lost and scared, Mariana. I don't know what to do next. I went to stay with an older friend in the city but things aren't as good as I thought they would be. I miss my family and school, but I can't go back home. What should I do? I understand that this must be very difficult for you, Caroline. Running away from home is a tough decision and it's important to think about your safety first. Let me help you explore some options together. Have you considered reaching out to someone you trust like a teacher, counselor, or relative who can support you? I don't have anyone I can talk to, Mariana. My friends are either too busy or they don't really care about my situation. I feel alone and stuck. I want to go back home but I don't know if it's the right choice. Can you help me find a way out of this? I'm here for you, Caroline. Let's look at some alternatives together. Have you heard about local youth organizations or shelters that might be able to provide support and guidance during this tough time? It's important for you to stay safe and seek professional help if possible. Thank you, Mariana. I will research about local youth organizations and shelters. Do you have any suggestions on how to find them? Yes, there are several ways you can find resources in your area. You could start by asking a librarian or a teacher

Hi there, you've reached the child helpline. I'm Amali. How can I assist you today? Hello, I'm Maria from Kiteto in Manyara. I'm 10 years old and I've been feeling really sad for a while now. My parents got divorced, and it's just not the same at home anymore. It makes me feel lonely and confused. I'm so sorry to hear that you're going through this, Maria. Divorce can be tough on everyone involved, especially children. Let's try to find a way for you to cope with these feelings. Have you been talking about it with anyone in your family or at school? I've tried talking to my mom, but she's always busy. My friends don't really understand what I'm going through, so it's hard to talk to them about it. That must feel very isolating. Is there someone else you could reach out to for support? A teacher or a counselor at school perhaps? I see. It's important that we find an adult who can help you navigate these feelings. Remember, it takes courage to ask for help, and I commend you for reaching out today. Now, let's focus on some things that might help you feel better. One thing we could try is finding ways to express your emotions. Drawing, writing, or even talking about them can help lighten the burden. You could also consider joining a club or activity at school where you can meet new friends who may be more understanding. That's a great idea! It's important to find healthy outlets for these feelings. Another thing I'd like to suggest is setting small goals for yourself, like spending time with friends or doing an activity you enjoy. Sometimes focusing on the positive can help take your mind off the negative thoughts

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, I'm here to help. My name is Adelaida from Mbarali, Mbeya. I'm 10 years old and I need someone to talk to about what's happening at home. My father... he gets angry a lot, especially when I don't do well in school or forget to do chores. He shouts at me and says hurtful things that make me feel small. I'm really sorry to hear that Adelaida. It sounds like you're going through a tough time. It's important to remember that it's not okay for anyone to speak to you that way, especially someone who is supposed to care for you. Have you told anyone else about what your father says? I haven't told anyone, Faustina. I feel scared and embarrassed. My mother tries to help but she's always busy with work. I don't want her to worry too. But sometimes I just cry myself to sleep at night because of his words. That sounds very difficult for you Adelaida. It's understandable that you might feel scared or ashamed, but please remember that it's not your fault. I know it might be hard, but could you try talking to someone else about what's happening? Maybe a teacher at school, or even a trusted neighbor? If you don't feel comfortable doing that yet, there are other resources that can help. I can connect you with a local social worker who can provide support and guidance. Thank you Faustina. I think I might need that help. Can you tell me how to reach the social worker? Of course Adelaida. I'll make sure to connect you with someone in Mbarali who can offer you the assistance you need. In the meantime, please remember that it's important to take care

Hello? Hi there, you've reached the child helpline. I'm Janeth. Can I help you today, Lina? From Magharibi Unguja, Mjini Magharibi, I'm 14 years old and I need some advice. I have a friend who keeps prank calling me and it's getting out of hand. They call late at night and it's waking up the whole household. It's really stressful and affecting my sleep. I'm sorry to hear that, Lina. Prank calls can be very distressing, especially when they disrupt your sleep. Have you tried talking to your friend about this? Sometimes people don't realize how their actions affect others. I have talked to them before, but they just laugh it off and continue doing it. I don't know what to do anymore. It feels like no one is listening. It can feel that way sometimes, Lina, but you're not alone. There are things we can try. Have you considered blocking their number or reporting the calls to your parents or school authorities? I haven't thought about reporting it, but I'm afraid they might get in trouble. I just want them to stop calling me. It's understandable that you don't want anyone to get in trouble, Lina, but their actions are causing you harm. It's important to prioritize your well-being. If you block their number, they might create a new one or find another way to contact you, so reporting the calls could be a good idea. I think I will try reporting it, but I'm still scared. What if they retaliate? Retaliation is always a possibility, Lina, but remember that you have the right to feel safe and respected. If they do retali

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, I'm here to help. You sound a bit sad today. That's alright, it's okay to feel this way. My name is Barke and I'm here for you. Tell me a little about yourself, Salama. I can hear the wind blowing in the background. You're from Pangani in Tanga, correct? You're 17 years old and attending high school there. It sounds like you might be going through something tough right now. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? You mentioned feeling lonely or isolated. I can imagine that can be quite challenging. Have you felt this way for a while, Salama? Are there people in your life who care about you and could offer support during these times? It's important to remember that feelings are temporary and it's okay to feel overwhelmed at times. But it's also crucial to reach out when things seem too much. You've taken the first step by reaching out today, which is a sign of strength. I wonder if there are any activities or hobbies you enjoy that might help you connect with others who share similar interests? Sometimes finding shared ground can help build connections and friendships. Have you considered joining a club or group related to one of your passions? It's also vital to prioritize self-care, Salama. This includes eating well, getting enough sleep, and making time for activities that bring joy. Taking care of yourself physically and emotionally can help improve how you feel overall. If things don't improve, it might be helpful to speak with a trusted adult in your life like a parent, teacher, or school counselor. They can offer guidance and support during this difficult time. I also encourage you to reach out again if you need someone to talk to. Remember,

Hello, child helpline? Hi there, I'm Susana. How can I assist you today? I'm Daniel from Kondoa, Dodoma. There's a concern regarding Masomakali, a 7-year-old child in our neighborhood. I've noticed that he seems to be neglected physically. Oh, Daniel, it's important that you reached out. Can you tell me more about what you've observed? What kind of physical neglect are you referring to? I've seen Masomakali several times without adequate clothing or food. His parents seem to be too occupied with their own matters to provide proper care for him. This worries me greatly as he is a young child who needs nourishment and warmth. I understand your concern, Daniel. Neglect can have serious consequences on a child's development. Are there any adults in Masomakali's life who you think could help or report this issue? A teacher, social worker, or another family member perhaps? Yes, there is a local schoolteacher named Mwanga who I believe might be able to help. He seems concerned about the children in our community and often takes an active role in ensuring their well-being. However, I'm afraid to approach him directly as I don't want to cause any trouble for Masomakali or his family. I completely understand your apprehension, Daniel. It's important to prioritize the child's safety and welfare. Mwanga is indeed a valuable resource in this situation. I encourage you to speak with him confidentially about your concerns for Masomakali. If it feels too daunting, we can help guide you through the process or connect you with local authorities if needed. Thank you, Susana. This means a lot to me and to Masomakali as well.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Natori, I'm here to help. I'm calling about a concern regarding Hamisi, a 14-year-old boy from Same, Kilimanjaro. I believe he might be a victim of human trafficking. I've noticed some unusual behavior from him recently. He's been acting secretive, avoiding conversations and rarely spends time with friends. He also seems fearful, as if there's something weighing heavily on his mind. A few days ago, I overheard a suspicious conversation between Hamisi and an older man who arrived in our village unexpectedly. The man seemed to be offering him a job in the city, promising better opportunities. Hamisi agreed without hesitation, which worried me greatly. I'm afraid that this man might be involved in trafficking, given his sudden arrival and the nature of the offer he made to Hamisi. I haven't seen Hamisi since then, and I'm deeply concerned for his safety. Natori, I appreciate you listening to my concerns. I just want to ensure that Hamisi is safe and away from harm. Could you please help me with this situation? What should I do next? Thank you for reaching out, Joyce. I'm truly sorry to hear about the situation you described. It sounds like you have a genuine concern for Hamisi's welfare, and that's commendable. First, I would recommend documenting any information related to the man who approached Hamisi, such as his name, physical description, vehicle details, or any other distinguishing features. This could potentially help law enforcement in their investigation. Second, it may be helpful to gather more information about where Hamisi went and if there are any leads on his current location. Reaching

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, I'm here to help. My name is Mohamed, how can I assist you today? I'm Eliana from Magharibi Unguja, Mjini Magharibi, and I'm 16 years old. I have a question about my dietary needs as I've recently been diagnosed with celiac disease. I'm unsure of what foods I can eat safely without causing any harm to my health. I understand your situation, Eliana. Celiac disease can be challenging to manage, especially when it comes to food. It's important to ensure you're getting the nutrients you need while avoiding gluten. Can you tell me more about what you typically eat and if you've already made any changes to your diet? I'd be happy to help guide you towards safe and healthy food choices. I usually eat rice, beans, fish, and vegetables for my meals, but I'm not sure if they are safe for me now. My mother has started preparing separate meals for me, which includes a lot of gluten-free grains like quinoa and millet. But, I'm still worried about unintentional contamination from cross-contamination with gluten-containing foods. It's great that your mother is being proactive in preparing separate meals for you, Eliana. However, it's important to ensure that there is no cross-contamination in the kitchen to prevent accidental consumption of gluten. I would recommend using separate utensils, cutting boards, and cooking surfaces for gluten-free foods to minimize any risk of contamination. Additionally, it might be helpful to educate your family members about celiac disease and its importance to maintain a strict gluten-free diet. This way, they can help

Hi, this is the child helpline. How can I assist you today? Hello, my name is Mwipopo from Kilwa, Lindi. I'm a 17-year-old girl and I need help. I've been experiencing gender-based violence at school. A teacher has been harassing me sexually for some time now. I feel scared and helpless. I'm really sorry to hear that, Mwipopo. It's important to remember that what you're going through is not your fault. You have every right to feel safe and respected. Have you told anyone about this? I tried talking to my parents but they didn't believe me. I'm too afraid to report the teacher. He threatened me, saying he would fail me in all subjects if I do. It's understandable that you might feel scared, but it's crucial to seek help. There are people who can support and protect you. Have you considered speaking to another trusted adult at school or a counselor? I don't know who else to turn to. Everyone at school seems to be on his side. I just want this to stop. You're not alone, Mwipopo. There are organizations that can help you. I can connect you with them if you'd like. Also, remember that it's important to take care of yourself during this difficult time. It might be helpful to talk to a counselor or trusted friend about what you're going through. Thank you for listening, Anyabwile. I appreciate your help. Yes, I would appreciate if you could connect me with some organizations that can help me. I will do my best to find resources for you, Mwipopo. In the meantime, please remember to take care of yourself and trust in the process.

Hello, child helpline? Hi there, I'm Aida. How can I assist you today? I'm Alasiri from Babati, Manyara. There's a concern about my 10-year-old nephew, Idi. We've noticed he seems withdrawn lately and has been having trouble at school. He's mentioned some issues with friendship. Could you help? Of course, Alasiri. Let's talk more about what's been happening with Idi. Can you tell me a bit more about the situation? What kind of friendship issues is he facing? Well, it appears that Idi is being excluded by some of his peers. He mentioned that they don't let him play during recess and sometimes make fun of him when they do interact. This has been going on for a few weeks now. I'm really sorry to hear that. Exclusion can be very distressing for a child, especially at such a young age. It's important to address this issue as soon as possible. Have you spoken with Idi about how he's feeling? Yes, we have talked about it and he feels upset and lonely. He mentioned that he doesn't know why they're treating him this way and doesn't know what to do. We've also noticed a decline in his school performance, which is concerning. It sounds like Idi is struggling with both emotional and academic difficulties due to this situation. It's crucial to help him find a resolution. Have you tried speaking with the school or the children who are excluding him? Yes, we have reached out to the school administration and they've been supportive. They're looking into the matter and will take appropriate action. As for the children, Idi has attempted to speak with them but they seem unresponsive. We don't

Hi there, you've reached the child helpline. I'm Sofia. How can I help you today? Hello, I'm Clara from Micheweni, Kaskazini Pemba. I'm 16 years old and I need some advice. Lately, I've been feeling overwhelmed with schoolwork and it's causing me a lot of stress. I'm worried about my future and whether I can handle the pressure. I understand how you feel Clara. It's normal to feel anxious about your future and academic performance. Have you spoken to anyone at school about this or is there a teacher you trust that you could talk to? There's one teacher, Miss Mwakilanga, who I feel comfortable speaking with but I haven't yet because I don't know how to put it into words. The workload feels unmanageable and I fear I won't be able to keep up. It takes courage to open up about your feelings Clara. Talking to Miss Mwakilanga could help alleviate some of the stress you're experiencing. Have you considered discussing a study schedule with her that better suits your learning style? It might help manage your workload more effectively. That sounds like a good idea, but I'm afraid she'll think I can't handle it if I ask for extra help. What if she thinks I'm not smart enough or something? Clara, it's important to remember that teachers are there to support you in your learning journey. Asking for help doesn't mean you're admitting defeat; it means you're taking steps towards success. If you approach Miss Mwakilanga with an open mind and honesty about your struggles, I believe she will respond positively and offer guidance. Thank you Sofia, that makes me

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Charles, I'm here to help. I'm Fabiola from Magharibi Unguja, Mjini Magharibi. My daughter, Miriam, who's 17, has been acting differently lately. She's been making prank calls to people she knows and causing a lot of trouble. It's not like her at all. I'm concerned because it seems like she's seeking attention in an unhealthy way. She's always been a bright student, but recently, her grades have dropped significantly. I fear something is wrong and I don't know what to do. I understand your concerns, Fabiola. It sounds like Miriam might be going through a tough time. These attention-seeking behaviors could be a cry for help. Have you talked to her about it yet? If not, I would recommend approaching the conversation with care and empathy. Yes, I've tried talking to her, but she gets defensive and shuts down. She insists everything is fine, but I can see that she's struggling. It breaks my heart to see her like this. It's important not to push too hard if she's not ready to open up yet. You could try finding ways to spend quality time with her and engage in activities she enjoys. That might help create a more comfortable environment for her to share what's on her mind. I'll do that, Charles. Thank you for your advice. I really appreciate it. If there are any resources or support groups available for teenagers dealing with similar issues, would you be able to provide me with some information? Absolutely, Fabiola. There are several local and online resources available. I can help connect you with some trusted organizations that offer counseling

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, hello Sabina. I'm Josphat. How can I assist you today? I'm calling from Mafinga, Iringa. I have a concern about my 8-year-old nephew, Jacob. He seems to be going through something and I'm worried. Can you help me understand what he might be experiencing? Oh, Sabina, it's important that we talk about this. It sounds like Jacob may be dealing with depression. Have you noticed any changes in his behavior or mood recently? Yes, I have. He used to be a cheerful and active child, but lately, he's been withdrawn and seems sad most of the time. He doesn't play as much as he used to, and even when we try to engage him in activities, he often refuses. I'm sorry to hear that, Sabina. It's possible that Jacob is experiencing depression, especially if there are no significant life events that could explain his sudden change in behavior. Depression can sometimes be a result of biological predisposition or chemical imbalances in the brain. That makes sense. I've also noticed that he doesn't seem to enjoy things he used to like anymore. He rarely smiles and when he does, it doesn't reach his eyes. Is this a common symptom? Yes, lack of enthusiasm for previously enjoyed activities is indeed a common symptom of depression in children. It's also important to note that changes in appetite or sleep patterns, frequent crying, low self-esteem, and difficulty concentrating can also be signs. Thank you, Josphat. I didn't know these could be symptoms of depression in children. What can I do to help Jacob? Firstly, it's important to ensure he receives professional

Hello? Hi there, you've reached the child helpline. I'm Maimuna. Can I help you today, Sara? From Mjini Unguja, Mjini Magharibi? I'm 12 years old and there's a problem with my school. I've been denied education because... well, because of where I come from. The school says they can't accommodate me anymore due to overcrowding, but I think it might be something else. They don't want me here because I'm from a poor family and my skin is darker than the other students. I feel so scared and lost. I don't know what to do or where to go. My parents can barely afford to feed us, let alone send me to another school. And even if they could, I'm worried they might not be able to find one that would accept me. Maimuna, I've heard about you from some of the other children who have called here before. They told me you can help me understand my rights and what I can do to fight this injustice. Can you really help me, Maimuna? I know it sounds silly, but I feel like no one else cares about my situation. My teachers say it's just a matter of resources, but they don't see the pain it causes me every day. They don't understand how much I love learning and how important it is to me. Maimuna, thank you for listening to me. I know I have a long road ahead, but knowing there are people like you who believe in my rights and want to help gives me hope. Can we discuss what my next steps should be? I'm so grateful for your support, Maimuna. Thank you for being here for me when no one else seems to care.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, I'm here to help. My name is Mfalme from Sengerema, Mwanza. I'm 17 years old and I've been feeling really low lately. I can't shake off these thoughts about ending my life. It's just too much, Adelina. I feel like there's no escape. I understand how overwhelming this might be for you, Mfalme. It's okay to feel this way, but it's important that we find a solution together. Have you been experiencing these thoughts for a long time? Yes, for quite some time now. I tried talking to my parents, but they don't really understand what I'm going through. They think I should just pull myself together, but it's not that simple. I can see how difficult this is for you, and I appreciate your courage in reaching out. It shows that there's hope within you, Mfalme. Let's talk about some things that might help. Have you ever felt this way before? Yes, a few times, but it always passes. But this time, it feels different. I can't shake off these thoughts. They consume me. It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now. I want to remind you that it's okay to ask for help and that there are people who care about you. Have you considered speaking with a trusted adult, like a teacher or a relative? I have thought about it, but I'm scared they won't understand. They might think I'm just seeking attention or being dramatic. It's important to remember that asking for help is not being dramatic, Mfalme. It shows strength and courage. Have you considered writing down your feelings? Sometimes putting

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, I'm here to help. My name's not important, but you can call me Elisia. How can I assist you today, Frederick? I'm from Mbarali, Mbeya, and I'm 14 years old. Lately, things at home have been really tough, and I was hoping to find someone who could help guide me. My parents are going through a divorce, and it's affecting everyone in our family. Oh, I'm so sorry to hear that, Frederick. Going through a divorce can be difficult for everyone involved, especially children like you. It's important to remember that it's not your fault and that you deserve love and support during this time. I understand that it might be hard to talk about, but can you tell me more about what's been happening at home? Are there any specific issues or concerns that you'd like to discuss? I appreciate you opening up to me, Frederick. It takes courage to share these feelings. Do you have someone in your life who you feel safe talking to and receiving support from? A teacher, friend, or family member? It's great that you have a trusted adult to lean on, but sometimes it can be helpful to speak with someone outside of your immediate circle. I am here for you, Frederick, and there are other resources available as well. Would you like information about counseling services or support groups in your area? I want to make sure that you feel supported during this challenging time. Is there anything else that's been on your mind or that you would like to discuss today? It sounds like things have been difficult for you lately, Frederick. I'm here to listen and offer guidance if you need it. If you ever want to talk again or have more questions, please don't

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, I'm Ken. How can I assist you today? I'm Baraka from Ruangwa, Lindi. There's a concern regarding Fausta, an 8-year-old girl in our community. I believe she might be experiencing physical abuse at home, specifically corporal punishment that seems to be escalating. I've noticed bruises on her body and heard her cry out in pain after arguments between her parents. She's become increasingly withdrawn and fearful, often flinching when touched. Take photographs of the bruises if possible, but make sure not to touch them as it may cause further harm. Also, keep a record of dates, times, and descriptions of each incident. Secondly, provide Fausta with support and reassurance. Let her know that she's not alone and that there are people who care about her. Encourage her to express her feelings and listen without judgment. Thirdly, report the situation to local authorities or a child protection agency. They have the resources and legal power to investigate and intervene if necessary. I can help you find contact information for such organizations in your area. Lastly, it's essential to prioritize Fausta's emotional well-being. Encourage her to engage in activities she enjoys, connect with supportive peers, and seek counseling services if available.

A mental health professional can provide strategies and techniques to cope with stress and manage perfectionism. I hope these suggestions help

Her employer expects her to work long hours and doesn't pay her for her labor. I'm really sorry to hear that Adela is going through this. It's important to remember that child labor is a serious issue, and no child should be forced into such a situation. How long has this been happening? It's been going on for about six months now. At first, I thought she was just helping out as part of her responsibility around the house, but it seems like things have taken a turn for the worse recently. She looks tired and stressed all the time, and she barely interacts with other children in the neighborhood anymore. I understand your concerns, Collins. It's crucial to get Adela out of this situation as soon as possible. I can help you report this case to the appropriate authorities and provide support for Adela along the way. Thank you, Noah. That would mean a lot to me and Adela. I was afraid to speak up because I didn't know who to turn to or how to handle it myself, but now that I have your help, I feel more hopeful about finding a solution. I'm glad I could provide some assistance, Collins. Together, we can make a difference for Adela and ensure her safety. In the meantime, please try to keep an eye on Adela as much as possible and encourage her to talk openly about what she's going through. The more support she has during this difficult time, the better. Thank you

Hello, child helpline? Hi there, I'm Ana. How can I assist you today? I'm Maimuna from Chake Chake, Kusini Pemba. There's a concern regarding my son, Jonathan, who is 9 years old. Recently, I've noticed he's been acting differently and I fear he may be suffering physical abuse at the hands of his caregiver. I'm so sorry to hear that, Maimuna. It's important to take such concerns seriously. Can you share some specific details about what's been happening with Jonathan? Well, he's been coming home with bruises and scratches that I can't explain. He's become withdrawn and afraid to talk about his day. Yesterday, I found him crying in his room with a swollen lip. It's crucial that we take steps to ensure Jonathan's safety. Have you spoken to anyone else about this, such as a family member or school teacher? No, I haven't. I was hesitant to bring it up because of the stigma surrounding these issues in our community. But I can't ignore the signs any longer. What should I do next? Firstly, Maimuna, it's important that you document any physical evidence you find on Jonathan. Photographs could serve as valuable evidence if a report needs to be made. Also, speak with someone you trust – a family member, doctor, or teacher – about your concerns. If the situation worsens, contact local authorities for further assistance. Thank you, Ana. I'll take action right away. I feel much more informed

Ignoring the problem won't make it go away, and it's important to take action against gender-based violence in schools. Have you considered speaking with other teachers or school administrators about the issue? You might find

Hi there, you've reached the child helpline. I'm Jamila. Can I help you? Yes, I need your help. My name is Faustina and I'm from Mbulu in Manyara. I'm 11 years old and I have a problem that I don't know how to solve. A man promised me work in the city but instead he brought me here to work long hours without pay. I feel scared and trapped, Jamila. I'm really sorry to hear that Faustina. You are not alone, and we can help you. This is illegal and it's called human trafficking. Have you been given any documents or told a different name besides your real one? Yes, I was given a new identity card with a fake name and age. The man took my original ID when he brought me here. What should I do now, Jamila? Don't worry, we will help you. First, let's make sure you are safe. Can you tell me where you are right now? Are there any other people around who could overhear our conversation? I am in a small room by myself. The door is locked and the man gave me a phone to call him if I need anything. What should I do next, Jamila? Please try to remember any details about where you are or the man's appearance. We can use that information to locate you. In the meantime, we will connect you with local authorities who can help rescue you and bring justice against your trafficker. I am scared, Jamila. What if something happens to me before they arrive? I understand your fear, Faustina. It's important to stay strong and remember that help is on the way. Try to be as quiet as possible and avoid contacting the man unless it's absolutely necessary.

One thing we can do is try to reach out to local authorities or social services to report the situation and see if they can offer support. Would you be comfortable with that? Yes, I would. But I'm worried about Daniel getting into trouble because of this. I don't want him to suffer any consequences as a result of my actions. I understand your concern, Sabas. It's important to approach the situation carefully so as not to put Daniel in danger. We can work together to ensure that his best interests are prioritized throughout the process. Would you be open to discussing this further and coming up with a plan? Yes, I would appreciate that

In the meantime, please try to stay safe and avoid doing any work for your employer. Do not engage in conversations about this with anyone unless it is someone you

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Geni, I'm here to help. I'm Asteria, from Tanga, Tanga. I'm 11 years old and I have some questions about changes in my body. Recently, I started noticing some new developments, like growing breasts and getting periods. It's a bit confusing and scary for me. I understand how you feel, Asteria. These changes are a natural part of puberty, but they can be overwhelming at times. I'm glad you reached out for help. Let's talk about what's happening to your body. Firstly, the growth of breasts is one of the earliest signs of puberty in girls. It's normal to feel self-conscious during this time, but remember that these changes are a part of growing up and becoming a woman. Secondly, getting periods means you've started menstruating. This is when your body sheds its lining each month in preparation for possible pregnancy. You might experience some discomfort or cramping, as well as mood swings. It's important to have sanitary products on hand to manage this. I can also suggest resources where you can learn more about puberty and development. Would you be interested in that? I want to ensure you feel informed and prepared during these changes. Thank you for reaching out, Asteria. It's important to talk about these things and ask questions. If you have any other concerns or need further guidance, please don't hesitate to call again. Take care and remember that it's okay to ask for help when you need it. Bye for now.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, I'm here to help. I'm Peter, a 14-year-old boy from Moshi Mjini, Kilimanjaro. I need your help. I'm really sorry for what you're going through, Peter. Remember, it's not your fault and there is help available. If you need someone to talk to, I'm here for you. Hi Nikusubila, how can I assist you today? I've been having some trouble at school. There's this academic competition coming up, and some of the older students have been bullying me and my friends. They keep calling us names and making fun of us for wanting to participate. I'm sorry to hear that you're going through this, Nikusubila. Bullying is never okay, and it's important to address the situation. Have you tried talking to a teacher or a school counselor about what's been happening? I haven't yet. I was worried that it would just make things worse. But it's been really affecting my confidence and my desire to participate in the competition. It's understandable to feel that way, but it's important to speak up and seek help. Your well-being is the top priority, and no one should have to endure bullying. I can help you come up with a plan to address the situation and support you through this. Thank you, Frederick. I really appreciate your help. I'll try talking to a teacher about what's been happening and see if we can find a solution. That's a great step, Nikusubila. Remember, you're not alone in this. If you ever need to talk or seek guidance, don't hesitate to reach out to the child helpline or any trusted adult. You deserve to feel safe and respected at school. Thank you, Frederick. I'll keep that in mind.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Hilda, I'm here to help. Hi, my name is Johnson, and I'm calling about a child named Raha from Namtumbo, Ruvuma. She's only 6 years old, and she's been running away from home a lot lately. I'm really worried about her safety. That sounds like a serious issue, Johnson. Can you tell me more about what's been happening with Raha? Well, it all started when she made friends with some older kids in the neighborhood. They've been influencing her to run away from home and go on adventures with them. I've tried talking to her about the dangers of running away, but she just won't listen. It's understandable that you're concerned about Raha's well-being. Peer influence can be a powerful thing, especially for young children. Have you tried talking to her friends' parents or involving the local authorities? I haven't spoken to her friends' parents yet, but I did report her as missing to the local police. They're doing their best to search for her, but I'm still worried she might get into trouble. It's good that you've taken steps to involve the authorities. In the meantime, it's important to continue communicating with Raha and letting her know that you care about her safety. Encouraging her to make better choices and setting boundaries with her friends may also help prevent future incidents. Thank you, Hilda. I'll keep trying to reach out to Raha and make sure she knows she can always come to me if she needs help. I appreciate your support and advice. You're welcome, Johnson. Remember, the child helpline is here to support you and provide guidance whenever you need it. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any more concerns or questions. Take care and stay strong for Raha.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Diana, I'm here to help. Hi, I'm Victoria from Iramba, Singida. I'm 15 years old and I have a problem. I have a friend who ran away from home a few days ago and I'm really worried about her. I'm sorry to hear that, Victoria. Can you tell me more about what happened? Well, my friend Linda has been having a tough time at home. Her parents are always fighting, and she told me she felt like she had no one to talk to. So, one day after school, she didn't come home. Her parents have been looking for her everywhere, but they can't find her. That must be really hard for you and her family. Have you tried talking to Linda to see if she's okay? I've been trying to call her, but her phone is off. I don't know where she could be. I'm really scared that something bad might have happened to her. It's understandable to feel scared and worried in this situation. It's important to try and reach out to her and let her know that you're there for her. Have you thought about talking to a trusted adult about what's been going on? I haven't, but I will try to talk to our school counselor tomorrow. I just hope Linda is safe and that we can find her soon. That's a good idea, Victoria. Remember, you're not alone in this. We're here to help and support you through this difficult time. If you need anything else, don't hesitate to reach out to us. Thank you, Diana. I appreciate your help and support.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Bakari, I'm here to help. Hi, my name is Busu. I'm 13 years old, and I'm calling from Unguja Kaskazini A, Kaskazini Unguja. Nice to meet you, Busu. How can I assist you today? I recently went through a breakup with my girlfriend, and I'm feeling really upset about it. I'm sorry to hear that, Busu. Breakups can be tough. Can you tell me more about what happened? We had been dating for a few months, and everything was going well. But then she suddenly told me that she didn't want to be together anymore. I don't understand why she changed her mind. It's understandable to feel confused and hurt when someone you care about ends the relationship. Have you tried talking to her about how you feel? I tried, but she doesn't want to talk to me anymore. I feel like I've lost my best friend as well as my girlfriend. It's normal to feel that way after a breakup. It's important to remember that your feelings are valid, and it's okay to grieve the loss of the relationship. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling? Not really. I didn't know who to turn to, so I decided to call the helpline. I'm glad you reached out, Busu. It's important to talk about your feelings and not keep them bottled up. Remember, it's okay to take time to heal and focus on yourself after a breakup. If you need more support, we're here for you. Thank you, Bakari. I feel a little better after talking to you.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Violet, I'm here to help. Hi, my name is Valentine, I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Magu, Mwanza. Nice to meet you, Valentine. How can I assist you today? I've been feeling really pressured by my friends at school to do things I'm not comfortable with. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, they've been talking a lot about relationships and some of them have even started dating. They keep saying I should do the same, but I don't feel ready for that. It's important to listen to your own feelings and not give in to peer pressure. Have you talked to anyone about this before? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I found this helpline number. I'm glad you reached out to us, Valentine. It's completely normal to feel this way, and it's important to make decisions that are right for you. Have you talked to your parents or a trusted adult about how you're feeling? Not yet, but I think I will now. I don't want to do anything I'm not comfortable with just to fit in. That's a very brave decision, Valentine. Remember, you can always come back to us if you need more support. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about? No, I think that's all for now. Thank you for listening to me, Violet. You're welcome, Valentine. Take care of yourself, and don't hesitate to reach out if you need anything. Goodbye. Goodbye.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Mwamba, I'm here to help. Hi, my name is Jefferson. I'm 49 years old and I'm calling about a child named Madina. She's 16 years old and she's from Mkoani, Kusini Pemba. Thank you for reaching out, Jefferson. What seems to be the issue with Madina? Well, I'm concerned because Madina has been facing emotional and psychological abuse at home. Her parents constantly criticize and belittle her, making her feel worthless and unloved. I'm sorry to hear that, Jefferson. It's important that Madina knows she is not alone and that there is help available for her. Have you talked to Madina about reaching out for support? Yes, I have. But she's scared and feels ashamed to talk about it. She's afraid of what her parents might do if they find out she's seeking help. I understand, Jefferson. It's common for children in abusive situations to feel scared and isolated. It's important for Madina to know that she has the right to be safe and to be treated with respect. Is there a trusted adult or teacher at Madina's school who can provide support? Yes, there is a teacher at her school who she trusts. I will encourage her to talk to him about what she's going through. That's a good idea, Jefferson. Encouraging Madina to speak to a trusted adult can be a crucial first step in getting her the help she needs. Thank you for reaching out and advocating for Madina. If you have any further concerns or need assistance, please don't hesitate to contact us again. Thank you, Mwamba. I appreciate your support and guidance.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Zayn speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Mariamu. I'm 16 years old and I'm from Biharamulo in Kagera. I'm calling because I need help with something really important. Of course, Mariamu. What's going on? You can share with me. I've been experiencing some gender-based violence. There's this man in my neighborhood who keeps making inappropriate comments towards me and touching me inappropriately whenever I pass by his house. I'm really sorry to hear that, Mariamu. It's really brave of you to reach out for help. No one should have to go through that. Have you told anyone else about what's been happening? No, I haven't. I was scared that no one would believe me or that they would blame me for what's been happening. It's understandable to feel that way, Mariamu. But remember, you have the right to feel safe and respected. You are not to blame for someone else's inappropriate behavior. We can work together to find a solution to this situation. Have you thought about talking to someone you trust about what's been happening? I haven't, but I feel a bit better now that I've talked to you about it. Thank you for listening and for reassuring me that it's not my fault. You're welcome, Mariamu. Remember, you can always reach out to us if you need to talk or if you need any support. Your safety and well-being are important. You are not alone in this.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Glory speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Pili. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Manyoni, Singida. Nice to meet you, Pili. What seems to be the issue that you'd like to talk about today? I've been feeling really tired and weak lately, and I keep getting headaches. I don't know what's wrong with me. I'm sorry to hear that, Pili. It's important to take care of your health. Have you been eating well and getting enough rest? I try to eat fruits and vegetables, but sometimes we don't have much food at home. And I have trouble sleeping because I worry a lot about things. I see. It sounds like your physical health might be connected to your mental health as well. It's important to try and find ways to relax and manage your stress. Have you talked to anyone about how you're feeling? Not really. I don't want to worry my parents because they already have a lot to deal with. It's understandable that you're worried about your parents, Pili. But it's important to take care of yourself too. You can try talking to a trusted adult, like a teacher or a counselor at school, about how you're feeling. They might be able to help you find ways to feel better. Okay, I'll try talking to my teacher about it. Thank you for listening, Glory. You're welcome, Pili. Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it. Take care of yourself, okay? I will. Thank you. Goodbye.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Neema speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Susana. I'm 26 years old and I'm calling about a child named Akuji. She's 16 years old and she's from Singida Vijijini, Singida. Thank you for providing that information, Susana. What seems to be the issue with Akuji? Well, I'm concerned about Akuji's physical health. She has been looking very weak and tired lately. I think she might be having some nutritional health issues. I see. It's good that you're looking out for Akuji's well-being. Can you tell me more about her diet and eating habits? Akuji's family doesn't have much food at home, so she often goes to school without eating breakfast. Sometimes, she only has one meal a day, and it's not always nutritious. That does sound concerning. It's important for Akuji to have a balanced diet to stay healthy and strong. Is there any way her family can access more food or support? I'm not sure. They don't have a lot of money to buy food, and the nearest health center is quite far away. I'm not sure what to do to help Akuji. Don't worry, Susana. We can help connect Akuji's family with resources and support in their community. We can also provide information on nutrition and health for Akuji. Thank you for reaching out and caring for Akuji's well-being. Thank you, Neema. I appreciate your help. I just want Akuji to be healthy and happy. We will do our best to support Akuji and her family. Please feel free to contact us again if you need further assistance. Thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline.

Hello, hi, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Saidi from the child helpline. How can I help you today? My name is Patricia, I'm 12 years old, and I'm calling from Ukerewe, Mwanza. I don't know where else to turn, but I need help. Of course, Patricia. What seems to be the problem? I don't have any parents. They abandoned me when I was very young. I live with my grandmother now, but she is getting old and sick. I don't know what will happen to me if something happens to her. I'm so sorry to hear that, Patricia. You are very brave for reaching out for help. It must be very difficult for you. Have you talked to anyone about this before? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to talk to. I feel lost and scared. It's understandable to feel that way, but you are not alone. We are here to help you. Are there any other family members or adults in your community who you trust and can talk to about your situation? There are some neighbors who have been kind to me, but I don't want to burden them with my problems. I just want to know if there is any help available for children like me who have been abandoned by their parents. There are organizations and services that can provide support and assistance to children in situations like yours. We can help connect you with local resources and support networks to ensure you are safe and cared for. Would you like me to help you with that, Patricia? Yes, please. Thank you so much, Saidi. I feel a little relieved knowing that there is help out there for children like me. Thank you for listening to me. You are very welcome, Patricia. You are not alone, and we are here to support you. Let's work together to find the help you need.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Fredrick, I'm 10 years old, and I'm calling from Mkoani, Kusini Pemba. Hello Fredrick, my name is Ambonisye and I'm here to help. What seems to be the problem? I... I don't really know how to say this, but I think I've been sexually abused by a family member. I'm so sorry to hear that, Fredrick. It takes a lot of courage to talk about something like this. Can you tell me more about what happened? Well, my uncle has been touching me inappropriately when no one else is around. He tells me not to tell anyone or else something bad will happen. Fredrick, it's important for you to know that what your uncle is doing is wrong and you shouldn't have to go through this. Have you told anyone else about this? No, I was too scared to say anything. But it's been happening for a while now and I don't know what to do. You did the right thing by reaching out to us, Fredrick. We are here to help and we will make sure you're safe. I will need to report this to the authorities so they can investigate and protect you from any further harm. Is that okay with you? Yes, please do whatever you need to do to make it stop. I just want it to end. I understand, Fredrick. You are very brave for speaking up. I will make sure you get the help and support you need. You are not alone in this. Thank you for trusting us and reaching out.

Hello, Child Helpline, you're speaking with Sina. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Hilda, I'm 15 years old, and I'm calling from Mpanda, Rukwa. Nice to meet you, Hilda. What's on your mind today? I'm really struggling with getting enough food and clothes. My family is going through a tough time, and we can't afford to buy proper meals or new clothes. I'm sorry to hear that, Hilda. It must be tough for you. Have you tried talking to anyone about this, like a teacher or a neighbor? I haven't really opened up to anyone about it. I feel like I'm burdening them with my problems. It's important to remember that it's okay to ask for help when you need it. We're here to support you. Have you talked to your parents about your concerns? Yes, I have, but they are also struggling to make ends meet. We barely have enough to cover our basic needs. I understand, Hilda. It's good that you're reaching out for help. Have you tried accessing any local resources, like food banks or clothing donations? I didn't know there were resources like that available. Is there a food bank or donation center near my area? Yes, there is a food bank near the Police Station in Mpanda that provides assistance to families in need. I can help connect you with them if you'd like. That would be great, thank you so much. I really appreciate your help, Sina. You're welcome, Hilda. Remember, you're not alone in this. We're here to support you through this difficult time.

Hello, Child Helpline, how may I help you today? Hi, my name is Ambata. I'm 17 years old and I live in Ilala, Dar es Salaam. Hello Ambata, I'm Angolwisye from the child helpline. How are you feeling today? I'm not doing so good, Angolwisye. I just went through a breakup with my girlfriend and I'm feeling really down about it. I'm sorry to hear that, Ambata. Breakups can be really tough. Can you tell me more about what happened? Well, we've been together for almost a year now and everything was going great. But recently, we started having a lot of fights and disagreements. And yesterday, she told me that she doesn't want to be with me anymore. It's completely normal to feel sad and upset after a breakup, Ambata. It's important to take care of yourself during this difficult time. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling? No, I haven't really talked to anyone about it. I just feel so lost and alone right now. It's okay to feel that way, Ambata. It's important to reach out for support when you're going through a tough time. Have you thought about talking to a trusted friend or family member about what you're going through? I haven't really thought about it, but maybe I should. I just feel so overwhelmed by everything right now. Talking to someone you trust can help you feel less alone, Ambata. And remember, it's okay to take your time to heal and move on from this breakup. You deserve to be happy and supported during this time.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Norah. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Milka. I'm 13 years old and I'm calling from Masasi, Mtwara. Hi Milka, how can I assist you today? I'm really scared because there was a big storm last night and it destroyed our house. My family and I are now homeless and we don't know what to do. I'm so sorry to hear that, Milka. It must be a very difficult situation for you and your family. Have you been able to find a safe place to stay for the time being? No, we've been staying with our neighbors but it's very crowded and uncomfortable. I don't know where else we can go. I understand, Milka. It's important to prioritize your safety and well-being during this time. Have you contacted any local authorities or organizations for assistance? Yes, we went to St. Mary's Church for help, but they said they don't have enough resources to support us. I don't know what to do now. I'm glad you reached out to us, Milka. We can help connect you with emergency response services and organizations that can provide assistance to you and your family. Can you provide me with your contact information so we can follow up with you? Yes, my phone number is 0789XXXXXX. Thank you so much for your help, Norah. I was feeling really lost and scared, but now I feel like there's hope. You're welcome, Milka. We're here to support you through this difficult time. Please stay safe and take care of yourself and your family. We'll be in touch with you soon.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Justin speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, Justin. My name is Stela, and I'm 15 years old. I'm calling from Mafinga, Iringa. Nice to meet you, Stela. How can I assist you today? I'm really scared, Justin. My parents fight a lot at home, and it's getting worse. I'm sorry to hear that, Stela. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? My dad is always yelling at my mom, and sometimes he hits her. I can hear everything from my room, and it's really scary. I can imagine how frightening that must be for you, Stela. It's not okay for anyone to be treated like that. Have you talked to anyone about this before? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I found out about the child helpline. I'm glad you reached out to us, Stela. It's important that you have someone to talk to about what you're going through. Have you ever felt unsafe because of the fighting at home? Yes, sometimes I'm scared that my dad might hurt me or my mom. I don't know what to do. You're very brave for speaking up, Stela. No one should have to live in fear like that. We can help you find support and resources to keep you safe. Would you like me to connect you with someone who can help? Yes, please. I don't want things to keep getting worse at home. I'll make sure to connect you with the right people, Stela. You're not alone in this, and we're here to support you every step of the way. Thank you for reaching out for help.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Ghubari speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Ghubari, my name is Jordan. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Manyoni, Singida. Hello Jordan, how can I assist you today? I need help, Ghubari. My parents have been fighting a lot lately and I can't take it anymore. I want to run away from home. I'm sorry to hear that, Jordan. Running away may not be the best solution. Can you tell me more about what's been happening at home? My parents argue all the time and I feel like I'm always caught in the middle. I just want to escape from all the yelling and the tension. I understand how difficult that must be for you, Jordan. Have you talked to your parents about how you're feeling? I've tried, but they don't listen. They're always too busy fighting with each other. I see. It's important for you to know that there are other ways to cope with family conflicts. Running away can be dangerous, especially for someone your age. Have you considered talking to a trusted adult, like a teacher or a family friend, about what's been happening at home? I haven't thought about that. I guess I could talk to my teacher. But what if things don't get better at home? It's good to have a plan, Jordan. If things don't improve, you can always reach out to the child helpline for support. We're here to listen and help you through difficult situations. Remember, there are people who care about your well-being and want to help you. Thank you, Ghubari. I'll talk to my teacher and see if they can help. I won't run away. That's great to hear, Jordan. Remember, you're not alone in this. Feel free to call us back if you need more support. Take care of yourself.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Edisa speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Anyabwile. I am 13 years old and I am calling from Chemba, Dodoma. Nice to meet you, Anyabwile. How can I assist you today? I am calling because I have noticed a lot of my friends dropping out of school and not attending classes regularly. That sounds like a serious issue. Can you tell me more about what you have observed? Yes, many of my friends are starting to skip school more often and some have completely stopped going. They say they are bored with school and would rather do other things. I see. It's important for children to attend school regularly to get a good education. Have you tried talking to your friends about the importance of staying in school? Yes, I have tried talking to them, but they don't seem to listen to me. I am worried about their future and what will happen to them if they don't finish their education. I understand your concerns, Anyabwile. It's great that you care about your friends and want to help them. Have you spoken to any adults or teachers about this issue? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to talk to about it until I found this helpline number. I'm glad you reached out to us. We can help you find a solution to this problem. I will provide you with some guidance on how to address this issue with the appropriate authorities. Thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. Thank you, Edisa. I appreciate your help.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Russom speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Jina. I'm 12 years old and I'm from Handeni, Tanga. Nice to meet you, Jina. What seems to be troubling you today? I've been having some problems with my friends at school. They've been excluding me from activities and it's making me feel really lonely. I'm sorry to hear that, Jina. It must be tough to feel left out. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, we used to play football together during lunch breaks, but recently they've been forming their own group and not inviting me to join them. They even make fun of me sometimes. That sounds really hurtful, Jina. Have you tried talking to your friends about how you feel? I did try to talk to them, but they just brushed me off and said I was being too sensitive. I don't know what to do. It's important to remember that it's not your fault, Jina. Sometimes friends can be mean without realizing it. Have you thought about talking to a teacher or a trusted adult at school about what's been happening? I haven't, but I guess that's a good idea. I just don't want to make things worse. Talking to a teacher or an adult can help them understand what's going on and they might be able to help mediate the situation. Remember, you deserve to have friends who treat you with kindness and respect. Thank you, Russom. I'll try talking to a teacher about it. I appreciate your advice. You're welcome, Jina. Remember, you're not alone and there are people who care about you. Take care and don't hesitate to call us again if you need more support.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Zahara, I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Ilemela, Mwanza. Hello Zahara, I'm Neema from the child helpline. How are you feeling today? I'm not feeling very good, Neema. I've been feeling really sad and down lately. I'm sorry to hear that, Zahara. Can you tell me a little bit more about what's been going on? Well, my family recently moved to a new town and I had to change schools. I miss my old friends and I'm having a hard time making new ones. It's completely normal to feel sad and overwhelmed with major life changes like moving, Zahara. It's okay to feel the way you do. But I just feel so alone and like I don't belong here. I miss my old home and everything that was familiar to me. It's okay to miss your old home, Zahara. It's natural to feel that way when you go through big changes. Have you talked to anyone about how you're feeling? No, I haven't really told anyone how I feel. I didn't think anyone would understand. It's important to talk about your feelings, Zahara. It can really help to share what you're going through with someone who can listen and support you. Thank you, Neema. I feel a little better just talking to you about it. I'm glad to hear that, Zahara. Remember, it's okay to reach out for help whenever you need it. You're not alone in this.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Jasmin, I'm 11 years old, and I live in Kati Unguja, Kusini Unguja. Hello Jasmin, I'm Emmanuel from the child helpline. What seems to be the problem? I'm being bullied at school, and it's making me really sad. I'm sorry to hear that, Jasmin. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, some of the kids in my class keep excluding me from activities during break time. They whisper and laugh when I try to join in, and it makes me feel really left out. That sounds like a tough situation to be in, Jasmin. Have you tried talking to a teacher or a parent about what's been going on? I haven't told anyone yet. I was afraid they wouldn't believe me or that it would make the bullying worse. It's important to speak up about what you're going through, Jasmin. Bullying is never okay, and everyone deserves to feel safe and included at school. You deserve support in dealing with this. I just don't know what to do. I feel so lonely and scared. I understand how you must be feeling, but remember, you're not alone in this. We can work together to come up with a plan to address the bullying and make things better for you at school. Thank you, Emmanuel. I really appreciate your help. It feels good to talk about this with someone who cares. I'm always here to listen, Jasmin. Let's work on finding a solution together so you can feel happier and safer at school.

Hey, um, hi there. I'm Noah. I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Ulanga, Morogoro. Hello Noah, this is Clement from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? Well, I wanted to talk about something important. I think I need some help with sexual health education. Of course, Noah. It's great that you're reaching out for information on sexual health. What specific questions do you have? I just feel like I don't know enough about it, you know? Like, I hear things at school and from friends, but I'm not sure what's true and what's not. That's completely understandable, Noah. It's important to have accurate information about sexual health. Have you had any formal education on the topic at school? Not really, we've had some basic biology lessons, but nothing specific about sexual health or relationships. I see. It's important to have a good understanding of your body and how it works. Do you have any specific questions or concerns about sexual health that you'd like to discuss? Well, I've heard about things like puberty, contraception, and STIs, but I'm not sure how they all fit together. Can you help me understand more about these topics? Absolutely, Noah. Let's start with puberty and how your body changes during this time. Have you noticed any changes in your body recently? Yeah, I've noticed some changes like growing taller and starting to develop breasts. It's all kind of confusing, to be honest. It's completely normal to feel that way, Noah. Puberty is a time of significant changes, both physically and emotionally. Let's talk about these changes and how you can take care of your body during this time.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Laurence, I'm 31 years old, and I'm calling about a child named Mwakitwange from Ilala, Dar es Salaam. Nice to meet you Laurence, my name is Elia and I am here to help. What seems to be the issue regarding Mwakitwange? I am concerned about Mwakitwange's nutrition. I noticed that he seems to be underweight and I wanted to make sure he is getting the proper nutrition he needs. That's a valid concern, Laurence. It's important to ensure that children are receiving the necessary nutrients for their growth and development. Can you tell me more about Mwakitwange's feeding practices? Well, Mwakitwange's family mainly relies on maize and beans for their meals. I'm not sure if that is providing him with all the nutrients he needs. It's great that they are providing him with staple foods, but it's also important to include a variety of foods in his diet to ensure he is getting all the necessary nutrients. Have you noticed any signs of malnutrition in Mwakitwange? I haven't noticed any specific signs, but I just want to make sure he is healthy and growing properly. Do you have any suggestions on how his family can improve his nutrition? I would recommend incorporating more fruits, vegetables, and protein-rich foods into Mwakitwange's diet. It's also important to ensure he is getting enough water and that his meals are balanced. If you need further assistance, feel free to reach out to local health facilities for guidance. Thank you so much for your help, Elia. I will pass along this information to Mwakitwange's family and make sure they are aware of the importance of a balanced diet for his health. You're welcome, Laurence. Remember, we are here to support you and Mwakitwange whenever you need assistance. Have a great day.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Julius speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Julius, my name is Emma and I'm calling about a child named Miry. Yes, she has tried talking to her teachers, but they haven't been able to stop the bullying. She's feeling very discouraged and it's affecting her performance in the competition. It's important that Miry feels supported and safe at school. Have you tried discussing the situation with her parents or guardians? It's great that Miry has a strong support system. I recommend reaching out to the school again and requesting a meeting with the teachers and school administration to address the bullying. We can also provide additional resources and support for Miry if needed. Thank you, Julius. I will make sure to follow up with the school and keep you updated on the situation. Please do, Emma. We are here to support Miry and any other children facing similar challenges. Thank you for reaching out to us.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Upendo, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Anga. I'm calling about a child in my village, Salim. There are programs in place to help families in need access nutritious food for their children. That would be a huge relief for Salim and his family. Thank you, Upendo. We'll do everything we can to support Salim and his family. Thank you for caring about the well-being of children in your community.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Idili, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Bibiana. I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Handeni Mjini in Tanga. Hello Bibiana, it's nice to meet you. How are you feeling today? I'm not doing so well, Idili. I've been feeling really sad and overwhelmed lately. I've been having these thoughts of hurting myself. I don't know, everything just feels so heavy and hard to deal with. I feel like I'm all alone and no one understands me. I just want all this pain to go away. I'm here to listen to you, Bibiana. You are not alone. Have you ever acted on these thoughts of hurting yourself? Yes, I have. I've been cutting myself as a way to cope with the pain. I'm so sorry to hear that, Bibiana. Self-harm is not a healthy way to cope with your feelings. It's important that we find healthier ways for you to manage your emotions. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to. But I saw the helpline number at the Post Office and decided to call. I'm glad you reached out, Bibiana. You are very brave for doing so. We can work together to help you feel better. Would you be open to talking to a counselor or therapist about your feelings? Yes, I think that would be helpful. Thank you for listening to me, Idili.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Pili speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Pili, my name is Mike, I'm 14 years old, and I'm calling from Unguja Kaskazini B in Kaskazini Unguja. I've been feeling really sick lately and I don't know what to do.
