Our house got flooded last week, and we lost a lot of our belongings. I can imagine how tough that must be for you and your family. It's important to talk about these feelings. Have you been able to talk to anyone about what you're going through? Not really. My parents are busy trying to fix the damages, and I don't want to burden them with my worries. It's completely normal to feel overwhelmed during times like this. Remember, it's okay to seek support and talk about your feelings. Is there anything specific you would like advice or help with? I just need some guidance on how to cope with the aftermath of the natural disaster and how to stay safe during these difficult times. I'm here to support you, Kombo. Let's discuss some safety measures you can take and ways to cope with the impact of the natural disaster. Remember, you're not alone in this. We are here to help you through this challenging time.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Masomakali speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Dina. I'm 12 years old, a girl from Arumeru Magharibi, Arusha. I'm having some trouble with my friends. Tell me more about what's been happening, Dina. Well, lately, my friends have been excluding me from things. They used to always invite me to hang out with them, but now they leave me out of activities and conversations. It makes me feel really lonely and sad. I'm sorry to hear that, Dina. It's tough when you feel left out by your friends. Have you tried talking to them about how you feel? I have, but they just brush it off and say I'm overreacting. It's like they don't care about my feelings at all. That sounds really hurtful, Dina. It's important to have friends who respect and value you. Have you thought about making new friends or joining different activities where you feel included? I've thought about it, but I'm worried about being alone if I leave this group of friends. I don't want to lose the only friends I have. I understand your concerns, Dina. It's important to prioritize your own well-being and happiness. Remember that you deserve friends who treat you with kindness and respect. If you ever feel overwhelmed or need someone to talk to, you can always reach out to the Child Helpline for support. Our number is 07499 903386. Thank you, Masomakali. I appreciate your advice and for listening to me. It feels good to know that there's someone I can talk to about my friendship issues.

Hello, um, hi there. Hi, this is Theresia from the child helpline. How can I help you today? My name is Russom, I am 17 years old, and I am from Mufindi, Iringa. Nice to meet you, Russom. What seems to be troubling you today? I've been feeling really down lately. I think I might be depressed. I'm sorry to hear that, Russom. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? Well, I've been feeling really lonely and isolated. I don't have many friends at school, and I feel like I don't fit in. It sounds like you're experiencing social rejection. That must be really tough. Yeah, it's been really hard. I feel like no one understands me and I don't have anyone to talk to. It's important to remember that you're not alone, Russom. We are here to listen and support you. Thank you, I really appreciate that. I just don't know how to cope with these feelings. It's okay to feel this way, Russom. Have you considered talking to a trusted adult or a counselor at your school? I haven't really thought about that. I guess it wouldn't hurt to reach out for help. Definitely. It's important to take care of your mental health. Remember, you are strong and you deserve to feel happy and supported. Thank you, Theresia. I feel a little better talking to you. I will try to seek help and work on feeling better. I'm glad to hear that, Russom. Remember, you can always call us if you need to talk. Take care of yourself.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Alamisi, how can I assist you today? Hey there, Alamisi. My name is Collins, I'm 35 years old, and I'm calling about a child named Clement who lives in Lindi Vijijini, Lindi. Thank you for reaching out, Collins. How old is Clement? Clement is only 7 years old, and I'm concerned about him. He's been working long hours in the fields to help his family make ends meet. I'm sorry to hear that, Collins. It sounds like Clement may be experiencing child labor. Can you tell me more about the type of work he's doing? Yes, he's helping his parents with farming tasks like weeding and harvesting. They are struggling financially, so Clement feels like he needs to contribute to their income. I see. It's important that children like Clement are protected from engaging in hazardous or exploitative work. Have you talked to his parents about this situation? Yes, I have, but they feel like they have no other choice. They are grateful for Clement's help, but I can see how it's affecting his education and well-being. Thank you for sharing this with me, Collins. We can provide support and guidance to Clement's family on alternative ways to improve their income without involving him in labor. Would you be willing to provide us with more details so we can follow up on this case? Absolutely, Alamisi. I just want what's best for Clement, and I appreciate your help in finding a solution to this situation. Thank you for your concern, Collins. We will do our best to assist Clement and his family. Please stay in touch with us if you have any updates or further concerns.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Zena speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Zena, my name is Joshua and I'm calling about a child named Frederick. He's a 6-year-old boy from Serengeti, Mara. I'm really concerned about him. Thank you for reaching out, Joshua. Could you please tell me what's been going on with Frederick? Well, it's about gender-based violence. Frederick is being discriminated against because of his gender. His parents treat him differently from his sisters. They don't allow him to participate in certain activities just because he's a boy. It breaks my heart to see him going through this. I'm sorry to hear that, Joshua. Gender discrimination is a serious issue that can have long-lasting effects on a child's well-being. Have you talked to Frederick's parents about your concerns? Yes, I have tried to talk to them, but they don't seem to understand the impact of their actions. I'm afraid Frederick is growing up in an environment where he feels inferior just because he's a boy. It's important to address this issue before it escalates further. I can provide you with information on local resources and support services that can help Frederick and his family. We can also discuss ways to advocate for gender equality in his community. Thank you, Zena. I really appreciate your help. I just want Frederick to grow up in a safe and supportive environment where he can thrive without being limited by his gender. You're doing the right thing by speaking up for Frederick. We will work together to ensure that he receives the support he needs. Please know that you're not alone in this, and we are here to help.

Hello, Child Helpline. This is John speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Bibiana, I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Mpwapwa in Dodoma. I'm really struggling with academic pressure at school. I'm sorry to hear that, Bibiana. Can you tell me more about what's going on? Well, my parents have really high expectations for me when it comes to my grades. They always want me to be at the top of my class and get straight A's. But it's just so much pressure and I feel like I'm constantly stressing out about school. That sounds really tough, Bibiana. It's important to remember that it's okay to not be perfect all the time. Have you tried talking to your parents about how you're feeling? I've tried, but they just tell me that I need to work harder and that I should be able to handle the pressure. I feel like I can't live up to their expectations no matter how hard I try. It sounds like you're really struggling with this, Bibiana. Have you spoken to anyone at school about how you're feeling? Not really. I don't really feel comfortable talking to my teachers about this. I just don't know what to do anymore. It's okay, Bibiana. It's really brave of you to reach out for help. Just remember that it's important to take care of yourself and your mental health. Have you thought about seeking support from a counselor at your school or maybe a trusted adult in your community? I haven't thought about that, but maybe I could talk to someone at the community center. Thank you for listening, John. It feels good to talk about this. I'm glad I could help, Bibiana. Remember, it's important to prioritize your well-being and not let the pressure get to you. Don't hesitate to reach out for support whenever you need it. Take care of yourself, okay? Thank you, John. I will.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Mwanangwa, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Asha. I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Ikungi in Singida. Hello Asha, it's nice to speak with you. How are you feeling today? I'm not doing so well, Mwanangwa. I've been having some really dark thoughts lately. I'm sorry to hear that, Asha. Can you tell me more about what you've been feeling? I've been feeling really sad and hopeless, like there's no point in anything. I've even thought about hurting myself. I'm glad you reached out to us, Asha. It's really brave of you to talk about these feelings. Have you ever acted on these thoughts? No, I haven't actually done anything, but they just keep coming back. It's important to remember that these thoughts are temporary, Asha. You don't have to go through this alone. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling? No, I haven't. I was too scared to tell anyone. It's okay to feel scared, Asha. But talking about your feelings can really help. We're here to listen and support you. Would you be willing to talk to a counselor or a trusted adult about what you're going through? I think I can do that. Thank you for listening to me, Mwanangwa. You're welcome, Asha. Remember, you are not alone in this. We're here for you whenever you need to talk. Take care of yourself, okay? Thank you, Mwanangwa. Goodbye.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Huruma speaking, how can I help you today? Hey, my name is Julius and I'm 15 years old. I'm calling from Shinyanga Mjini, Shinyanga. Hello Julius, how are you feeling today? I'm feeling really anxious and stressed out. I can't seem to shake this feeling of worry and fear. I'm sorry to hear that, Julius. Can you tell me more about what's been causing you to feel this way? Well, my parents are going through a divorce and I'm really struggling with the idea of not having them both around all the time. I feel like I'm being pulled in different directions and it's really overwhelming. That sounds like a difficult situation to be in, Julius. It's understandable that you would feel anxious and stressed about your parents' divorce. Have you talked to anyone about how you're feeling? Not really, I haven't felt comfortable opening up to anyone about it. It's important to remember that it's okay to feel this way and that you're not alone in dealing with these emotions. Have you tried any coping mechanisms to help you manage your anxiety? I've tried taking deep breaths and going for walks, but it only helps temporarily. Those are good strategies, Julius. Have you thought about seeking professional help or talking to a counselor about your feelings? I haven't considered it before, but I think it might be a good idea. Do you know of any resources or places I could go for help in Shinyanga Mjini? Yes, there are counseling services available at the Central Hospital in Shinyanga Mjini that could provide you with the support you need. It's important to take care of your mental health during this difficult time, Julius. Thank you, Huruma. I appreciate your advice and I'll look into seeking help at the Central Hospital.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Jacob speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Mosi, I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Kyela, Mbeya. Nice to meet you, Mosi. What seems to be the issue today? Well, I've been making prank calls to people in my community and now I feel guilty about it. I see. Can you tell me more about why you've been making these prank calls? I guess I just wanted attention. My friends at school were doing it, and I wanted to fit in. It's understandable to want to feel included, but it's important to remember that prank calls can have negative consequences. Have you thought about how the people you called might have felt? Yeah, I didn't really think about that at the time. I just wanted to be funny. It's okay, Mosi. We all make mistakes, but it's important to learn from them. Have you talked to your friends about how you're feeling now? No, I haven't. I'm not sure how they'll react. It might be a good idea to talk to them and explain how you're feeling. It's important to surround yourself with friends who support you in positive ways. Also, have you thought about finding other ways to seek attention that are more positive and constructive? I haven't really thought about that. Maybe I could join a club at the community center or something. That sounds like a great idea, Mosi. The community center is a great place to meet new friends and try out different activities. Remember, it's never too late to make a change for the better.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Julieth, how can I assist you today? Hi Julieth, my name is Cecilia. I'm 15 years old and I'm from Kibondo, Kigoma. Nice to meet you, Cecilia. How can I help you today? I'm calling because I ran away from home and I don't know where to go. I'm sorry to hear that, Cecilia. Can you tell me more about why you ran away? My parents have been fighting a lot lately, and I just couldn't take it anymore. I needed to get away. I understand how difficult that must be for you. Do you have a safe place to stay right now? I'm staying with a friend, but I know I can't stay here forever. I'm worried about what will happen when I go back home. It's important for us to make sure you are safe, Cecilia. Have you talked to anyone about what's going on at home? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to talk to until I found this helpline number. I'm glad you reached out to us, Cecilia. We can help you figure out the best way to handle this situation. Have you thought about talking to a trusted adult, like a teacher or counselor at your school? I'm too scared to go back to school right now. But maybe I can talk to my teacher when things calm down at home. That sounds like a good plan, Cecilia. In the meantime, is there anything else you would like to discuss or any other support you need? No, I think that's all for now. Thank you for listening, Julieth. You're welcome, Cecilia. Remember, we are here to help you whenever you need it. Take care of yourself.

Hello, is this the child helpline? I need to talk to someone. Hi there, this is Bora from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Florence. I'm 14 years old and I'm from Kati Unguja, Kusini Unguja. I'm calling because I need help with something that's been bothering me. Of course, Florence. You can talk to me about anything. What's been troubling you? Well, I've been experiencing gender-based violence at home. My parents treat me differently because I'm a girl. They always give my brother more attention and opportunities than me. It's not fair. I'm really sorry to hear that, Florence. Gender discrimination is a serious issue. You deserve to be treated with respect and equality. Have you talked to anyone about this before? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I found out about the child helpline. I just feel so alone and misunderstood. You're not alone, Florence. We're here to support you. It's important to speak up about what you're going through. Have you thought about talking to a trusted adult or teacher about this? I'm too scared to speak to anyone in my community. I'm afraid they won't understand or believe me. That's why I reached out to you. I'm glad you reached out, Florence. It takes courage to talk about these things. We can help you come up with a plan to address the gender-based violence you're facing. You deserve to feel safe and respected in your own home. Thank you, Bora. I feel a bit better already knowing that someone cares and wants to help me.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Florida speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Dennis. I'm 11 years old, and I'm calling from Magharibi Unguja, Mjini Magharibi. Nice to meet you, Dennis. What seems to be the problem? Well, I'm really worried about my parents. They both drink a lot, and it's causing a lot of problems in our family. I'm sorry to hear that, Dennis. It must be really tough for you to deal with. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? My parents argue a lot when they drink, and sometimes things get really out of hand. I'm scared that something bad might happen one day. It's understandable that you're feeling scared and worried about your parents' behavior. Have you tried talking to them about how you feel? I've tried, but they just get angry and tell me to mind my own business. I don't know what to do anymore. You're very brave for reaching out for help, Dennis. It's important for you to know that you're not alone in this situation. Have you thought about talking to a trusted adult or a teacher about what's going on? I haven't really talked to anyone about it, but I'm glad I called you. Thank you for listening to me. Of course, Dennis. That's what we're here for. Remember, it's not your fault, and you deserve to feel safe and supported. If things get too overwhelming, don't hesitate to call us back at 07349 429173. We're here to help you.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline, my name is Haji. How can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Theodora, I'm a 14-year-old girl from Iramba, Singida. I need help with something really serious. Of course, Theodora. What seems to be the issue you're facing? I think I might be in danger of human trafficking. There's this man who approached me promising a job in the city, but I'm starting to feel like something is not right. I'm glad you reached out, Theodora. It's important to trust your instincts in situations like these. Can you tell me more about this man and the job he offered you? He said he could get me a job as a housemaid in the city with a good salary. But now he's asking me to leave my family and come with him, and I'm scared. I understand why you would feel scared, Theodora. It's important not to make any decisions until you have all the information you need. Can you tell me if this man has asked you to do anything else that makes you uncomfortable? He asked me to keep our conversations a secret from my family, and he doesn't want me to ask too many questions about the job or where exactly we would be going. It's good that you're sharing these details with me, Theodora. It's important to remember that you have the right to ask questions and seek help if you feel unsafe. I can help you connect with local authorities who can investigate this situation further and ensure your safety. Is that something you would like me to do? Yes, please. I'm really scared and I don't want to put myself in danger. Thank you for listening and helping me, Haji. You're very brave for reaching out, Theodora. I will ensure that you receive the support you need to stay safe. Stay on the line while I make the necessary arrangements.

Hello, um, hi there. Hi, this is Rose from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi Rose, my name is Vincent. I'm 13 years old and I'm calling from Mwanga, Kilimanjaro. Nice to meet you, Vincent. What seems to be the problem? Well, I'm having some trouble at home. My older brother has been hitting me a lot lately. It's getting really bad and I don't know what to do. I'm sorry to hear that, Vincent. It's not okay for anyone to hurt you. Have you talked to anyone about this before? No, I've been too scared to tell anyone. But it's getting worse and I don't know how to make it stop. It's brave of you to reach out for help, Vincent. It's important to speak up about what's happening to you. Do you feel safe at home right now? No, I don't feel safe. I'm always worried about when the next time he will hit me. I understand, Vincent. You deserve to feel safe in your own home. We can help you figure out a plan to keep yourself safe. Have you thought about talking to your parents or another trusted adult about what's been happening? I haven't, but maybe I should. I just don't want to make things worse. It's important to speak up so that you can get the help you need. We can also connect you with local resources that can support you through this difficult time. You don't have to go through this alone, Vincent. Thank you, Rose. I feel a little better knowing that I can talk to someone about this. You're welcome, Vincent. Remember, it's not your fault and you deserve to be safe. Let's work together to find a solution to this problem.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Amri speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Amri, my name is Stela. I'm 11 years old, a girl from Unguja Kaskazini B, Kaskazini Unguja. I'm feeling really anxious about my schoolwork. I'm sorry to hear that, Stela. Can you tell me more about what's been causing you stress? Well, I have exams coming up soon and I feel like I'm not prepared enough. I keep worrying about failing and disappointing my parents. It's completely normal to feel anxious about exams, Stela. But remember, it's okay to make mistakes and it's important to try your best. Have you been studying regularly? Yes, I have been studying a lot, but I still feel like it's not enough. I can't seem to concentrate properly. Have you tried talking to your teachers or parents about how you're feeling? Not really, I feel like they expect me to do well and I don't want to let them down. It's important to communicate your feelings, Stela. Your teachers and parents care about you and want to support you through this. Maybe they can offer you some guidance on how to study effectively. I'll try talking to them, but I still feel so overwhelmed. What if I fail? Failure is a part of learning, Stela. It's okay to not be perfect. Just do your best and remember that your worth is not defined by your grades. Thank you, Amri. I feel a little better after talking to you. I'll try to talk to my parents and teachers about how I'm feeling. I'm glad I could help, Stela. Remember, you can always call us if you need someone to talk to. Take care and good luck with your exams. Thank you, Amri. Goodbye.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Adika, how can I help you today? Hi Adika, my name is Omar. I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Tandahimba, Mtwara. Nice to meet you, Omar. How can I assist you today? I'm really worried about my little sister, Adika. She's only 6 years old and she's been sick for a while now. My parents don't take her to the hospital or give her any medicine. I'm sorry to hear that, Omar. It sounds like your sister might be experiencing medical neglect. Have you tried talking to your parents about this? Yes, I've tried talking to them multiple times, but they just brush me off. They say we can't afford medical care. I understand how frustrating that must be for you, Omar. It's important that your sister gets the help she needs. Have you considered reaching out to any other adults for support, like a teacher or a neighbor? I haven't thought about that. But I don't know who to turn to for help. You can also consider visiting the police station in your area, they may be able to intervene in situations like this. Your sister's health is important and shouldn't be neglected. Thank you, Adika. I will try talking to someone at the police station. I just want my sister to feel better. You're doing the right thing by seeking help, Omar. Remember, you can always call us back if you need any more support. Take care of yourself and your sister.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi there, my name is Vincent, I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Kigoma Ujiji, Kigoma. Hello Vincent, this is Habiba from the child helpline. How are you today? I'm not doing so great, Habiba. I wanted to talk to someone about school dropouts and truancy in my community. I'm sorry to hear that, Vincent. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, a lot of kids in my neighborhood have been skipping school lately. Some of them just don't show up at all, and others leave in the middle of the day. That must be really tough to see, Vincent. Do you know why they're skipping school? I think some of them are struggling with their schoolwork and feel embarrassed to go to class. Others might have family problems or responsibilities at home. It sounds like there are a lot of different reasons why kids might be dropping out or skipping school. Have you talked to anyone about this issue before? Not really, I didn't know who to talk to until I found out about the child helpline. I just want to help my friends and make sure they get the support they need. I'm glad you reached out, Vincent. It's important to address these issues early on so that we can help prevent more kids from dropping out. Thank you for caring about your friends and community. Thank you, Habiba. I just want to see all my friends succeed and have a better future.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Mwamba speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Angela. I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Sumbawanga Vijijini in Rukwa. Hello Angela, nice to meet you. How can I assist you today? I...I don't know how to say this, but I think I'm being sexually abused. I'm so sorry to hear that, Angela. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? There's this man online who keeps sending me inappropriate messages and asking me to do things that make me feel uncomfortable. That sounds really scary, Angela. It's important to remember that what this man is doing is not okay and you don't have to keep it a secret. Have you told anyone else about this? No, I was too scared to tell anyone. But then I remembered about the child helpline and I decided to call for help. I'm really glad you reached out to us, Angela. You are very brave for speaking up about what's been happening. We are here to support you and we will do everything we can to help keep you safe. Can you tell me more about this man and what he's been saying to you? He keeps asking me to send him pictures and videos of myself, and he says if I don't do what he wants, he will tell my parents and my friends about our conversations. That must be really frightening for you, Angela. I want you to know that none of this is your fault and you are not alone. We will work together to make sure this man can't harm you anymore. Can you tell me if you have any other concerns or questions about what to do next?

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Justina speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Kito. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Kigoma Vijijini in Kigoma. Nice to meet you, Kito. What's on your mind today? I'm really upset because I feel like there's a lot of gender bias in my school. The teachers always seem to favor the boys over the girls, even when the girls are just as good or even better. I'm sorry to hear that, Kito. It's important that everyone is treated fairly and equally. Can you give me some examples of the gender bias you've noticed? Well, for one thing, the boys always get chosen first for sports teams and leadership roles, even if the girls are more qualified. And when it comes to punishments, the girls always seem to get harsher punishments for the same things that the boys do. That does sound unfair, Kito. It's important to speak up about these issues so that they can be addressed. Have you tried talking to anyone at your school about this? I've tried talking to my teacher, but she just brushed me off and said that's the way things are. I don't think that's right. I agree, Kito. It's important to have a safe and supportive environment at school. Have you talked to your parents or any other adults about this? I haven't talked to my parents yet, but I wanted to call you first to see if there's anything that can be done about this gender bias at my school. I'm glad you called, Kito. We can definitely look into this further and see what steps can be taken to address the gender bias at your school. Your voice is important, and it's great that you're speaking up about this issue.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Grace speaking. How can I help you today? Hi Grace, my name is Justa and I'm 14 years old. I'm from Mpwapwa, Dodoma. Nice to meet you, Justa. How are you feeling today? I'm feeling really lonely and isolated. I just feel like no one in my family understands me. I'm sorry to hear that, Justa. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? Well, my parents are always busy with work, and my siblings are much older than me. I feel like I'm always alone at home. That must be really tough, Justa. Have you tried talking to your family about how you're feeling? I've tried, but they just brush it off. They don't seem to have time for me. I understand how that can make you feel even more lonely. Have you thought about reaching out to friends or teachers at your school? I don't really have any close friends at school, and I feel like my teachers are always busy with other students. It sounds like you're really struggling with feeling isolated. Just know that you're not alone, Justa. We're here to listen and support you. Thank you, Grace. It means a lot to know that someone is there for me. Of course, Justa. Remember, it's important to take care of yourself and reach out for help when you need it. You can always call us whenever you're feeling lonely or isolated. Thank you, Grace. I'll try to remember that.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Gloria speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Zubeda. I'm 14 years old and I'm calling from Pangani, Tanga. Hello Zubeda, nice to meet you. How are you feeling today? I'm not feeling very good, Gloria. I've been having a really tough time lately. I'm sorry to hear that, Zubeda. Can you tell me a bit more about what's been going on? I've been feeling really down and I've been having these thoughts...you know, about hurting myself. I'm really glad you reached out to us, Zubeda. It takes a lot of courage to talk about these things. Can you tell me more about what's been making you feel this way? I've been having a lot of pressure at school and at home. Sometimes it just feels like too much to handle. And cutting myself...it's like the only way I can cope with everything. I'm so sorry you're going through this, Zubeda. It must be really hard for you. But I want you to know that you're not alone, and there are people who care about you and want to help. I just don't know what to do anymore, Gloria. I feel so lost and hopeless. I understand, Zubeda. But there are ways to cope with these feelings that don't involve hurting yourself. Have you ever talked to anyone else about what you're going through? No, I haven't. I was too scared to tell anyone. It's okay to feel scared, Zubeda. But reaching out for help is a brave thing to do. Would you be willing to talk to a counselor or a trusted adult about what you're going through? I think I could try that, Gloria. Thank you for listening to me and for being there for me. Of course, Zubeda. Remember, you are not alone, and there is always help available for you. Don't hesitate to reach out to us or to someone you trust whenever you need support. Take care of yourself.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Busu speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Busu, my name is Alicia. I'm calling about a child named Anyabwile who is 11 years old from Rorya in Mara. I wanted to inquire about the services provided by the helpline. Thank you for reaching out, Alicia. We offer a range of services to support children in Tanzania. This includes counseling, referrals to appropriate agencies, and information on child rights and protection. That's great to hear. Can you provide more details on how the counseling services work? Of course, Alicia. Our counseling services are available for children who may be facing various challenges such as abuse, neglect, or emotional distress. Trained counselors are here to listen, provide support, and help children navigate their situations. That's really important. How can children access these services? Children can reach out to us through our helpline number at 06954 728927. They can call or send a message, and our counselors will be available to assist them. That's good to know. Are there any other services or resources available through the helpline? Yes, Alicia. In addition to counseling, we can also provide referrals to other organizations or agencies that can offer further support to children in need. We are here to ensure the well-being and protection of all children in Tanzania. Thank you, Busu. I will pass this information along to Anyabwile and his family. I appreciate your help. You're welcome, Alicia. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you or Anyabwile need any further assistance. Take care.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Rabia speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Rabia, my name is Kajakafwile. I am 29 years old and calling from Namtumbo in Ruvuma. I am worried about a child in my community named Gaudencia. What seems to be the issue with Gaudencia, Kajakafwile? Well, Gaudencia is only 7 years old, but she is being forced to work in the fields to help her family survive. She should be in school, but instead, she is spending long hours laboring in the sun. That is concerning to hear. Child labor is a serious issue that we need to address. Have you spoken to Gaudencia's family about this? Yes, I have tried to talk to them, but they are struggling to make ends meet. They believe that Gaudencia's work is necessary for their economic survival. I understand the difficult situation they are facing, but it is important for children to be protected from such labor. We can provide support and guidance to help Gaudencia and her family find alternative solutions. Have you considered reaching out to local authorities or organizations for assistance? I have not thought about that. Do you have any recommendations on where I can go for help? Yes, there are organizations in Ruvuma that can provide assistance with issues like child labor. You can also visit the District Hospital, where they may have resources and information on how to support children in need. Thank you for bringing this to our attention, Kajakafwile. We will do our best to help Gaudencia and her family.

Hello, good afternoon. My name is Angela, and I'm calling about my niece, Isabela. She's 14 years old and she's from Micheweni, Kaskazini Pemba. Hi Angela, I'm Mwanandeke from the child helpline. How can I assist you today regarding Isabela? Isabela has been having some problems at home with her parents. They argue a lot, and she often feels like she's caught in the middle. Yesterday, after a particularly heated argument, she ran away from home. I'm sorry to hear that Isabela is going through such a difficult time. It's important that we work together to ensure her safety and well-being. Have you contacted the local authorities to report her as missing? Yes, I've already spoken to the police, but they haven't been able to locate her yet. I'm really worried about her, especially with the current situation in our area. I understand your concern, Angela. It's crucial that we act quickly to find Isabela and ensure that she is safe. Can you provide me with more information about her, such as her physical appearance and any places she might go to seek refuge? Isabela is about 5 feet tall, with long brown hair and brown eyes. She's a quiet girl who enjoys spending time at the beach near our home. I'm worried that she might be there or at a friend's house. Thank you for sharing that information, Angela. I will do everything in my power to assist in locating Isabela and ensuring her safety. Please stay in touch with me so we can work together to bring her back home.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Auni, I'm 15 years old, and I'm calling from Babati Vijijini in Manyara. Hello Auni, I'm Buyu from the child helpline. How can I assist you? I've been having some problems at school. I'm being bullied by some of my classmates. I'm sorry to hear that, Auni. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? They call me names, spread rumors about me, and exclude me from activities. It's been going on for a while now, and it's really starting to affect me. It sounds like you're going through a tough time. Have you tried talking to anyone at school about this? I've tried talking to my teachers, but they don't seem to take it seriously. They just tell me to ignore it. It's important to remember that bullying is not okay, and you deserve to feel safe and respected at school. Have you talked to your parents about what's been happening? No, I haven't. I don't want to worry them or cause any trouble. It's important to reach out to someone you trust for support, Auni. Your parents care about you and want to help. Would you be willing to talk to them about what's been going on? I guess I could give it a try. I just feel so alone and helpless right now. You're not alone, Auni. We're here to support you, and your parents will want to help you through this. Remember, you deserve to feel safe and respected. Don't hesitate to reach out for help when you need it.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Zubeda speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Aoko. I'm 39 years old and I'm calling about a child in Wete, Kaskazini Pemba. His name is Ambidwile, and he's only 7 years old. I'm really concerned about his well-being. What seems to be the issue with Ambidwile, Aoko? Well, I've noticed that Ambidwile is being made to work in hazardous conditions. He's being forced to work long hours in a factory with dangerous machinery, and he's not even provided with proper safety equipment. It's really worrying me. That does sound like a serious issue, Aoko. Child labor in hazardous conditions is illegal and extremely dangerous for the child's well-being. Thank you for bringing this to our attention. We will do everything we can to ensure Ambidwile's safety and well-being. I'm glad to hear that. I just want to make sure that Ambidwile is protected and kept safe from harm. No child should have to endure such dangerous working conditions. Absolutely, Aoko. We will take immediate action to investigate the situation and ensure that Ambidwile is removed from the hazardous work environment. Thank you for your concern for his well-being. Thank you for your help, Zubeda. I appreciate all that you and the child helpline are doing to protect children like Ambidwile. It means a lot to me. You're welcome, Aoko. It's our duty to protect children from harm. Please don't hesitate to contact us if you have any more concerns or need further assistance in the future.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Fausta speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Mwakanjuki. I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Dodoma, Dodoma. Nice to meet you, Mwakanjuki. What seems to be the problem today? I have a friend who keeps running away from home. He says it's because he doesn't like his parents' rules. That sounds like a difficult situation. It's important to remember that running away is not a safe solution to problems at home. Have you tried talking to your friend about this? Yes, I have. But he just gets mad and says he doesn't care. It's good that you tried to talk to him. It's important to let him know that running away can put him in danger. Have you thought about talking to a trusted adult about this? I haven't, but I will. I just want to help my friend before something bad happens to him. That's very brave of you, Mwakanjuki. It's important to seek help from adults who can intervene and help your friend. Do you know of any adults you can trust to talk to about this situation? Yes, I think I can talk to my teacher at school. She's always been very supportive. That's a great idea. Your teacher can help you figure out the best way to support your friend and keep him safe. Remember, it's important to always prioritize your friend's safety above all else. Thank you, Fausta. I feel better knowing that I can do something to help my friend. You're welcome, Mwakanjuki. Remember, you can always call us if you need more support or advice. Take care.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Frida speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Afua, I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Buhigwe, Kigoma. I really need someone to talk to about my parents. I'm here to listen, Afua. What's been going on with your parents? Well, they've been fighting a lot lately, and I think they're going to get a divorce. I don't know what to do. I'm sorry to hear that, Afua. It must be really tough for you. Have you tried talking to them about how you feel? I have, but they just keep arguing and don't listen to me. I feel like they're only thinking about themselves. It's important for parents to consider how their actions are affecting their children. Have you talked to anyone else about this, like a teacher or a trusted adult? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I found this helpline. I just want things to go back to how they used to be. I understand, Afua. It's completely normal to feel overwhelmed in this situation. Just know that you're not alone, and we're here to support you. Would you like some advice on how to cope with your parents' divorce? Yes, please. I really need some guidance on how to handle all of this. I can provide you with some resources and tips on how to navigate through this difficult time. Remember, it's okay to feel upset and confused, but it's important to take care of yourself too.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Juma speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Imelda, I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Tabora Mjini in Tabora. Nice to meet you, Imelda. What seems to be the problem? Well, there was a big storm in our area last night, and our house got flooded. My parents are trying to fix things, but I'm really scared. I'm sorry to hear that, Imelda. It must have been a frightening experience for you. Are you and your family safe now? Yes, we are safe, but we lost a lot of our belongings. And the water is still everywhere in the house. I understand how overwhelming that must be for you. Have you been able to contact any emergency services for help? No, we haven't. I didn't know who to call. That's why I decided to call the child helpline. You did the right thing, Imelda. I will make sure to notify the local authorities about your situation. In the meantime, try to stay calm and stay away from any electrical outlets or standing water. Okay, thank you, Juma. I will do that. I just want everything to go back to normal. I know it's a difficult time for you, but help is on the way. Just hang in there, Imelda. Thank you for your help, Juma. I feel a little better now that I've talked to you. I'm glad I could be here for you, Imelda. Remember, you can always call the child helpline if you need someone to talk to. Take care. Goodbye, Juma. Thank you again. Goodbye, Imelda. Stay safe.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Jacqueline speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Jacqueline, my name is Jane and I'm 16 years old. I'm calling from Moshi Vijijini in Kilimanjaro. Nice to meet you, Jane. How can I help you today? I'm really struggling with school right now. I've been skipping classes because my family is struggling financially and I need to work to help support them. I'm sorry to hear that, Jane. It must be difficult to balance work and school. Have you talked to anyone at school about your situation? No, I'm too embarrassed to tell anyone at school. I don't want them to think less of me. It's important to remember that your education is valuable, Jane. Skipping school could have long-term consequences. Have you thought about reaching out for support? I didn't know who to talk to until I found this helpline number. I just feel like I have no other choice but to work to help my family survive. I understand your situation, Jane. It's commendable that you want to help your family, but your education is also important. Have you considered speaking to a counselor or a teacher about your struggles? I haven't, but I will try to find someone to talk to at school. Thank you for listening and giving me some advice, Jacqueline. You're welcome, Jane. Remember, there are resources available to support you through this difficult time. If you ever feel overwhelmed, don't hesitate to reach out to us or visit the police station for assistance. Thank you, Jacqueline. I will keep that in mind.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Ali speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Eveline, I'm 10 years old, and I'm from Monduli, Arusha. Hello Eveline, it's nice to meet you. What's on your mind today? I've been feeling really lonely lately. My family is always busy with work and I don't have any siblings to play with. I'm sorry to hear that, Eveline. It's important to talk about our feelings. Have you tried talking to your family about how you feel? Yes, but they always say they're too busy to spend time with me. I feel like they don't understand. It sounds like you're feeling isolated and disconnected from your family. It's okay to feel that way, Eveline. You're not alone in feeling lonely sometimes. But what can I do about it? I don't want to feel this way anymore. One thing you can try is finding activities that make you happy and keep you busy. Do you have any hobbies or interests that you enjoy? I like drawing and playing with my dolls, but it's not the same as having someone to talk to. That's understandable, Eveline. It's important to find ways to connect with others and build relationships outside of your family. Have you thought about making friends at school or in your community? I've tried, but it's hard for me to open up to new people. I feel like I don't fit in. It's normal to feel that way, Eveline. Just remember that it takes time to build relationships and find people who truly understand you. You can also reach out to a trusted adult or counselor for support. Thank you, Ali. I feel a little better now that I've talked to you. I'm glad I could help, Eveline. Remember, you can always call the Child Helpline whenever you need someone to talk to. Take care of yourself, okay? Okay, thank you. Goodbye, Ali.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Ambokile from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Francis. I am 10 years old and I live in Iringa Vijijini, Iringa. Nice to meet you, Francis. What seems to be the issue you're facing today? I am having a problem with my parents. They always argue and fight about how to raise me and my siblings. I'm sorry to hear that, Francis. It must be really tough for you to see your parents fighting. Can you tell me more about the arguments they're having? Well, my dad is really strict and he always wants us to follow strict rules. But my mom is more relaxed and she lets us have more freedom. They can never agree on how to discipline us. It sounds like your parents have different parenting styles. That must be confusing for you and your siblings. Have you tried talking to them about how their arguments make you feel? I've tried, but they always end up arguing even more. I just wish they could find a way to get along and not fight all the time. I understand, Francis. It's important for parents to work together and find common ground when it comes to raising their children. If you ever feel overwhelmed or need someone to talk to, you can always call us at 07774 633687. We are here to help you. Thank you, Ambokile. I really appreciate your help. You're welcome, Francis. Remember, you can always call us whenever you need to talk. And if you ever need immediate help, you can go to the District Hospital as a landmark. Take care.

Hello, good afternoon. I am calling because I am worried about my daughter, Hala. She is only 11 years old and we are facing some challenges. Hello, this is Fanana from the child helpline. I'm here to help. Can you tell me more about what's going on with Hala? Yes, my name is Mama and we are from Rombo, Kilimanjaro. Hala has been caught in the middle of our parental conflicts. My husband and I have been arguing a lot lately, and it's affecting her. I'm sorry to hear that, Mama. It's important to consider how this might be impacting Hala. How is she reacting to the arguments between you and your husband? She has been very quiet lately and seems withdrawn. I'm worried that she is feeling overwhelmed by the tension at home. She shouldn't have to deal with all of this at such a young age. It's understandable that you're concerned about Hala's well-being. It's important to create a safe and supportive environment for her, especially during difficult times like this. Have you tried talking to Hala about how she's feeling? I have tried, but she doesn't open up easily. I want to make sure she knows that she can always come to me or someone for help. That's a good approach, Mama. It's important for Hala to feel supported and heard during this challenging time. If you need further assistance or resources, please don't hesitate to reach out to the child helpline or other local organizations for support. We are here to help you and Hala through this difficult situation. Thank you, Fanana. I appreciate your support and guidance. I will continue to prioritize Hala's well-being and seek help when needed.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Asha speaking. How can I assist you today? Hey, my name is Justin. I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Ilala, Dar es Salaam. Hello Justin, nice to meet you. How can I help you today? I have a friend who ran away from home yesterday because of some problems with his parents. I'm really worried about him. I'm sorry to hear that, Justin. It must be difficult for both you and your friend. Have you tried contacting him or his family? Yeah, I tried calling him but his phone is off. I also went to his house but no one was there. It's important to stay calm in situations like this, Justin. Have you spoken to any adults, like your parents or a teacher, about your friend's situation? I haven't told anyone yet. I was hoping to find him first and talk to him about going back home. It's understandable that you want to help your friend, but it's also important to involve adults who can help in these situations. Have you considered contacting the authorities or a helpline for runaway children? I didn't think about that. Do you think I should call the police or a helpline for help? Yes, Justin, it would be best to contact the authorities or a helpline for assistance. They have the resources and experience to help find your friend and ensure his safety. Okay, I'll do that. Thank you for your advice, Asha. I hope we can find my friend soon. You're welcome, Justin. Remember, it's important to seek help from adults in situations like this. Stay safe and take care.

Hello, how can I help you today? Hi, I'm Mzee. I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Unguja Kaskazini A, Kaskazini Unguja. Hi Mzee, I'm Cecil from the child helpline. What seems to be the issue today? I'm really worried about my younger siblings. Our parents passed away recently, and I've been taking care of them, but it's getting really hard. I'm sorry to hear that, Mzee. It must be tough for you to take on that responsibility at such a young age. Are you getting any support from other family members or adults in your community? Not really. Our aunt was supposed to help us, but she's been neglecting us. She doesn't provide enough food or support, and she's always angry with us. I see. It sounds like you and your siblings are in a difficult situation. Have you tried talking to anyone else about what's going on at home? I haven't. I didn't know where to turn for help until I found this helpline number at my school. I'm glad you reached out to us, Mzee. We can help connect you with organizations that provide support for orphaned and abandoned children like you and your siblings. It's important that you get the help you need to ensure your well-being and safety. Thank you, Cecil. I really appreciate your help. I just want to make sure my siblings and I have a safe and stable home. You're welcome, Mzee. We will do our best to assist you and your siblings. Let's work together to find a solution to your situation.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Ambata. How can I help you today? Hey, my name is Yusuf. I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Kinondoni, Dar es Salaam. Hi Yusuf, how are you feeling today? I'm not doing so great, Ambata. I've been feeling really scared and stressed lately. I'm sorry to hear that, Yusuf. Can you tell me what's been bothering you? Well, there's been a lot of violence in my community recently. There have been fights breaking out almost every day, and I feel like I'm constantly on edge. That sounds really tough, Yusuf. It's completely normal to feel scared and stressed in a situation like that. Have you been directly involved in any of these conflicts? No, thankfully I haven't been directly involved, but I've witnessed some pretty scary things happening. It's understandable that witnessing violence can be very traumatic. Have you talked to anyone about what you've seen? Not really, I haven't felt comfortable talking to my family about it. I feel like they have enough to worry about already. Yusuf, it's important to remember that your feelings are valid and it's okay to seek help. You don't have to go through this alone. Have you thought about reaching out to any local support services for assistance? I haven't really thought about that, but I'm glad I called the helpline today. It feels good to talk about what's been weighing on my mind. I'm glad you reached out, Yusuf. Remember, you can always call us whenever you need to talk. Your safety and well-being are important to us.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Furaha speaking. How can I assist you today? Hey, my name is Vincent, I'm 17 years old, and I'm calling from Unguja Kaskazini B, Kaskazini Unguja. I'm having some issues at home with my parents. There's a lot of conflict and pressure coming from external sources that's really getting to me. I'm sorry to hear that, Vincent. It must be really difficult for you. Can you tell me more about what's been going on at home? Yeah, so my parents have been arguing a lot lately, and I feel like I'm caught in the middle of it. They both have their own expectations and pressures they're placing on me, and it's starting to affect my mental health. I just don't know how to handle it anymore. It sounds like a really tough situation to be in. Have you tried talking to your parents about how you're feeling? I've tried, but they just don't seem to listen. They're so caught up in their own issues that they don't see how it's affecting me. I feel like I have no one to turn to. I understand how frustrating that must be for you, Vincent. It's important to remember that it's not your fault and that you deserve to have a safe and supportive environment at home. Have you thought about reaching out to any other trusted adults for help? I haven't really thought about that. I guess I've been too caught up in everything going on at home. But it's good to know that there are people out there who can help. Absolutely, Vincent. You're not alone in this. We're here to support you and help you through this difficult time. Would you like me to provide you with some resources or options for seeking help outside of your home? Yes, please. That would be really helpful. Thank you, Furaha.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Abasi, how can I help you today? Hi there, Abasi. My name is Rabia, I'm 14 years old and I'm calling from Handeni, Tanga. Nice to meet you, Rabia. How can I assist you today? Well, Abasi, I've been having some physical health concerns lately. I was playing football with my friends and I fell and injured my ankle. It's been hurting a lot and I'm worried it might be serious. I'm sorry to hear that, Rabia. It's important to take care of your health, especially when it comes to injuries. Have you seen a doctor or received any medical attention for your ankle? No, I haven't. I was hoping it would get better on its own, but it's been a few days and it's still really painful. I understand, Rabia. It's always best to get injuries checked out by a medical professional to ensure proper care and treatment. Have you talked to your parents or guardians about this? Yes, I told my mom, but she's been really busy with work and hasn't had time to take me to the doctor. I see. In situations like this, it's important to prioritize your health and seek medical attention. Is there a trusted adult or family member who can take you to see a doctor? I think my uncle might be able to take me. I'll talk to him about it. Thank you for your help, Abasi. You're welcome, Rabia. Remember, your health is important and it's okay to ask for help when you need it. Take care of yourself and don't hesitate to reach out if you need further assistance.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Jennifer speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Zena. I'm 13 years old and I'm calling from Kati Unguja, Kusini Unguja. I have some concerns about my growth and development. I'm sorry to hear that, Zena. Can you tell me more about what specifically you're worried about? Well, I feel like I'm not growing as fast as my friends. I see them getting taller and stronger, but I still feel so small. Is there something wrong with me? It's completely normal to have these concerns, Zena. Growth and development can vary from person to person. Have you been eating well and getting enough nutrients? I try to eat as much as I can, but sometimes we don't have enough food at home. My parents work hard, but it's tough to make ends meet. I understand, Zena. It's important to make sure you're getting the right nutrients to support your growth. Have you tried talking to your parents about your concerns? Yes, but they're always busy. I don't want to burden them even more. Is there anything I can do on my own to help with my growth? You can try to eat more fruits and vegetables, and make sure you're drinking plenty of water. If you can, visit the Central Market in town to get fresh produce. And remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it, Zena. Thank you, Jennifer. I feel better knowing that there are things I can do to help with my growth. I'll try to eat healthier and talk to my parents about it too. That's great to hear, Zena. Remember, we're here to help you whenever you need us. Take care and stay healthy.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Ester speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Ester, my name is Jackson and I'm calling about my daughter Martha. She's 14 years old and we live in Kibaha, Pwani. Nice to meet you, Jackson. How can I help you with Martha today? Well, Ester, I'm really worried about Martha. We've been having a lot of conflicts at home lately, especially with financial stress. I feel like it's really affecting her. I'm sorry to hear that, Jackson. It must be tough for both of you. Can you tell me more about the financial stress conflicts you're facing? Yeah, it's been really hard to make ends meet lately. I've been working extra hours just to provide for the family, but it's still not enough. Martha doesn't understand why I can't buy her the things she wants, and it's causing a lot of tension between us. I can imagine how difficult that must be for both of you, Jackson. Have you tried talking to Martha about the financial situation and how it's affecting the family? I've tried, but she just gets upset and says that I don't care about her. I don't know what to do anymore, Ester. I just want what's best for her. It's clear that you care about Martha a lot, Jackson. Have you thought about seeking help from a counselor or therapist to work through these issues together? I haven't considered that before, but maybe it could help. Thank you for listening, Ester. I appreciate your advice. You're welcome, Jackson. Remember, we're here to support you and Martha whenever you need us. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need further assistance.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Jema, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Francis and I'm 14 years old. I'm calling from Mwanga, Kilimanjaro. Nice to meet you, Francis. What seems to be the issue you're facing today? I've been having a lot of trouble with my schoolwork. I just can't seem to understand some of the subjects no matter how hard I try. I'm sorry to hear that, Francis. Learning difficulties can be really tough. Have you talked to your teachers or parents about this? I've tried talking to my teachers, but they're always too busy to give me the extra help I need. And my parents don't really understand how hard it is for me. It sounds like you're feeling frustrated with your situation. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this. Have you considered seeking help from a tutor or a counselor at school? I thought about it, but I'm too embarrassed to ask for help. I don't want my friends to know that I'm struggling. It's completely normal to feel that way, Francis. But it's important to prioritize your education and well-being. Maybe we can come up with a plan together to help you improve your academic skills without feeling ashamed. That would be really helpful, Jema. I just want to do better in school and make my parents proud. I'm glad you reached out to us, Francis. Let's work on finding a solution together. Have you ever heard of the tutoring center on Main Road in Mwanga? They offer free tutoring services for students like you. No, I haven't heard of it. That sounds like a great idea. Thank you so much, Jema. You're welcome, Francis. Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it. We're here for you whenever you need support.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Zuberi speaking, how can I help you today? Hey, I'm Bora, I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Mjini Unguja, Mjini Magharibi. I've been feeling really stressed out lately because of all the pressure to do well in school. I'm sorry to hear that, Bora. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? Well, my parents and teachers always expect me to get top grades in every subject. They don't understand that it's really hard for me to keep up with everything. I feel like I have to be perfect all the time, and it's overwhelming. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of academic pressure. It's important to remember that it's okay to make mistakes and that nobody is perfect. Have you tried talking to your parents or teachers about how you're feeling? I've tried, but they just tell me to work harder and stop making excuses. I feel like I have no one to turn to for help. You're not alone, Bora. It's okay to ask for help when you're feeling overwhelmed. Have you thought about talking to a school counselor or reaching out to a trusted adult for support? I haven't, but I'm glad I called the helpline. It feels good to talk to someone who understands what I'm going through. I'm here to listen and support you, Bora. Remember, it's important to take care of yourself and not put too much pressure on yourself. If you ever need to talk again, don't hesitate to call us at 07621 577263. Is there a landmark near you where you feel safe? Yes, I feel safe near the District Hospital. Thank you for your help, Zuberi. I feel better already.

Hello, um, hi there. Good afternoon, this is Theresia from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi Theresia, my name is Seghen, and I'm 14 years old. I'm calling from Mbinga in Ruvuma. Nice to meet you, Seghen. What seems to be the problem? Well, I'm facing some gender-based violence at school. I feel like there's a lot of bias against girls when it comes to opportunities and treatment. I'm sorry to hear that, Seghen. It's important to address these issues. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Yeah, so for example, in our class, the teachers always give more attention and praise to the boys. They get chosen for leadership roles and opportunities, while the girls are often overlooked. It's not fair. That does sound unfair, Seghen. No one should be treated differently because of their gender. Have you tried talking to anyone at school about this issue? I've tried speaking up, but I feel like no one really listens or takes it seriously. I feel like I'm alone in this. You're not alone, Seghen. We are here to support you and help you find a solution. Have you thought about talking to someone in authority at school, like the headteacher or a counselor? I haven't, but maybe I should. I just don't want to cause any trouble. It's important to speak up for what's right, Seghen. Your voice matters, and you deserve to be treated with respect and equality. I can help you come up with a plan on how to approach this issue at school. Thank you, Theresia. I feel better knowing that I have someone to talk to about this.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline, this is Mwashambwa speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Mwakanjuki, I am 28 years old and I am calling about a child named Akida from Kilolo, Iringa. I believe she might be in danger of human trafficking. Thank you for reaching out, Mwakanjuki. Can you provide me with more details about what makes you think Akida is at risk of human trafficking? Well, I have noticed some suspicious activities happening in our neighborhood. There have been strange people coming and going from Akida's house at odd hours. She has also been seen with older men who do not seem to be her relatives. I am really concerned for her safety. I appreciate you bringing this to our attention, Mwakanjuki. It does sound like a serious situation. Human trafficking, especially sex trafficking, is a grave violation of a child's rights. We must take immediate action to protect Akida. Have you noticed any changes in Akida's behavior or any signs that she might be in distress? Yes, Akida has become very withdrawn and secretive lately. She used to be a cheerful and outgoing child, but now she hardly speaks to anyone. I am worried that she might be in trouble and unable to ask for help. Thank you for sharing that information, Mwakanjuki. It is crucial for us to act quickly to ensure Akida's safety. I will alert the authorities and child protection services in Kilolo, Iringa to investigate this matter further. Your quick thinking and concern for Akida's well-being are commendable. We will do everything we can to protect her from harm. Thank you for calling the child helpline.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Rabia. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Tina, I'm 10 years old, and I'm calling from Kilwa, Lindi. Hi Tina, it's nice to meet you. How are you feeling today? I'm not feeling good, Rabia. I've been having a lot of bad thoughts and I don't know what to do. I'm sorry to hear that, Tina. Can you tell me more about what's been troubling you? Well, my parents are always fighting and yelling at each other. It's really scary and I don't know how to make them stop. I feel like it's all my fault. I'm so sorry you're going through that, Tina. It's not your fault that your parents are fighting. You're not alone in feeling this way. But it's just too much for me, Rabia. I've been thinking about hurting myself because I don't see a way out of this. I understand that you're feeling overwhelmed right now, Tina. It's important to remember that there are people who care about you and want to help. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling? No, I haven't told anyone. I didn't know who to turn to until I found this helpline number. I'm glad you reached out, Tina. It takes a lot of courage to talk about these difficult feelings. You are not alone and we can work through this together. Would you like to talk more about how you're feeling and explore some ways to cope with these thoughts? Yes, please, Rabia. I really need help. Thank you for listening to me.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Jeremy speaking, how can I help you today? Hey Jeremy, my name is Simba. Hello, is this the child helpline? I need to talk to someone. Yes, this is Ambata from the child helpline. How can I help you today? But what if my friends or family don't accept me if I feel a certain way? It's understandable to feel worried about how others might react, but your feelings are valid and important. It's okay to talk to someone you trust about how you're feeling, whether it's a family member, friend, or a counselor like me. I don't know who to talk to about this. I'm scared they won't understand. That's okay, Msafiri. You can always reach out to the child helpline whenever you need someone to talk to. We are here to support you and provide guidance on any questions or concerns you may have. Thank you, Ambata. I feel a bit better talking to you about this. It's nice to know there's someone I can turn to for help. I'm glad you reached out, Msafiri. Remember, you are not alone, and it's important to take care of yourself and your well-being. Don't hesitate to call us anytime you need support.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Janet speaking. How can I help you today? Hi Janet, my name is Aisha, I'm 10 years old, and I'm calling from Karatu, Arusha. Nice to meet you, Aisha. What seems to be the problem? I feel like my rights are being denied, Janet. I see other kids in my community getting to participate in activities and make decisions, but I'm always left out. I'm sorry to hear that, Aisha. Can you give me some examples of how your participation rights are being denied? Well, for one, whenever there's a community event or meeting, I'm never invited to join in. Even at school, when it comes to choosing class representatives or deciding on activities, I'm never given a chance to participate. That does sound unfair, Aisha. Every child has the right to participate in decisions that affect them. Have you tried talking to any adults about how you feel? Yes, I've tried talking to my teachers and even my parents, but they don't seem to take me seriously. They always say that kids should just listen to adults and not try to be involved in important matters. I understand how frustrating that must be, Aisha. But remember, you have the right to be heard and to have a say in things that concern you. Have you thought about starting a conversation with other children in your community who might feel the same way? I haven't thought about that, Janet. Maybe if we all speak up together, the adults will finally listen to us. That's a great idea, Aisha. Remember, you have the right to participate and be included in decisions that affect your life. Don't be afraid to speak up and advocate for your rights. And if you ever need support, don't hesitate to call us at the child helpline.

Hello, is this the child helpline? I really need someone to talk to. Yes, this is Stella from the child helpline. How can I help you today? My name is Kwasi, I'm 15 years old and I'm from Manyoni, Singida. I don't know where else to turn. I feel like I'm all alone and no one understands me. I'm here to listen, Kwasi. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? My parents are always busy with work and they never have time for me. They don't ask about my day or how I'm feeling. I wish my parents would pay attention to me and show me that they care. It's okay to feel that way, Kwasi. You are not alone in feeling neglected or unloved. We can work together to find ways to cope with these emotions and improve your situation. Thank you, Stella. I feel a little bit better just talking to you about it. It helps to know that someone is listening to me.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Yusuf speaking, how can I assist you today? Hello Yusuf, my name is Akida. I'm 42 years old and I'm calling about a child named Ambidwile who lives in Mkoani, Kusini Pemba. I'm really concerned about his well-being. I'm glad you reached out, Akida. Can you tell me more about what's going on with Ambidwile? Well, the issue is with his family. His parents are struggling with alcoholism, and it's really affecting Ambidwile. He's only 6 years old and he's witnessing things that no child should have to see. I'm sorry to hear that, Akida. It must be very difficult for Ambidwile to be in that situation. Ambidwile is often left alone and neglected because of their drinking. It's important that we address this issue as soon as possible to ensure Ambidwile's safety and well-being. Have you considered contacting local authorities or social services for assistance? I haven't thought about that, but I will definitely look into it. I just want to make sure that Ambidwile is taken care of and that his parents get the help they need to overcome their addiction. That's a great step, Akida. Remember, you're not alone in this. The child helpline is here to support you and provide guidance on how to handle this situation. Please keep us updated on any developments, and we'll do our best to help.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Miriam speaking. How can I help you today? Hi Miriam, my name is Idi. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Kati Unguja, Kusini Unguja. Nice to meet you, Idi. What seems to be the problem? Well, my friends have been talking about running away from home and going to the city to have fun. You did the right thing by reaching out to us, Idi. We can help you figure out a safe solution. Have you thought about talking to your parents or a teacher about what's going on? I haven't, but I will try to talk to my parents about it. I don't want to get into trouble or put myself in danger. That's a good decision, Idi. Remember, there are people who care about you and want to help you. If you ever feel scared or unsure about something, you can always call us for support. Thank you, Miriam. I feel better now that I've talked to you. I'll try to talk to my parents about this. I'm glad I could help, Idi. Remember, it's always okay to ask for help when you need it. Stay safe and take care of yourself.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Jefferson, how can I assist you today? Hi Jefferson, my name is Valentine. I'm calling about my niece Sarah, she's 15 years old and we live in Mtwara Mjini, Mtwara. I'm sorry to hear that, Valentine. What seems to be the issue with Sarah? Well, it's about her parents. They both have a drinking problem, and it's starting to affect Sarah's well-being. I see. Substance abuse in the family can have a significant impact on children. It's important to address this issue as soon as possible. Have you tried talking to Sarah's parents about their alcoholism and how it's affecting her? Yes, I have, but they don't seem to listen or care. I'm really worried about Sarah's safety and well-being. I understand your concern, Valentine. It's good that you reached out for help. We can provide support and guidance on how to best help Sarah in this difficult situation. Would you like some information on resources available for families dealing with substance abuse? Yes, that would be helpful. Thank you, Jefferson. I just want what's best for Sarah. Of course, Valentine. We're here to help. Please feel free to call us anytime you need assistance or support. You can also reach out to us at our helpline number: +255 6113 824670.

Hello, how may I assist you today? Hello, this is Fabiano. I'm calling about a child named Tumaini from Ileje, Mbeya. Hello Fabiano, I'm Hilda from the child helpline. How can I help you regarding Tumaini? Well, Tumaini is only 15 years old, and he's been working long hours in a quarry to help support his family. I see, so Tumaini is involved in child labor. We can provide support and guidance to help Tumaini and his family find alternative solutions. That would be greatly appreciated. Tumaini deserves a chance to have a better future without sacrificing his education and childhood. Thank you for reaching out, Fabiano. We will work together to ensure that Tumaini receives the support he needs. Let's start by creating a plan to address his situation and provide him with the necessary resources. Thank you, Hilda. I'm grateful for your help in advocating for Tumaini's rights and well-being.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Kelvin speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Kelvin, my name is Darweshi. I'm 10 years old and I'm from Mjini Unguja, Mjini Magharibi. I'm feeling really stressed and anxious lately. I'm sorry to hear that, Darweshi. Have you tried talking to your parents about how their fighting is affecting you? I'm too scared to talk to them about it. I don't want to make things worse.
