Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Ajali speaking, how can I help you today? Hey, my name is Selas, I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Handeni, Tanga. Nice to meet you, Selas. How can I assist you today? I need help, Ajali. I think my friend is being forced to work against his will. He told me that he was promised a good job in the city, but now he's stuck working long hours without pay. I'm sorry to hear that, Selas. It sounds like your friend may be a victim of labor trafficking. Can you tell me more about what you know? He told me that he was brought to the city by someone promising him a good job in a hotel. But when he arrived, they took away his passport and forced him to work in a factory instead. He's scared to leave because they threatened to harm his family back home. That's a very serious situation, Selas. Your friend is being exploited and it's important that we help him. Do you know where exactly he is located in the city? Yes, he's in a factory in the industrial area of the city. He's not allowed to leave the premises and he's constantly monitored by guards. Thank you for sharing that information, Selas. We will need to involve the authorities to rescue your friend and ensure his safety. Can you provide me with any additional details about the situation? I don't have much else to share, but I'm worried about him and I want to help in any way I can. You're doing the right thing by reaching out, Selas. We will take action to assist your friend and put an end to the exploitation he's facing. Thank you for your courage in speaking up about this issue.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Mwasongwe, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Restituta, I am 14 years old and I am calling from Songea Vijijini, Ruvuma. Hello Restituta, how can I help you today? I need help, I think I am being sexually abused by someone in my community. I am so sorry to hear that, Restituta. Can you tell me more about what is happening? There is a man in my village who keeps touching me inappropriately and making me feel uncomfortable. He tells me not to tell anyone or else something bad will happen. That sounds really frightening, Restituta. It's important that you speak up about this. Have you tried talking to anyone else about what is happening? No, I have been too scared to tell anyone. I didn't know who to turn to for help. You did the right thing by reaching out to us. We are here to support you and help you through this difficult situation. It's important that we report this to the authorities to ensure your safety. Thank you for listening and for believing me, Mwasongwe. I was so scared to talk about this. You are brave for speaking up, Restituta. We will do everything we can to protect you and put a stop to this abuse. Your safety is our top priority. Thank you, Mwasongwe. I feel a little better knowing that I have someone to talk to about this. You are not alone, Restituta. We are here for you every step of the way. Let's work together to ensure your safety and well-being.

Hello, how may I help you today? Hi there, I'm Hadithi, I'm 17 years old and I'm calling from Iringa Mjini. Hello Hadithi, my name is Mwalimu and I'm from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? I'm calling because I need some advice. I've been experiencing gender-based violence at school and I don't know what to do about it. I'm sorry to hear that, Hadithi. Have you thought about reaching out to other teachers or school counselors who might be able to support you? I haven't, but maybe that's a good idea. I just feel so frustrated and helpless in this situation. It's completely understandable to feel that way, Hadithi. Remember, you have the right to be treated with respect and fairness. If you ever feel unsafe or need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to call us back or seek help from a trusted adult. You are not alone in this. Thank you, Mwalimu. I appreciate your advice and support.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Kamili speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Joyce. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Moshi Mjini in Kilimanjaro. Hello, Joyce. How can I assist you today? I'm having some trouble with getting enough food and proper clothing. My family is struggling, and we don't always have enough to eat or clothes to wear. Yes, I have, but they are also struggling to make ends meet. I don't want to burden them even more. I understand, Joyce. It's important to take care of yourself too. Have you thought about reaching out to any local organizations or charities that might be able to help? I haven't thought about that. Do you know of any organizations that could assist us with food and clothing? Yes, there are organizations in your area that provide support for families in need. I can help you find the contact information for them so you can reach out for assistance. Would that be helpful for you? Yes, that would be great. Thank you so much, Kamili. You're welcome, Joyce. I'm here to help. Just remember, it's important to take care of yourself and reach out for support when you need it. Don't hesitate to call us again if you have any more concerns or questions.

Hello, um, hi there. Good afternoon, this is Masomakali from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? Hi Masomakali, my name is Esther and I'm 13 years old. I live in Temeke, Dar es Salaam. Nice to meet you, Esther. How can I help you today? I need help. I think... I think I might be in trouble. What kind of trouble, Esther? You can tell me, I'm here to listen and help. I think... I think I'm being forced to do things I don't want to do. Can you tell me more about what's happening, Esther? It's important for me to understand so I can help you. My cousin promised me a job in the city, but when I got here, it was different. They make me do things... things I don't want to do. Esther, it sounds like you might be a victim of human trafficking, specifically sex trafficking. I want you to know that it's not your fault and there are people who can help you. I'm scared, Masomakali. I don't know what to do. It's okay to be scared, Esther. But you did the right thing by reaching out for help. We will do everything we can to ensure your safety and well-being. Can you tell me more about where you are right now? I'm at a house in the city. I don't know the address, but it's near a big market. Thank you, Esther. I will contact the authorities and they will come to rescue you. Stay strong, help is on the way. Thank you, Masomakali. Thank you for listening to me. You're welcome, Esther. Remember, you are not alone in this. Stay safe and stay strong.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Theresia. How can I assist you today? Hi, Theresia. I'm too scared to tell anyone in my community because I'm afraid of what they might think. But it's getting worse, and I don't know how to protect my siblings from him. You did the right thing by calling us, Andwele. It's important to speak up about the abuse you're facing. Have you thought about contacting the authorities or seeking help from a trusted adult? I haven't, but I'm willing to try. I just want my siblings and I to be safe. Do you think you can help me find a way to get out of this situation? Of course, Andwele. We can connect you with local organizations and resources that can assist you in dealing with this abuse. Remember, you're not alone in this. We're here to support you every step of the way. Thank you, Theresia. I feel a bit better knowing that I have someone to talk to about this. I'll do whatever it takes to protect my family.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Mariamu speaking, how can I assist you today? Hey Mariamu, my name is Johnson. I understand how frustrating that must be. You have the right to a quality education, and it's important that your school provides you with the support you need. Have you thought about reaching out to the District Hospital for assistance? I haven't, but I will definitely consider it. Thank you for your suggestion, Mariamu. You're welcome, Johnson. Remember, your education is important, and you have the right to receive the support you need to succeed. Don't hesitate to reach out to us if you need any further assistance.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline, this is Victoria speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Florian, I'm 15 years old and I'm from Mafia in Pwani. I don't know, I just feel so overwhelmed all the time. I have trouble sleeping, I don't feel like eating, and I can't concentrate on anything. It sounds like you might be going through a tough time. It's important to talk about these feelings so we can figure out how to help you feel better. Have you talked to anyone else about how you've been feeling? No, I haven't told anyone. I didn't know who to talk to. It's brave of you to reach out to us, Florian. You're not alone in feeling this way, and there are people who can help you. Have you thought about talking to a counselor or a therapist about what you're going through? I haven't, but maybe that's a good idea. I just want to feel better. I'm here to support you, Florian. It's important to take care of yourself and your mental health. Would you like me to help you find resources in your area that can support you through this? Yes, please. Thank you for listening to me, Victoria. I really appreciate it. Of course, Florian. I'm here to help you every step of the way. Let's work together to find the support you need to start feeling better.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Nasra, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Masomakali and I am 10 years old. I'm calling from Rombo, Kilimanjaro. Nice to meet you, Masomakali. What's on your mind today? I've been feeling really lonely and isolated lately. My family doesn't seem to talk to me much or spend time with me. I've tried, but they always seem too busy or not interested in listening to me. That sounds really difficult. I don't really have many friends at school, and my teachers are always busy with other students. I understand. It's important to have someone to talk to when you're feeling lonely. Have you thought about joining any clubs or activities where you can meet new people? I haven't really thought about that. Maybe I could try joining a sports team or a club at school. That's a great idea, Masomakali. It's important to find activities that you enjoy and where you can make new friends. Remember, you can always call the helpline if you need someone to talk to. Is there anything else on your mind? Thank you, Nasra. I feel a little better now. I'll try joining a club at school and see how it goes. I'm glad I could help, Masomakali. Remember, you're not alone. Take care and feel free to call us anytime you need support.

Hi, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Rozina from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi Rozina, I'm Monica, I'm 13 years old, and I'm from Mufindi, Iringa. Nice to meet you, Monica. How are you feeling today? I'm feeling really lonely and isolated. I live in a rural area and there are not many kids my age around here. I'm sorry to hear that, Monica. I try to keep busy with school and chores, but it's not the same as having friends to hang out with. I can imagine how difficult that must be for you. You're not alone in feeling this way. It's important to take care of yourself and reach out for help when you need it. Remember, you can always call the helpline whenever you need someone to talk to. Take care of yourself and know that you're not alone in this.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Roza, I'm 10 years old, and I live in Kigoma Mjini. Hello Roza, my name is Shabani and I'm here to listen and help you. What's on your mind today? I'm really worried about my family. My dad drinks a lot of alcohol and it's causing a lot of problems at home. I'm sorry to hear that, Roza. It's not your responsibility to fix your dad's drinking problem, Roza. It's important to remember that you can always reach out for help and support. Have you talked to anyone else about this? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to talk to until I found this helpline number. I'm glad you reached out to us, Roza. You're very brave for speaking up about this. Is there anyone else in your family or community that you trust and feel comfortable talking to? I have an aunt who lives nearby. She's always been very supportive and understanding. Maybe I can talk to her about it. That sounds like a good idea, Roza. It's important to have someone you trust to talk to about your feelings. Remember, you can always call us back if you need more support or advice. You're not alone in this. Thank you, Shabani. I feel a little better now that I've talked to you.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Dionisia, I'm 25 years old, and I'm calling about a child named Albina from Kilolo, Iringa. Hello Dionisia, I'm Lea from the child helpline. How can I help you with Albina today? Well, Albina is only 15 years old, and she has been going through a lot of stress and anxiety lately. Her family is facing instability, and it's really taking a toll on her. I'm sorry to hear that. Can you tell me more about what's been happening in Albina's family? Her parents have been fighting a lot, and they are on the verge of getting a divorce. Albina is caught in the middle of it all, and she feels like she has to choose sides. It's causing her a lot of anxiety and stress. That sounds really tough for Albina. It's important for her to know that she doesn't have to choose sides and that she can talk to someone about how she's feeling. Have you noticed any changes in her behavior or mood? Yes, she has been withdrawing from her friends and school activities. She's also been having trouble sleeping and eating properly. I'm really worried about her. It's good that you reached out for help. Albina needs support during this difficult time. I've tried talking to him, but he's so young and I don't think he fully understands what's going on. It's important for Mohamed to feel supported and understood during this challenging time. If you need any additional assistance or resources, please don't hesitate to reach out to us. We're here to help you and Mohamed through this difficult situation. Thank you, Ashura. I appreciate your support and guidance. I'll definitely consider reaching out to others for help.

Hello, is this the child helpline? I really need someone to talk to. Yes, this is Barke from the child helpline. How can I help you today? My name is Shangazi, I'm 11 years old, and I live in Magharibi Unguja, Mjini Magharibi. I'm calling because I don't know what to do anymore. My caregiver has been hitting me a lot lately and I don't know why. I'm really sorry to hear that, Shangazi. It's not okay for anyone to hurt you. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, my caregiver has been really stressed out lately because of work and money problems. I think that's why she takes it out on me. She yells at me for little things and sometimes she hits me too. I try to be good, but it's never enough. That sounds really tough, Shangazi. It's not your fault that your caregiver is feeling overwhelmed. You deserve to be treated with love and respect. Have you talked to anyone else about what's been happening? No, I haven't. I'm scared that if I tell someone, things will get worse. But I can't keep living like this. I don't know what to do. It's brave of you to reach out for help, Shangazi. You deserve to feel safe and protected. We can help you find a safe solution to this situation. Would you be comfortable with us contacting someone who can help you? Yes, please. I want things to get better. Thank you for listening to me, Barke. You're welcome, Shangazi. We will do everything we can to support you. Let's work together to make sure you are safe and cared for.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Jaali speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Jaali, my name is Anthonia. I'm 27 years old and I'm calling about a child named Winnie who is 17 years old. She lives in Babati Vijijini, Manyara. Thank you for reaching out, Anthonia. Can you tell me more about what's going on with Winnie? Well, Winnie has been dealing with a lot of parental conflicts at home. Her parents are constantly arguing and fighting, and it's really taking a toll on her mental health. She's been feeling stressed and anxious because of their constant bickering. I'm sorry to hear that Winnie is going through such a difficult time. It's important for her to feel safe and supported at home. Have you talked to Winnie about how she's feeling? Yes, I have. She's opened up to me about how overwhelmed she feels with all the tension in her household. She's been struggling to focus on her schoolwork and her overall well-being is being affected. It's great that Winnie has someone like you to confide in. It's important for her to know that she's not alone and that there are people who care about her well-being. Have you tried talking to her parents about the impact their conflicts are having on Winnie? I have, but unfortunately, her parents don't seem to realize how their behavior is affecting Winnie. They're under a lot of external pressure and it's causing them to take out their frustrations on each other and on Winnie. I understand. It's a challenging situation, but it's important for Winnie to feel safe and supported. Let's work together to support Winnie.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Msafiri speaking, how can I assist you today? Hello, my name is Noah, I am 47 years old, and I am calling about a child named Latifa. She is 15 years old and she lives in Mbarali, Mbeya. I am concerned about her well-being. Thank you for reaching out, Noah. Can you please share with me what specific issue or concern you have regarding Latifa? I believe Latifa's rights are being violated. She is being forced to work long hours on a farm by her relatives, and she is not able to attend school regularly. I am worried about her safety and education. I appreciate you bringing this to our attention, Noah. It is indeed concerning to hear about Latifa's situation. Every child has the right to be protected from exploitation and to receive an education. We will do everything we can to help Latifa. Can you provide me with any additional information about her situation? Latifa's relatives have been taking advantage of her vulnerability since her parents passed away. They do not provide her with proper care or support, and she is often left to fend for herself. I fear for her safety and well-being. Thank you for sharing these details, Noah. It is important that we take action to protect Latifa's rights and ensure that she receives the support she needs. I will escalate this case to the appropriate authorities and organizations to intervene and provide assistance to Latifa. Please rest assured that we are here to help and support both you and Latifa through this process. Thank you for your prompt response, Msafiri. I appreciate your assistance in this matter. I hope Latifa can receive the help she deserves.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Janeth speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Bahari. I'm 10 years old, and I'm calling from Mafia in Pwani. Hello Bahari, it's nice to meet you. How can I assist you today? I, um, I don't really know how to say this, but I think I've been... I've been touched inappropriately by someone in my community. I'm so sorry to hear that, Bahari. It takes a lot of courage to talk about something like this. Can you tell me more about what happened? Well, there's this man who lives near my house, and he always wants me to come over to play games with him. But then, when we're alone, he... he touches me in places he shouldn't. That sounds really scary, Bahari. It's important for you to know that what this man is doing is not okay. You have the right to feel safe and protected. I don't know what to do. I'm scared to tell my parents because I don't want to get in trouble. You're not in trouble, Bahari. It's not your fault that this is happening to you. You deserve to be safe and protected. Have you thought about talking to a trusted adult about what's been happening? I haven't. But I'm glad I called you. It feels good to talk about it. I'm glad you reached out, Bahari. You can always call us at the Child Helpline whenever you need to talk or get help. And remember, you can reach out to the police or social welfare department for further assistance. Your safety is important. If you ever feel in danger, call this number for immediate help: +255 6983 168397. Thank you, Janeth. I feel better already knowing that I have someone to talk to. You're welcome, Bahari. Remember, you're not alone in this. We're here to support you.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Florian. I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Arumeru Mashariki, Arusha. Hello Florian, I'm Azize from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? I'm calling because I'm having some issues at home. There has been a lot of fighting and violence between my parents lately. I'm sorry to hear that, Florian. It must be really difficult for you to witness such conflicts at home. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, it started a few months ago with small arguments, but now it has escalated to physical violence. I'm scared for my safety and the safety of my younger siblings. I understand how frightening that must be for you. It's important to prioritize your safety and well-being. Have you tried talking to your parents about how their behavior is affecting you and your siblings? I have tried to talk to them, but it only seems to make things worse. I don't know what else to do. It's brave of you to try to communicate with your parents, Florian. It's not your responsibility to fix their problems, but it's important for you to seek help and support. Have you thought about reaching out to other family members, friends, or authorities for assistance? I haven't told anyone else about what's been happening at home. I was too scared and ashamed, but I couldn't keep it to myself anymore. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, Florian. It takes courage to ask for help, and I'm glad you reached out to us. We can connect you with resources and support to help you navigate this difficult situation. Your safety and well-being are our top priority.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Etana from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Amali. I'm 17 years old and I'm calling from Kinondoni, Dar es Salaam. Nice to meet you, Amali. What seems to be the problem? I've been feeling a lot of pressure from my friends to try drugs and alcohol. I know it's risky behavior, but it's hard to say no sometimes. Peer pressure can be tough to deal with, especially when it involves risky behavior like substance experimentation. Have you already experimented with drugs or alcohol? Yeah, I tried smoking weed with my friends last weekend, and I didn't really enjoy it. But now they're pressuring me to try something stronger, and I'm not sure how to handle it. It's important to remember that you always have a choice, Amali. It's okay to say no to things that make you uncomfortable or put you at risk. Have you talked to your friends about how you feel? Not really, I'm afraid they'll make fun of me or stop hanging out with me. It's understandable to feel that way, but true friends will respect your boundaries and decisions. It might be helpful to have an honest conversation with them about how you feel. You can also reach out to supportive adults or counselors for guidance. Thank you, Etana. I'll try talking to my friends and seeking help if I need it. I appreciate your advice. You're welcome, Amali. Remember, you deserve to feel safe and respected in your friendships. If you ever need to talk more, feel free to call the helpline again. Take care of yourself. I will. Thank you. Goodbye. Goodbye, Amali. Take care.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Elina speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Idili, I am 13 years old and I'm calling from Iringa Mjini. Nice to meet you, Idili. How can I assist you today? I have been feeling really down lately and I have been having thoughts of hurting myself. I'm sorry to hear that, Idili. It's important that you reach out for help when you are feeling this way. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? I don't know, I just feel so hopeless and lost. I feel like nobody cares about me. I'm here to listen to you, Idili. Your feelings are valid and I want to help you through this. Have you ever hurt yourself before? Yes, I have. I've been cutting myself when I feel overwhelmed. I'm glad you reached out to us, Idili. It takes a lot of courage to talk about these things. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I found this helpline number. I'm glad you called, Idili. It's important that you get the support you need. I think it would be best for you to seek help from a professional. Is there a trusted adult you can talk to about this, like a teacher or a family member? I think I can talk to my teacher about it. I just don't want my parents to know. That's okay, Idili. Your teacher can help you get the support you need. Is there a landmark near you, like the District Hospital, where you can go to seek help in case of an emergency? Yes, I know where the District Hospital is. Thank you for your help, Elina. I feel a little better talking to you. I'm here for you, Idili. Remember, you are not alone in this. It's important to take care of yourself and seek help when you need it. Don't hesitate to call us back if you need to talk again. Take care.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Mwipopo. I'm 14 years old and I'm calling from Kinondoni, Dar es Salaam. Hello Mwipopo, I'm Edina from the child helpline. How are you feeling today? I'm feeling a bit confused and stressed out. What's been going on, Mwipopo? Well, I've been feeling a lot of pressure from my friends to start dating. They keep teasing me about not having a girlfriend and it's been really bothering me. I'm sorry to hear that, Mwipopo. It's important to remember that you don't have to rush into anything just because your friends are pressuring you. It's okay to take your time and focus on yourself. I know, but it's hard when everyone around me is in relationships and I feel left out. It's completely understandable to feel that way, Mwipopo. Just remember that it's important to prioritize your own feelings and well-being above what others expect from you. I just don't know how to handle all this pressure. It's starting to affect my schoolwork and my mood. Have you tried talking to your friends about how you're feeling? I haven't really talked to them about it. I'm afraid they'll just make fun of me even more. It's important to have open and honest conversations with your friends about how their actions are affecting you. If they truly care about you, they will listen and understand. I'll try to talk to them and see how it goes. Thank you for listening and giving me advice, Edina. You're welcome, Mwipopo. Remember, you can always call us if you need someone to talk to. Take care of yourself.

Hello, good afternoon. I'm calling about my son, Vincent, who is 9 years old and we live in Kisarawe, Pwani. Hello, this is Natori from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? Well, my son has been having some trouble at school. He's been feeling left out and excluded by his classmates. I'm sorry to hear that, Calvin. Bullying and social exclusion can be very difficult for children to deal with. How long has this been going on? It started a few weeks ago. Vincent told me that some of the other kids in his class have been making fun of him and not including him in their games during break time. It's important to address this issue as soon as possible. Has Vincent talked to his teacher or school counselor about what's been happening? Yes, he did. The teacher spoke to the students involved, but the situation hasn't improved much. Vincent still feels lonely and left out. I understand how concerning this must be for you as a parent. Have you talked to Vincent about how he's feeling and what he would like to see happen? Yes, we've had some conversations about it. He just wants to be able to play with his classmates and feel included like everyone else. It's great that you're supporting him through this. We can work together to come up with some strategies to help Vincent feel more accepted at school. Would you like some advice on how to approach this situation? Yes, please. I want to do everything I can to help my son feel happy and included at school. Let's start by discussing some ways to address this issue with the school and come up with a plan to support Vincent. Let's work together to make sure he feels safe and valued at school.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Ashura. I'm 12 years old and I live in Kinondoni, Dar es Salaam. Hello Ashura, I'm Leah from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? I have some questions about puberty and development. I feel like things are changing in my body and I'm not sure what to do. It's completely normal to have questions about puberty and development at your age, Ashura. What specific concerns do you have? Well, I've noticed some changes in my body like my voice getting deeper and hair growing in new places. I'm not sure if this is normal or if something is wrong. Those changes are all part of puberty, Ashura. It's your body growing and developing as you become older. It's completely normal and nothing to be worried about. But I feel so confused and sometimes embarrassed about these changes. I don't know who to talk to or where to get information from. It's okay to feel confused and embarrassed, Ashura. It's a natural part of growing up. It's great that you reached out to us for support. You can always talk to a trusted adult like a parent, teacher, or healthcare provider about your concerns. Thank you, Leah. I feel better knowing that these changes are normal. I will try to talk to someone I trust about this too. That's great to hear, Ashura. Remember, we are always here to support you whenever you need it. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any more questions or concerns in the future. Thank you, Leah. I really appreciate your help and guidance. You're welcome, Ashura. Take care and remember that you're not alone in this journey of growing up.

Hello, is this the child helpline? I'm feeling really lonely and I don't know who to talk to about it. Yes, this is Busu from the child helpline. I'm here to listen. Can you tell me your name, age, and where you're calling from? My name is Jeremy, I'm 11 years old, and I'm calling from Mpanda, Rukwa. I just started at the Secondary School this year, and I feel like I don't fit in with the other kids. I'm sorry to hear that, Jeremy. It can be tough starting at a new school and feeling like you don't belong. Have you tried talking to any of your classmates about how you're feeling? I've tried, but they all seem to already have their own friends and groups. I just feel like I'm on the outside looking in. It's completely normal to feel that way, Jeremy. It takes time to adjust to a new environment and make new friends. Have you thought about joining any clubs or activities at school to meet new people? I've thought about it, but I'm not sure where to start. I'm not very good at sports, and I don't know what else to try. There are plenty of other clubs and activities at school that don't involve sports. You could try joining the art club or the music club. It's a great way to meet new friends who share the same interests as you. That's a good idea, Busu. I think I'll give it a try. Thank you for listening to me and giving me some advice. It really means a lot to me. I'm glad I could help, Jeremy. Remember, it's okay to feel lonely sometimes, but there are always people who care about you and want to help. Don't hesitate to reach out if you ever need to talk again.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Aziza, how can I help you today? Hi Aziza, my name is Mwakipesile. I'm 13 years old and I live in Unguja Kaskazini A, Kaskazini Unguja. Nice to meet you, Mwakipesile. What seems to be troubling you today? I'm really scared because my parents recently separated, and now my father has been coming to our house and yelling at my mother. He even hit her once. I'm so sorry to hear that, Mwakipesile. It sounds like a very difficult situation. Your safety is the most important thing right now. Have you talked to anyone else about what's been happening at home? No, I haven't. I don't know who to turn to for help. You did the right thing by calling us, Mwakipesile. It's important to speak up about any form of violence, especially when it's happening at home. Have you thought about talking to a teacher or a trusted adult at your school about what's going on? Yes, I have a teacher at my primary school who I trust. I will try to talk to them about it. That's a good idea, Mwakipesile. Your teacher can help you find the support you need. Remember, you're not alone in this. We're here to support you every step of the way. Is there anything else you would like to talk about or any other concerns you have? No, that's all for now. Thank you for listening, Aziza. You're welcome, Mwakipesile. Take care and remember that you deserve to feel safe and loved. Don't hesitate to reach out to us again if you need to talk.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Lina, I'm 12 years old, and I'm calling from Karagwe, Kagera. Hello Lina, I'm Saidi from the child helpline. How can I assist you? I don't know who else to talk to, but my village was hit by a terrible flood last week. Our houses were destroyed, and many people were injured. I'm scared and don't know what to do. I'm so sorry to hear that, Lina. It must be a very difficult time for you and your community. Have you and your family been able to find a safe place to stay? Yes, we are staying at a temporary shelter, but it's crowded and uncomfortable. I miss my home. I understand, Lina. It's normal to feel scared and sad after experiencing such a traumatic event. Have you been able to talk to anyone about how you're feeling? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I found this helpline number. I'm glad you reached out, Lina. It's important to talk about your feelings and fears. It's also essential to take care of yourself during this challenging time. Remember to eat well, get enough rest, and try to find moments of joy, even in difficult circumstances. Thank you, Saidi. I will try to do that. Do you think our village will ever be the same again? Rebuilding after a natural disaster takes time and effort, Lina. But with the support of your community and organizations that provide aid, things will get better. It's essential to stay strong and hopeful for the future. I will try to do that, Saidi. Thank you for listening and for your advice. You're welcome, Lina. Remember, you can always reach out to us whenever you need someone to talk to. Stay strong, and take care.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Haji, how can I assist you today? Hi Haji, my name is Sakina, I'm 17 years old and I'm calling from Handeni Mjini, Tanga. Nice to meet you, Sakina. How can I help you today? I'm facing a problem with my educational rights being denied. My parents are not allowing me to go to school anymore. I'm sorry to hear that, Sakina. Education is a fundamental right for every child. Have you tried talking to your parents about this issue? Yes, but they refuse to listen to me. They believe that girls should not go to school and should stay at home instead. That's not right, Sakina. Every child, regardless of gender, has the right to education. Have you spoken to any teachers or school authorities about this? I haven't, I'm scared of what my parents might do if they find out. I don't know what to do. Don't worry, Sakina. You've taken the first step by reaching out to us. We can help you navigate this situation and ensure your right to education is protected. Can you provide me with your phone number so we can follow up with you? Sure, my phone number is +255 7936 578146. Thank you for listening, Haji. Of course, Sakina. We are here to support you. I will connect you with the appropriate resources to address this issue. Please remember, education is your right, and no one should deny you that. You can also visit our office near the Police Station in Tanga for further assistance. Thank you, Haji. I feel better knowing that there is someone who can help me.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Busu, I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Namtumbo, Ruvuma. Hello Busu, I'm Hala from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? I have some questions about puberty and development. I'm not sure what's happening to my body. It's completely normal to have questions about puberty, Busu. Can you tell me a little more about what you're experiencing? Well, I've noticed that my body is changing, and I'm not sure why. I have also started to have some strange feelings that I don't understand. It sounds like you are going through puberty, Busu. During this time, your body goes through a lot of changes as you grow into an adult. It's important to talk about these changes and ask questions. I'm a bit scared to talk about it with anyone. I don't know who to ask. You can always talk to someone you trust, like a parent, guardian, or teacher. You can also reach out to us here at the child helpline. We are here to support you and answer any questions you may have. Thank you, Hala. I feel a bit better knowing that I can talk to someone about this. I will try to talk to my parents about it too. That's great, Busu. Remember, it's important to take care of your body and understand these changes. If you ever feel uncomfortable or have more questions, you can always call us or visit our office near the Police Station in your area. We are here to help you. Thank you, Hala. I will keep that in mind.

Hello, thank you for calling the Child Helpline, this is Sheila speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi Sheila, my name is Angy. I'm calling about my daughter Imani, she's 14 years old and we live in Mtwara Mjini, Mtwara. I'm really worried about her. What seems to be the problem, Angy? Well, Imani has been having a lot of conflicts with her father lately. He's been putting a lot of pressure on her to do well in school and follow his strict rules. It's causing a lot of stress for her and they keep arguing all the time. I'm sorry to hear that, Angy. It sounds like a difficult situation for Imani. Have you tried talking to her father about how this is affecting her? Yes, I have, but he doesn't seem to listen. He thinks he's doing what's best for her, but I can see how much it's hurting her. I just don't know what to do anymore. It's important for Imani to feel supported and understood during this time. Have you considered seeking help from a mediator or counselor to help facilitate communication between Imani and her father? I haven't thought about that, but it might be a good idea. Do you have any recommendations for counselors in our area? There is a counseling center near the Police Station in Mtwara Mjini that may be able to help. They specialize in family therapy and could provide support for Imani and her father to work through their conflicts. Thank you, Sheila. I will look into that. I just want what's best for my daughter and I appreciate your help. You're welcome, Angy. Remember, you're not alone in this. We're here to support you and Imani through this challenging time.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Rach. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Reth. I'm 12 years old, and I'm calling from Kati Unguja, Kusini Unguja. Nice to meet you, Reth. What's on your mind? I'm really scared and upset. My caregiver has been hitting me a lot lately. I'm so sorry to hear that, Reth. No one deserves to be hurt. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? My caregiver gets really frustrated with me easily. Sometimes it's because I forget to do my chores, or sometimes it's just because they're in a bad mood. But no matter what, they always end up hitting me. That sounds really tough, Reth. It's important to remember that it's not your fault. Have you tried talking to anyone else about this? I haven't told anyone else. I'm too scared that they won't believe me, or that things will get even worse if my caregiver finds out. It's brave of you to reach out for help, Reth. You deserve to feel safe and respected. We can work together to figure out a plan to keep you safe. Have you thought about any safe adults or friends you could talk to about this? I have a teacher at school who is really nice. I think I could trust them. That's a great idea, Reth. Your teacher can help you find the support you need. And remember, you can always call us here at the child helpline whenever you need to talk. You're not alone in this. Thank you, Rach. I feel a little bit better knowing that I have someone to talk to about this.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Salome speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Salome, my name is Hellen. I'm calling about my son Mwangosi, he's 9 years old and we live in Unguja Kaskazini B, Kaskazini Unguja. Hello Hellen, nice to meet you. What seems to be the issue with Mwangosi? Well, lately I've noticed that Mwangosi has been acting a bit strange. He seems to be very secretive and spends a lot of time on his phone. I'm worried that he might be involved in some romantic or relationship issues at such a young age. I see, it's understandable that you're concerned about his behavior. Have you tried talking to Mwangosi about what's going on? Yes, I've tried talking to him but he just shuts down and refuses to open up to me. I don't want to invade his privacy, but I also want to make sure he's not getting into any trouble. It's important to establish a healthy communication with Mwangosi so he feels comfortable sharing his thoughts and feelings with you. Maybe you can try approaching the topic in a non-confrontational way and assure him that you're there to support him. That's a good idea, I will try to have a calm and open conversation with him. Thank you for your advice, Salome. I just want to make sure Mwangosi is safe and happy. You're welcome, Hellen. Remember that the child helpline is here for you if you need any further assistance or support. Take care and good luck with your conversation with Mwangosi.

Hey there, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Hadithi. I'm 10 years old and I live in Nyamagana, Mwanza. Hello Hadithi, I'm Kwasi from the child helpline. What's on your mind today? I have some questions about sexual identity. I've been feeling confused lately. It's great that you reached out, Hadithi. It's normal to have questions about your sexual identity at your age. Can you tell me more about what you're feeling? Well, I've been feeling like I might like boys more than girls. Is that okay? Of course, Hadithi. It's completely normal to have those feelings. It's important to remember that there is no right or wrong way to feel about your sexual identity. It's all about what feels right for you. But what if my family and friends don't understand? It can be tough if your family and friends don't understand, but it's important to remember that you are valid and deserving of love and respect no matter what. Have you thought about talking to someone you trust about how you're feeling? I haven't really talked to anyone about it before. But I feel a bit better now that I've talked to you, Kwasi. I'm glad to hear that, Hadithi. Remember, you can always reach out to us here at the child helpline whenever you need to talk. Is there anything else you'd like to discuss today? No, that's all for now. Thank you for listening, Kwasi. You're welcome, Hadithi. Take care of yourself, and don't hesitate to call us again if you need to talk. Oh, and if you ever visit the Central Market in Mwanza, make sure to check out the delicious street food there. Stay safe and take care, Hadithi.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Naomi speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Ngonepe. I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Bahi, Dodoma. Nice to meet you, Ngonepe. How are you doing today? I'm okay, but I'm a bit worried. There was a big storm last night, and it caused a lot of damage in my village. I'm sorry to hear that, Ngonepe. Is everyone in your village safe? Yes, thankfully no one was hurt, but many houses were destroyed, and some people lost their belongings. That sounds really tough. Have you and your family been affected by the storm? Our house got flooded, and now we have to stay with our neighbors because it's not safe to be in our home. I'm glad you're staying safe with your neighbors, Ngonepe. Have you been able to get any help or support? Not yet. The roads are blocked, and it's hard for emergency services to reach us. I'm worried about what will happen if we don't get help soon. I understand your concern, Ngonepe. Do you have any relatives or friends you can reach out to for assistance? Not really. Most of our family lives far away, and our neighbors are also struggling with their own damaged homes. I see. In situations like this, it's important to stay calm and seek help from local authorities or organizations that provide assistance during natural disasters. Thank you, Naomi. I will try to find help for my family and neighbors. I appreciate your advice and support. You're welcome, Ngonepe. Remember, you can always call the child helpline for more guidance or assistance. Hello, you've reached the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Hala speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Hala, my name is Eunice. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Simanjiro, Manyara. Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Suzana speaking, how can I help you today? Have you considered speaking to a school counselor or seeking extra support outside of school? I haven't thought about that before. Do you think it would be helpful for me to seek additional support? Hello, Child Helpline, this is Cyrus speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Ndweleifwa. I am 11 years old and I live in Unguja Kaskazini B, Kaskazini Unguja. Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Yahya, I'm 16 years old, and I'm calling from Mkalama, Singida. Hello Yahya, I'm Fahamu from the child helpline. Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Clement, I'm 10 years old and I'm from Kigoma Ujiji, Kigoma. Hello Clement, I'm Amidah from the child helpline. Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Elia from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? My name is Kelvin, I'm a 15-year-old boy from Mjini Unguja, Mjini Magharibi. Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Jordan speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Jordan, my name is Emma, I'm 14 years old and I'm calling from Hanang in Manyara. Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Pili, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Zakia, I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Wete, Kaskazini Pemba. Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Tumaini, I'm 11 years old, and I'm calling from Kibaha, Pwani. Hi Tumaini, I'm Filbert from the child helpline. Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Saida, I am 14 years old and I am from Kigoma Vijijini in Kigoma. Nice to meet you, Saida. I'm Aida from the child helpline. Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Blandina speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Jauhar. I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Hanang, Manyara. Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Azize, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Adin. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Mkinga, Tanga. Nice to meet you, Adin. They were saying that the girls are promised jobs in the city, but then they end up being forced into doing bad things. They said some of the girls are as young as me. I'm so sorry to hear that, Adin. It's not right for anyone, especially children, to be put in those situations. We will do everything we can to help. Can you tell me if you know who is involved in this trafficking? I didn't hear any names, but I can try to find out more information and let you know. That would be very helpful, Adin. Thank you for being brave and reaching out to us. Your safety and well-being are our top priority. We will make sure to follow up on this information and take the necessary steps to protect those who are at risk.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Tumaini. How can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Aisha. I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Mbulu, Manyara. Hello Aisha, how can I help you? I think I need help. I've been working as a domestic worker for a family in my village, but they make me work long hours and don't pay me properly. I'm sorry to hear that, Aisha. It sounds like you may be experiencing child labor and exploitation. Can you tell me more about your situation? That sounds very difficult, Aisha. No child should have to go through that. Do you have anyone you can talk to about this? No, I don't have anyone to talk to. I saw a poster about the child helpline at the bus stand and decided to call for help. I'm glad you reached out to us, Aisha. We take child labor and exploitation very seriously. We will do everything we can to help you. Can you tell me more about the family you work for? They are a wealthy family in my village. They promised my parents that they would take care of me and send me to school, but they haven't kept their word. Thank you for sharing that with me, Aisha. We will investigate this situation and ensure that you are safe and protected. It's important that you know you are not alone in this. We are here to support you. Thank you, Tumaini. I feel relieved knowing that someone is listening to me. You're welcome, Aisha. We will do everything we can to help you. Stay strong, and we will be in touch with you soon. Take care.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Mwanangwa, I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Nyasa, Ruvuma. Hello Mwanangwa, I'm Seghen from the child helpline. Is there a trusted adult you can talk to about what's been happening at home? I think I can talk to my teacher about it. She's always been kind to me and I feel like she could help. That sounds like a good idea, Mwanangwa. Your teacher can provide support and help you find resources to deal with the situation. Remember, you deserve to feel safe and happy. If things get too difficult, you can always call us back. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about today? No, thank you, Seghen. I feel better now that I've talked to someone about this. Thank you for listening. You're welcome, Mwanangwa. Remember, help is always available. Take care of yourself and don't hesitate to reach out if you need anything. Goodbye. Goodbye, Seghen. Thank you.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Janeth, I'm 12 years old, and I live in Bukoba Vijijini, Kagera. Hello Janeth, my name is Faustina and I'm here to help you. What seems to be the problem? My older brother has been hitting me a lot lately. He gets angry for no reason and starts hitting me really hard. I'm sorry to hear that, Janeth. I'm scared to tell anyone else. I don't want to get my brother in trouble, but I also don't want to keep getting hurt. It's brave of you to reach out for help, Janeth. You deserve to feel safe in your own home. We can help you find ways to stay safe and get the support you need. Would you like to talk more about it? Yes, please. I don't know what to do, and I'm tired of feeling scared all the time. You're not alone, Janeth. We're here to support you and help you through this. Let's talk about some ways to keep you safe and find a solution to stop the abuse.

Hello, how can I help you today? Hi there, I'm Mwakalinga. I'm 13 years old, and I'm calling from Rorya, Mara. Hello Mwakalinga, this is Zaina from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? I haven't, but I heard about the child helpline at the Community Center. That's why I decided to call. I'm glad you reached out, Mwakalinga. It's important that you feel safe and supported. We can help you navigate this challenging situation and connect you with the right resources. Thank you, Zaina. I just want things to get better at home and for my mom to feel safe again. Hello, is this the child helpline? My name is Omar, I'm 33 years old and calling from Lindi Mjini, Lindi. Yes, this is Fernando from the child helpline. How can I assist you today, Omar?
