You did the right thing by reaching out to us, Idi. We can help you figure out a safe solution. Have you thought about talking to your parents or a teacher about what's going on? I haven't, but I will try to talk to my parents about it. I don't want to get into trouble or put myself in danger. That's a good decision, Idi. Remember, there are people who care about you and want to help you. If you ever feel scared or unsure about something, you can always call us for support. Thank you, Miriam. I feel better now that I've talked to you. I'll try to talk to my parents about this. I'm glad I could help, Idi. Remember, it's always okay to ask for help when you need it. Stay safe and take care of yourself.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Jefferson, how can I assist you today? Hi Jefferson, my name is Valentine. I'm calling about my niece Sarah, she's 15 years old and we live in Mtwara Mjini, Mtwara. I'm sorry to hear that, Valentine. What seems to be the issue with Sarah? Well, it's about her parents. They both have a drinking problem, and it's starting to affect Sarah's well-being. I see. Substance abuse in the family can have a significant impact on children. Yes, I have, but they don't seem to listen or care. I'm really worried about Sarah's safety and well-being. I understand your concern, Valentine. It's good that you reached out for help. We can provide support and guidance on how to best help Sarah in this difficult situation. Would you like some information on resources available for families dealing with substance abuse? Yes, that would be helpful. Thank you, Jefferson. I just want what's best for Sarah. Of course, Valentine. We're here to help. Please feel free to call us anytime you need assistance or support. You can also reach out to us at our helpline number: +255 6113 824670.

Hello, how may I assist you today? Hello, this is Fabiano. I'm calling about a child named Tumaini from Ileje, Mbeya. Hello Fabiano, I'm Hilda from the child helpline. How can I help you regarding Tumaini? Well, Tumaini is only 15 years old, and he's been working long hours in a quarry to help support his family. I see, so Tumaini is involved in child labor. That's a serious issue. Can you tell me more about his situation? Yes, his parents are struggling to make ends meet, so Tumaini feels the need to contribute by working in the quarry. He's missing out on his education and childhood. It's heartbreaking to hear about children being forced to work for economic survival. Have you tried talking to his parents about the importance of Tumaini's education? Yes, I have, but they are in a difficult financial situation and see Tumaini's income as necessary for the family. They don't understand the long-term impact on his well-being. I understand the challenges they are facing, but it's crucial for Tumaini to have access to education and a childhood. We can provide support and guidance to help Tumaini and his family find alternative solutions. That would be greatly appreciated. Tumaini deserves a chance to have a better future without sacrificing his education and childhood. Thank you for reaching out, Fabiano. We will work together to ensure that Tumaini receives the support he needs. Let's start by creating a plan to address his situation and provide him with the necessary resources. Thank you, Hilda. I'm grateful for your help in advocating for Tumaini's rights and well-being.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Kelvin speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Kelvin, my name is Darweshi. I'm 10 years old and I'm from Mjini Unguja, Mjini Magharibi. I'm feeling really stressed and anxious lately. I'm sorry to hear that, Darweshi. My parents are always fighting and it makes me really scared and worried. I don't know what to do. That sounds really tough, Darweshi. That's why I decided to call the helpline. I'm glad you reached out, Darweshi. It's important to talk about your feelings, especially when you're going through a difficult time. Have you tried talking to your parents about how their fighting is affecting you? I'm too scared to talk to them about it. I don't want to make things worse. But it's really starting to affect me at school and I can't concentrate on my studies. I understand, Darweshi. It's important to take care of yourself and your mental health. Have you thought about talking to a teacher or a school counselor about what's going on at home? I haven't, but maybe that's a good idea. Thank you for listening, Kelvin. I feel a little better already just talking about it. I'm here to listen, Darweshi. Remember, you're not alone in this. It's important to reach out for help when you need it. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about or any other questions you have? No, I think I'm okay for now. Thank you, Kelvin. I really appreciate your help. You're welcome, Darweshi. Take care of yourself and don't hesitate to call us again if you need to talk. Have a good day.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Ajali speaking, how can I help you today? Hey, my name is Selas, I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Handeni, Tanga. Nice to meet you, Selas. How can I assist you today? I need help, Ajali. I think my friend is being forced to work against his will. He told me that he was promised a good job in the city, but now he's stuck working long hours without pay. I'm sorry to hear that, Selas. It sounds like your friend may be a victim of labor trafficking. Can you tell me more about what you know? He told me that he was brought to the city by someone promising him a good job in a hotel. But when he arrived, they took away his passport and forced him to work in a factory instead. He's scared to leave because they threatened to harm his family back home. That's a very serious situation, Selas. Your friend is being exploited and it's important that we help him. Do you know where exactly he is located in the city? Yes, he's in a factory in the industrial area of the city. He's not allowed to leave the premises and he's constantly monitored by guards. Thank you for sharing that information, Selas. We will need to involve the authorities to rescue your friend and ensure his safety. Can you provide me with any additional details about the situation? I don't have much else to share, but I'm worried about him and I want to help in any way I can. You're doing the right thing by reaching out, Selas. We will take action to assist your friend and put an end to the exploitation he's facing. Thank you for your courage in speaking up about this issue.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Mwasongwe, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Restituta, I am 14 years old and I am calling from Songea Vijijini, Ruvuma. Hello Restituta, how can I help you today? I need help, I think I am being sexually abused by someone in my community. I am so sorry to hear that, Restituta. Can you tell me more about what is happening? There is a man in my village who keeps touching me inappropriately and making me feel uncomfortable. He tells me not to tell anyone or else something bad will happen. That sounds really frightening, Restituta. It's important that you speak up about this. Have you tried talking to anyone else about what is happening? No, I have been too scared to tell anyone. I didn't know who to turn to for help. You did the right thing by reaching out to us. We are here to support you and help you through this difficult situation. It's important that we report this to the authorities to ensure your safety. Thank you for listening and for believing me, Mwasongwe. I was so scared to talk about this. You are brave for speaking up, Restituta. We will do everything we can to protect you and put a stop to this abuse. Your safety is our top priority. Thank you, Mwasongwe. I feel a little better knowing that I have someone to talk to about this. You are not alone, Restituta. We are here for you every step of the way. Let's work together to ensure your safety and well-being.

Hello, how may I help you today? Hi there, I'm Hadithi, I'm 17 years old and I'm calling from Iringa Mjini. Hello Hadithi, my name is Mwalimu and I'm from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? I'm calling because I need some advice. I've been experiencing gender-based violence at school and I don't know what to do about it. I'm sorry to hear that, Hadithi. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, it's mainly coming from one of my teachers. He always seems to favor the boys in the class over the girls. He makes sexist remarks and gives the boys better opportunities than us girls. That sounds like a serious issue, Hadithi. It's important to remember that no one should be treated unfairly because of their gender. Have you tried talking to anyone about this at school? I haven't, I'm afraid of what might happen if I speak up. I don't want to get in trouble or have things get worse. I understand your concerns, Hadithi. It's important to prioritize your safety. Have you thought about reaching out to other teachers or school counselors who might be able to support you? I haven't, but maybe that's a good idea. I just feel so frustrated and helpless in this situation. It's completely understandable to feel that way, Hadithi. Remember, you have the right to be treated with respect and fairness. If you ever feel unsafe or need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to call us back or seek help from a trusted adult. You are not alone in this. Thank you, Mwalimu. I appreciate your advice and support.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Kamili speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Joyce. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Moshi Mjini in Kilimanjaro. Hello, Joyce. How can I assist you today? I'm having some trouble with getting enough food and proper clothing. My family is struggling, and we don't always have enough to eat or clothes to wear. I'm sorry to hear that, Joyce. It must be difficult for you and your family. Have you tried talking to anyone about this issue before? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to for help. It's good that you reached out to us. It's important to make sure you have enough food to stay healthy and clothes to keep you warm and clean. Have you talked to your parents about your concerns? Yes, I have, but they are also struggling to make ends meet. I don't want to burden them even more. I understand, Joyce. It's important to take care of yourself too. Have you thought about reaching out to any local organizations or charities that might be able to help? I haven't thought about that. Do you know of any organizations that could assist us with food and clothing? Yes, there are organizations in your area that provide support for families in need. I can help you find the contact information for them so you can reach out for assistance. Would that be helpful for you? Yes, that would be great. Thank you so much, Kamili. You're welcome, Joyce. I'm here to help. Just remember, it's important to take care of yourself and reach out for support when you need it. Don't hesitate to call us again if you have any more concerns or questions.

Hello, um, hi there. Good afternoon, this is Masomakali from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? Hi Masomakali, my name is Esther and I'm 13 years old. I live in Temeke, Dar es Salaam. Nice to meet you, Esther. How can I help you today? I need help. I think... I think I might be in trouble. What kind of trouble, Esther? You can tell me, I'm here to listen and help. I think... I think I'm being forced to do things I don't want to do. Can you tell me more about what's happening, Esther? It's important for me to understand so I can help you. My cousin promised me a job in the city, but when I got here, it was different. They make me do things... things I don't want to do. Esther, it sounds like you might be a victim of human trafficking, specifically sex trafficking. I want you to know that it's not your fault and there are people who can help you. I'm scared, Masomakali. I don't know what to do. It's okay to be scared, Esther. But you did the right thing by reaching out for help. We will do everything we can to ensure your safety and well-being. Can you tell me more about where you are right now? I'm at a house in the city. I don't know the address, but it's near a big market. Thank you, Esther. I will contact the authorities and they will come to rescue you. Stay strong, help is on the way. Thank you, Masomakali. Thank you for listening to me. You're welcome, Esther. Remember, you are not alone in this. Stay safe and stay strong.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Theresia. How can I assist you today? Hi, Theresia. My name is Andwele, I'm 17 years old, and I'm calling from Kati Unguja, Kusini Unguja. Nice to meet you, Andwele. How can I help you today? I'm in a really tough situation. My father has been drinking a lot lately and whenever he's drunk, he becomes violent towards me and my siblings. He hits us and yells at us for no reason. I don't know what to do. I'm sorry to hear that, Andwele. It's not right for anyone to hurt you, especially a parent. Have you tried talking to anyone about this before? I haven't. I'm too scared to tell anyone in my community because I'm afraid of what they might think. But it's getting worse, and I don't know how to protect my siblings from him. You did the right thing by calling us, Andwele. It's important to speak up about the abuse you're facing. Have you thought about contacting the authorities or seeking help from a trusted adult? I haven't, but I'm willing to try. I just want my siblings and I to be safe. Do you think you can help me find a way to get out of this situation? Of course, Andwele. We can connect you with local organizations and resources that can assist you in dealing with this abuse. Remember, you're not alone in this. We're here to support you every step of the way. Thank you, Theresia. I feel a bit better knowing that I have someone to talk to about this. I'll do whatever it takes to protect my family.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Mariamu speaking, how can I assist you today? Hey Mariamu, my name is Johnson. I'm 17 years old and I live in Unguja Kaskazini A, Kaskazini Unguja. Nice to meet you, Johnson. How can I help you today? I'm having a problem with my school. They are denying me my right to education. I'm sorry to hear that. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, the teachers at my school have been discriminating against me because of my disability. They refuse to provide me with the necessary support and accommodations to help me succeed in my studies. That sounds like a serious violation of your rights, Johnson. Every child has the right to education, regardless of any disabilities they may have. Have you tried talking to anyone at the school about this issue? Yes, I've tried speaking to the teachers and the principal, but they just ignore me. I feel like my voice isn't being heard. I understand how frustrating that must be. You have the right to a quality education, and it's important that your school provides you with the support you need. Have you thought about reaching out to the District Hospital for assistance? I haven't, but I will definitely consider it. Thank you for your suggestion, Mariamu. You're welcome, Johnson. Remember, your education is important, and you have the right to receive the support you need to succeed. Don't hesitate to reach out to us if you need any further assistance.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline, this is Victoria speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Florian, I'm 15 years old and I'm from Mafia in Pwani. Have you seen your friend around the Central Market area? Yes, she usually hangs out there with the older kids. I'm really worried about her. Thank you for reaching out, Rozalia. Hello, is this the child helpline? I really need someone to talk to. Yes, this is Regina from the child helpline. How can I help you today? My name is Faustina, I'm 12 years old, and I'm from Ikungi, Singida. I don't know what to do, my parents abandoned me. I'm so sorry to hear that, Faustina. It must be really hard for you. Can you tell me more about what happened? My parents passed away a few months ago, and ever since then, my relatives have been ignoring me. I have no one to take care of me or support me. That sounds like a very difficult situation, Faustina. You must be feeling very lonely and scared. Do you have anyone you can talk to about how you're feeling? No, I don't have anyone. That's why I called the helpline. I just don't know what to do anymore. It's really brave of you to reach out for help, Faustina. I want you to know that you're not alone. There are people who care about you and want to help you through this tough time. But what can I do? I have no one to turn to for help. I feel so lost and abandoned. I understand how overwhelming this must feel, Faustina. But there are organizations and services that can provide support for orphaned and abandoned children like you. We can help connect you with the right resources to ensure you have the care and assistance you need. Thank you, Regina. I really appreciate your help. I just want to feel safe and cared for again. You deserve to feel safe and cared for, Faustina. We will do everything we can to make sure you get the help you need. You are not alone in this, we are here for you every step of the way.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Mwashiuya speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Hadithi, I am 14 years old, and I am calling from Magharibi Unguja, Mjini Magharibi. Nice to meet you, Hadithi. How can I assist you today? I am calling because I am facing a problem with child labor. I have been working to help my family survive economically. I'm sorry to hear that, Hadithi. Can you tell me more about the type of work you are doing? I have been working at a construction site after school and on weekends. I carry heavy loads and help with building structures. My family is struggling financially, so I felt like I had to contribute. It's understandable that you want to help your family, but it's important to remember that children have the right to education and a safe environment to grow up in. Child labor can have negative impacts on your health and well-being. I know, but my family depends on the money I earn from working. I don't want to let them down. I understand your concerns, Hadithi. It's important to find a balance between helping your family and taking care of yourself. Have you talked to your parents about your feelings and the impact of your work on your education and health? Yes, I have tried to talk to them, but they say we need the money and there is no other option. I see. It's important to remember that there are resources and support available to help families in difficult situations. I can connect you with organizations that can provide assistance and guidance. Your well-being is important, Hadithi, and there are alternatives to child labor. Thank you, Mwashiuya. I appreciate your help and guidance. I will try to talk to my parents again and see if we can find a better solution.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. My name is Ambilikile, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Asante. I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Namtumbo, Ruvuma. Nice to meet you, Asante. What seems to be troubling you today? I'm really struggling with my emotions at home. My parents are always working and they never have time for me. I feel so alone and neglected. I'm sorry to hear that, Asante. It must be really tough for you to feel that way. Can you tell me more about how this makes you feel? I feel like I'm invisible in my own home. I try to talk to my parents, but they are always too busy or tired to listen. I just want someone to pay attention to me and show me that they care. It's understandable that you would feel that way, Asante. You deserve to feel loved and supported by your family. Have you tried talking to anyone else about how you're feeling? I haven't really talked to anyone about it before. I didn't know who to turn to until I found this helpline number. I'm glad you reached out, Asante. You're not alone in feeling this way, and it's important to talk about your emotions. Is there someone at school or in your community that you trust and can confide in? There is a teacher at my primary school who has always been kind to me. I think I could talk to her about how I'm feeling. Thank you for listening and helping me, Ambilikile. You're welcome, Asante. Remember, it's important to take care of your emotional well-being. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need further support.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Masomakali speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Hussein, I'm 17 years old and I'm calling from Malinyi, Morogoro. Nice to meet you, Hussein. How can I assist you today? I have a problem with orphaned and abandoned children in my community. There are many kids who have lost their parents or been left by their families. They are living with distant relatives, but the care they receive is not adequate. That sounds like a difficult situation. It's important for these children to be in a safe and supportive environment. Have you tried talking to anyone about this issue? Yes, I have spoken to some of the elders in my village, but they seem overwhelmed with other responsibilities. I don't know where else to turn for help. I understand your concern, Hussein. Have you considered reaching out to the local authorities, like the police station, for assistance? I haven't thought about that. Do you think they could help with this situation? Yes, the police station may be able to provide support or connect you with organizations that specialize in child welfare. It's important to ensure that these children are receiving the care and protection they need. Thank you, Masomakali. I will visit the police station and see how they can help. I appreciate your guidance on this matter. You're welcome, Hussein. Remember, you're not alone in this. Feel free to reach out to us anytime you need assistance or support. Take care.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Ashura speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Fortunata. I'm calling about my son, Mohamed. He's 8 years old and we live in Arumeru Mashariki, Arusha. I'm really concerned about him. What seems to be the issue with Mohamed, Fortunata? He's been really anxious and stressed lately. I think it's because of all the instability in our family. His father and I have been having a lot of arguments and it's really affecting him. I'm sorry to hear that, Fortunata. It's important to address these issues for Mohamed's well-being. Have you noticed any specific changes in his behavior or mood? Yes, he's been more quiet and withdrawn. He used to be so lively and energetic, but now he seems sad and worried all the time. I just want to help him feel better. It's understandable that you're worried about Mohamed. It's important to create a safe and stable environment for him. Have you tried talking to him about his feelings or seeking support from other family members or friends? I've tried talking to him, but he's so young and I don't think he fully understands what's going on. I haven't really reached out to other family members or friends, but maybe that's something I should consider. It's important for Mohamed to feel supported and understood during this challenging time. If you need any additional assistance or resources, please don't hesitate to reach out to us. We're here to help you and Mohamed through this difficult situation. Thank you, Ashura. I appreciate your support and guidance. I'll definitely consider reaching out to others for help.

Hello, is this the child helpline? I really need someone to talk to. Yes, this is Barke from the child helpline. How can I help you today? My name is Shangazi, I'm 11 years old, and I live in Magharibi Unguja, Mjini Magharibi. I'm calling because I don't know what to do anymore. My caregiver has been hitting me a lot lately and I don't know why. I'm really sorry to hear that, Shangazi. It's not okay for anyone to hurt you. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, my caregiver has been really stressed out lately because of work and money problems. I think that's why she takes it out on me. She yells at me for little things and sometimes she hits me too. I try to be good, but it's never enough. That sounds really tough, Shangazi. It's not your fault that your caregiver is feeling overwhelmed. You deserve to be treated with love and respect. Have you talked to anyone else about what's been happening? No, I haven't. I'm scared that if I tell someone, things will get worse. But I can't keep living like this. I don't know what to do. It's brave of you to reach out for help, Shangazi. You deserve to feel safe and protected. We can help you find a safe solution to this situation. Would you be comfortable with us contacting someone who can help you? Yes, please. I want things to get better. Thank you for listening to me, Barke. You're welcome, Shangazi. We will do everything we can to support you. Let's work together to make sure you are safe and cared for.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Jaali speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Jaali, my name is Anthonia. I'm 27 years old and I'm calling about a child named Winnie who is 17 years old. She lives in Babati Vijijini, Manyara. Thank you for reaching out, Anthonia. Can you tell me more about what's going on with Winnie? Well, Winnie has been dealing with a lot of parental conflicts at home. Her parents are constantly arguing and fighting, and it's really taking a toll on her mental health. She's been feeling stressed and anxious because of their constant bickering. I'm sorry to hear that Winnie is going through such a difficult time. It's important for her to feel safe and supported at home. Have you talked to Winnie about how she's feeling? Yes, I have. She's opened up to me about how overwhelmed she feels with all the tension in her household. She's been struggling to focus on her schoolwork and her overall well-being is being affected. It's great that Winnie has someone like you to confide in. It's important for her to know that she's not alone and that there are people who care about her well-being. Have you tried talking to her parents about the impact their conflicts are having on Winnie? I have, but unfortunately, her parents don't seem to realize how their behavior is affecting Winnie. They're under a lot of external pressure and it's causing them to take out their frustrations on each other and on Winnie. I understand. It's a challenging situation, but it's important for Winnie to feel safe and supported. I can provide you with some resources and guidance on how to help Winnie cope with the parental conflicts and navigate through this difficult time. Thank you for reaching out, Anthonia. Let's work together to support Winnie.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Msafiri speaking, how can I assist you today? Hello, my name is Noah, I am 47 years old, and I am calling about a child named Latifa. She is 15 years old and she lives in Mbarali, Mbeya. I am concerned about her well-being. Thank you for reaching out, Noah. Can you please share with me what specific issue or concern you have regarding Latifa? I believe Latifa's rights are being violated. She is being forced to work long hours on a farm by her relatives, and she is not able to attend school regularly. I am worried about her safety and education. I appreciate you bringing this to our attention, Noah. It is indeed concerning to hear about Latifa's situation. Every child has the right to be protected from exploitation and to receive an education. We will do everything we can to help Latifa. Can you provide me with any additional information about her situation? Latifa's relatives have been taking advantage of her vulnerability since her parents passed away. They do not provide her with proper care or support, and she is often left to fend for herself. I fear for her safety and well-being. Thank you for sharing these details, Noah. It is important that we take action to protect Latifa's rights and ensure that she receives the support she needs. I will escalate this case to the appropriate authorities and organizations to intervene and provide assistance to Latifa. Please rest assured that we are here to help and support both you and Latifa through this process. Thank you for your prompt response, Msafiri. I appreciate your assistance in this matter. I hope Latifa can receive the help she deserves.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Janeth speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Bahari. I'm 10 years old, and I'm calling from Mafia in Pwani. Hello Bahari, it's nice to meet you. How can I assist you today? I, um, I don't really know how to say this, but I think I've been... I've been touched inappropriately by someone in my community. I'm so sorry to hear that, Bahari. It takes a lot of courage to talk about something like this. Can you tell me more about what happened? Well, there's this man who lives near my house, and he always wants me to come over to play games with him. But then, when we're alone, he... he touches me in places he shouldn't. That sounds really scary, Bahari. It's important for you to know that what this man is doing is not okay. You have the right to feel safe and protected. I don't know what to do. I'm scared to tell my parents because I don't want to get in trouble. You're not in trouble, Bahari. It's not your fault that this is happening to you. You deserve to be safe and protected. Have you thought about talking to a trusted adult about what's been happening? I haven't. But I'm glad I called you. It feels good to talk about it. I'm glad you reached out, Bahari. You can always call us at the Child Helpline whenever you need to talk or get help. And remember, you can reach out to the police or social welfare department for further assistance. Your safety is important. If you ever feel in danger, call this number for immediate help: +255 6983 168397. Thank you, Janeth. I feel better already knowing that I have someone to talk to. You're welcome, Bahari. Remember, you're not alone in this. We're here to support you.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Florian. I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Arumeru Mashariki, Arusha. Hello Florian, I'm Azize from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? I'm calling because I'm having some issues at home. There has been a lot of fighting and violence between my parents lately. I'm sorry to hear that, Florian. It must be really difficult for you to witness such conflicts at home. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, it started a few months ago with small arguments, but now it has escalated to physical violence. I'm scared for my safety and the safety of my younger siblings. I understand how frightening that must be for you. It's important to prioritize your safety and well-being. Have you tried talking to your parents about how their behavior is affecting you and your siblings? I have tried to talk to them, but it only seems to make things worse. I don't know what else to do. It's brave of you to try to communicate with your parents, Florian. It's not your responsibility to fix their problems, but it's important for you to seek help and support. Have you thought about reaching out to other family members, friends, or authorities for assistance? I haven't told anyone else about what's been happening at home. I was too scared and ashamed, but I couldn't keep it to myself anymore. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, Florian. It takes courage to ask for help, and I'm glad you reached out to us. We can connect you with resources and support to help you navigate this difficult situation. Your safety and well-being are our top priority.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Etana from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Amali. I'm 17 years old and I'm calling from Kinondoni, Dar es Salaam. Nice to meet you, Amali. What seems to be the problem? I've been feeling a lot of pressure from my friends to try drugs and alcohol. I know it's risky behavior, but it's hard to say no sometimes. Peer pressure can be tough to deal with, especially when it involves risky behavior like substance experimentation. Have you already experimented with drugs or alcohol? Yeah, I tried smoking weed with my friends last weekend, and I didn't really enjoy it. But now they're pressuring me to try something stronger, and I'm not sure how to handle it. It's important to remember that you always have a choice, Amali. It's okay to say no to things that make you uncomfortable or put you at risk. Have you talked to your friends about how you feel? Not really, I'm afraid they'll make fun of me or stop hanging out with me. It's understandable to feel that way, but true friends will respect your boundaries and decisions. It might be helpful to have an honest conversation with them about how you feel. You can also reach out to supportive adults or counselors for guidance. Thank you, Etana. I'll try talking to my friends and seeking help if I need it. I appreciate your advice. You're welcome, Amali. Remember, you deserve to feel safe and respected in your friendships. If you ever need to talk more, feel free to call the helpline again. Take care of yourself. I will. Thank you. Goodbye. Goodbye, Amali. Take care.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Elina speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Idili, I am 13 years old and I'm calling from Iringa Mjini. Nice to meet you, Idili. How can I assist you today? I have been feeling really down lately and I have been having thoughts of hurting myself. I'm sorry to hear that, Idili. It's important that you reach out for help when you are feeling this way. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? I don't know, I just feel so hopeless and lost. I feel like nobody cares about me. I'm here to listen to you, Idili. Your feelings are valid and I want to help you through this. Have you ever hurt yourself before? Yes, I have. I've been cutting myself when I feel overwhelmed. I'm glad you reached out to us, Idili. It takes a lot of courage to talk about these things. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I found this helpline number. I'm glad you called, Idili. It's important that you get the support you need. I think it would be best for you to seek help from a professional. Is there a trusted adult you can talk to about this, like a teacher or a family member? I think I can talk to my teacher about it. I just don't want my parents to know. That's okay, Idili. Your teacher can help you get the support you need. Is there a landmark near you, like the District Hospital, where you can go to seek help in case of an emergency? Yes, I know where the District Hospital is. Thank you for your help, Elina. I feel a little better talking to you. I'm here for you, Idili. Remember, you are not alone in this. It's important to take care of yourself and seek help when you need it. Don't hesitate to call us back if you need to talk again. Take care.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Mwipopo. I'm 14 years old and I'm calling from Kinondoni, Dar es Salaam. Hello Mwipopo, I'm Edina from the child helpline. How are you feeling today? I'm feeling a bit confused and stressed out. What's been going on, Mwipopo? Well, I've been feeling a lot of pressure from my friends to start dating. They keep teasing me about not having a girlfriend and it's been really bothering me. I'm sorry to hear that, Mwipopo. It's important to remember that you don't have to rush into anything just because your friends are pressuring you. It's okay to take your time and focus on yourself. I know, but it's hard when everyone around me is in relationships and I feel left out. It's completely understandable to feel that way, Mwipopo. Just remember that it's important to prioritize your own feelings and well-being above what others expect from you. I just don't know how to handle all this pressure. It's starting to affect my schoolwork and my mood. Have you tried talking to your friends about how you're feeling? I haven't really talked to them about it. I'm afraid they'll just make fun of me even more. It's important to have open and honest conversations with your friends about how their actions are affecting you. If they truly care about you, they will listen and understand. I'll try to talk to them and see how it goes. Thank you for listening and giving me advice, Edina. You're welcome, Mwipopo. Remember, you can always call us if you need someone to talk to. Take care of yourself.

Hello, good afternoon. I'm calling about my son, Vincent, who is 9 years old and we live in Kisarawe, Pwani. Hello, this is Natori from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? Well, my son has been having some trouble at school. He's been feeling left out and excluded by his classmates. I'm sorry to hear that, Calvin. Bullying and social exclusion can be very difficult for children to deal with. How long has this been going on? It started a few weeks ago. Vincent told me that some of the other kids in his class have been making fun of him and not including him in their games during break time. It's important to address this issue as soon as possible. Has Vincent talked to his teacher or school counselor about what's been happening? Yes, he did. The teacher spoke to the students involved, but the situation hasn't improved much. Vincent still feels lonely and left out. I understand how concerning this must be for you as a parent. Have you talked to Vincent about how he's feeling and what he would like to see happen? Yes, we've had some conversations about it. He just wants to be able to play with his classmates and feel included like everyone else. It's great that you're supporting him through this. We can work together to come up with some strategies to help Vincent feel more accepted at school. Would you like some advice on how to approach this situation? Yes, please. I want to do everything I can to help my son feel happy and included at school. Let's start by discussing some ways to address this issue with the school and come up with a plan to support Vincent. Let's work together to make sure he feels safe and valued at school.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Ashura. I'm 12 years old and I live in Kinondoni, Dar es Salaam. Hello Ashura, I'm Leah from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? I have some questions about puberty and development. I feel like things are changing in my body and I'm not sure what to do. It's completely normal to have questions about puberty and development at your age, Ashura. What specific concerns do you have? Well, I've noticed some changes in my body like my voice getting deeper and hair growing in new places. I'm not sure if this is normal or if something is wrong. Those changes are all part of puberty, Ashura. It's your body growing and developing as you become older. It's completely normal and nothing to be worried about. But I feel so confused and sometimes embarrassed about these changes. I don't know who to talk to or where to get information from. It's okay to feel confused and embarrassed, Ashura. It's a natural part of growing up. It's great that you reached out to us for support. You can always talk to a trusted adult like a parent, teacher, or healthcare provider about your concerns. Thank you, Leah. I feel better knowing that these changes are normal. I will try to talk to someone I trust about this too. That's great to hear, Ashura. Remember, we are always here to support you whenever you need it. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any more questions or concerns in the future. Thank you, Leah. I really appreciate your help and guidance. You're welcome, Ashura. Take care and remember that you're not alone in this journey of growing up.

Hello, is this the child helpline? I'm feeling really lonely and I don't know who to talk to about it. Yes, this is Busu from the child helpline. I'm here to listen. Can you tell me your name, age, and where you're calling from? My name is Jeremy, I'm 11 years old, and I'm calling from Mpanda, Rukwa. I just started at the Secondary School this year, and I feel like I don't fit in with the other kids. I'm sorry to hear that, Jeremy. It can be tough starting at a new school and feeling like you don't belong. Have you tried talking to any of your classmates about how you're feeling? I've tried, but they all seem to already have their own friends and groups. I just feel like I'm on the outside looking in. It's completely normal to feel that way, Jeremy. It takes time to adjust to a new environment and make new friends. Have you thought about joining any clubs or activities at school to meet new people? I've thought about it, but I'm not sure where to start. I'm not very good at sports, and I don't know what else to try. There are plenty of other clubs and activities at school that don't involve sports. You could try joining the art club or the music club. It's a great way to meet new friends who share the same interests as you. That's a good idea, Busu. I think I'll give it a try. Thank you for listening to me and giving me some advice. It really means a lot to me. I'm glad I could help, Jeremy. Remember, it's okay to feel lonely sometimes, but there are always people who care about you and want to help. Don't hesitate to reach out if you ever need to talk again.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Aziza, how can I help you today? Hi Aziza, my name is Mwakipesile. I'm 13 years old and I live in Unguja Kaskazini A, Kaskazini Unguja. Nice to meet you, Mwakipesile. What seems to be troubling you today? I'm really scared because my parents recently separated, and now my father has been coming to our house and yelling at my mother. He even hit her once. I'm so sorry to hear that, Mwakipesile. It sounds like a very difficult situation. Your safety is the most important thing right now. Have you talked to anyone else about what's been happening at home? No, I haven't. I don't know who to turn to for help. You did the right thing by calling us, Mwakipesile. It's important to speak up about any form of violence, especially when it's happening at home. Have you thought about talking to a teacher or a trusted adult at your school about what's going on? Yes, I have a teacher at my primary school who I trust. I will try to talk to them about it. That's a good idea, Mwakipesile. Your teacher can help you find the support you need. Remember, you're not alone in this. We're here to support you every step of the way. Is there anything else you would like to talk about or any other concerns you have? No, that's all for now. Thank you for listening, Aziza. You're welcome, Mwakipesile. Take care and remember that you deserve to feel safe and loved. Don't hesitate to reach out to us again if you need to talk.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Lina, I'm 12 years old, and I'm calling from Karagwe, Kagera. Hello Lina, I'm Saidi from the child helpline. How can I assist you? I don't know who else to talk to, but my village was hit by a terrible flood last week. Our houses were destroyed, and many people were injured. I'm scared and don't know what to do. I'm so sorry to hear that, Lina. It must be a very difficult time for you and your community. Have you and your family been able to find a safe place to stay? Yes, we are staying at a temporary shelter, but it's crowded and uncomfortable. I miss my home. I understand, Lina. It's normal to feel scared and sad after experiencing such a traumatic event. Have you been able to talk to anyone about how you're feeling? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I found this helpline number. I'm glad you reached out, Lina. It's important to talk about your feelings and fears. It's also essential to take care of yourself during this challenging time. Remember to eat well, get enough rest, and try to find moments of joy, even in difficult circumstances. Thank you, Saidi. I will try to do that. Do you think our village will ever be the same again? Rebuilding after a natural disaster takes time and effort, Lina. But with the support of your community and organizations that provide aid, things will get better. It's essential to stay strong and hopeful for the future. I will try to do that, Saidi. Thank you for listening and for your advice. You're welcome, Lina. Remember, you can always reach out to us whenever you need someone to talk to. Stay strong, and take care.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Haji, how can I assist you today? Hi Haji, my name is Sakina, I'm 17 years old and I'm calling from Handeni Mjini, Tanga. Nice to meet you, Sakina. How can I help you today? I'm facing a problem with my educational rights being denied. My parents are not allowing me to go to school anymore. I'm sorry to hear that, Sakina. Education is a fundamental right for every child. Have you tried talking to your parents about this issue? Yes, but they refuse to listen to me. They believe that girls should not go to school and should stay at home instead. That's not right, Sakina. Every child, regardless of gender, has the right to education. Have you spoken to any teachers or school authorities about this? I haven't, I'm scared of what my parents might do if they find out. I don't know what to do. Don't worry, Sakina. You've taken the first step by reaching out to us. We can help you navigate this situation and ensure your right to education is protected. Can you provide me with your phone number so we can follow up with you? Sure, my phone number is +255 7936 578146. Thank you for listening, Haji. Of course, Sakina. We are here to support you. I will connect you with the appropriate resources to address this issue. Please remember, education is your right, and no one should deny you that. You can also visit our office near the Police Station in Tanga for further assistance. Thank you, Haji. I feel better knowing that there is someone who can help me.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Busu, I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Namtumbo, Ruvuma. Hello Busu, I'm Hala from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? I have some questions about puberty and development. I'm not sure what's happening to my body. It's completely normal to have questions about puberty, Busu. Can you tell me a little more about what you're experiencing? Well, I've noticed that my body is changing, and I'm not sure why. I have also started to have some strange feelings that I don't understand. It sounds like you are going through puberty, Busu. During this time, your body goes through a lot of changes as you grow into an adult. It's important to talk about these changes and ask questions. I'm a bit scared to talk about it with anyone. I don't know who to ask. You can always talk to someone you trust, like a parent, guardian, or teacher. You can also reach out to us here at the child helpline. We are here to support you and answer any questions you may have. Thank you, Hala. I feel a bit better knowing that I can talk to someone about this. I will try to talk to my parents about it too. That's great, Busu. Remember, it's important to take care of your body and understand these changes. If you ever feel uncomfortable or have more questions, you can always call us or visit our office near the Police Station in your area. We are here to help you. Thank you, Hala. I will keep that in mind.

Hello, thank you for calling the Child Helpline, this is Sheila speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi Sheila, my name is Angy. I'm calling about my daughter Imani, she's 14 years old and we live in Mtwara Mjini, Mtwara. I'm really worried about her. What seems to be the problem, Angy? Hello, Child Helpline, this is Rach. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Reth. I'm 12 years old, and I'm calling from Kati Unguja, Kusini Unguja. Nice to meet you, Reth. What's on your mind? Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Salome speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Salome, my name is Hellen. Hey there, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Hadithi. I'm 10 years old and I live in Nyamagana, Mwanza. Hello Hadithi, I'm Kwasi from the child helpline. What's on your mind today? Hello, Child Helpline, this is Naomi speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Ngonepe. I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Bahi, Dodoma. Nice to meet you, Ngonepe. Most of our family lives far away, and our neighbors are also struggling with their own damaged homes. I see. In situations like this, it's important to stay calm and seek help from local authorities or organizations that provide assistance during natural disasters. Thank you, Naomi. I will try to find help for my family and neighbors. I appreciate your advice and support. You're welcome, Ngonepe. Remember, you can always call the child helpline for more guidance or assistance. Stay safe and take care.

Hello, you've reached the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Hala speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Hala, my name is Eunice. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Simanjiro, Manyara. Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Mariam speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Mariam, my name is Emmy and I'm 11 years old. I'm calling from Lindi Mjini, Lindi. Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline, this is Akili speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Josephine. I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Same, Kilimanjaro. Hello, Child Helpline, this is Shangazi speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, Shangazi. My name is Rebecca, I'm 12 years old, and I'm calling from Misungwi, Mwanza. Nice to meet you, Rebecca. Hello, this is the Tanzanian child helpline, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Albina, I'm 17 years old and I'm from Mbarali, Mbeya. I have some questions about child nutrition. Of course, Albina. My name is Tumo, and I'm here to help you with any concerns you may have about child nutrition. What specifically would you like to know? Well, I have a younger sister who has some special dietary needs. She is allergic to gluten and dairy products, and I'm not sure how to ensure she is getting all the nutrients she needs. I understand your concern, Albina. It's important to make sure your sister's dietary needs are met while still providing her with a balanced and nutritious diet. Have you consulted with a healthcare professional about her allergies and dietary requirements? Yes, we have seen a doctor who recommended a gluten-free and dairy-free diet for her. But I'm still struggling to come up with meal ideas that are both safe for her to eat and nutritious. It's great that you've already sought medical advice on this matter. When planning meals for your sister, you can focus on whole foods such as fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains like quinoa or rice. There are also many gluten-free and dairy-free alternatives available in stores now that can help you create a variety of meals for her. Thank you, Tumo. I will definitely look into those options and try to create more balanced meals for my sister. I appreciate your help and guidance on this matter. You're welcome, Albina. If you have any more questions or need further assistance, please don't hesitate to reach out to us again. Take care of yourself and your sister.

Hello there, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Amri from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi Amri, my name is Dina. I'm a 14-year-old girl from Namtumbo, Ruvuma. They can provide you with counseling, resources, and a support network to help you through this difficult time. Would you like me to assist you in finding help? Yes, please. I would appreciate any guidance you can provide. Thank you, Amri, for listening to me and offering your support. You're welcome, Dina. It's important to reach out for help when you need it. I will connect you with the necessary resources. Remember, you are not alone in this.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Saada speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Saada, my name is Mwakisyala and I'm 15 years old. I'm from Sengerema, Mwanza. I feel like I can't talk to my friends or family about it because they might not understand or accept me. I'm glad you reached out to us. You deserve to have support and guidance during this time. It's important to find someone who will listen to you without judgment and provide you with the support you need. Thank you for listening to me and for offering your support. Of course, Mwakisyala. Remember, you are not alone and there are people who care about you and want to help you during this time. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any more questions or need further assistance. Thank you, Saada. I feel a bit better now knowing that there are people I can talk to about this.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Mzee. I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Bariadi, Shinyanga. Hi Mzee, I'm Tina, a counselor here at the child helpline. I don't want anyone to get hurt. I understand your concern, Mzee. It's important to prioritize safety in these situations. Have you talked to your mom about how you're feeling? Yes, I have. Thank you for listening and for offering help.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I assist you today? Hi there, my name is Vinza. I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Mkuranga, Pwani. Hello Vinza, I'm Kwasi from the child helpline. Hello, Child Helpline, this is Hilary speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Jaqueline, I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Chake Chake, Kusini Pemba. Nice to meet you, Jaqueline. Hello, good afternoon. My name is Fidelis, and I'm calling about a child in need of help. His name is Kafil, he's 11 years old, and he lives in Nzega, Tabora. Hello Fidelis, I'm Mkuu from the child helpline. How can I assist you today regarding Kafil? Thank you for taking my call, Mkuu. They can't afford to pay for his school fees and other necessary materials. I see, that is indeed a serious issue. Every child has the right to education, and it's concerning to hear that Kafil is being deprived of this fundamental right. Have you tried speaking to his family about this matter? Yes, I have spoken to his family, but unfortunately, they are unable to afford the expenses needed for Kafil to attend school regularly. I believe he has a lot of potential and deserves the opportunity to receive an education. Thank you for sharing this information with us, Fidelis. We will work on finding a solution to ensure that Kafil's educational rights are upheld. In the meantime, I will escalate this issue to our team so we can provide the necessary support and guidance to Kafil and his family. I truly appreciate your assistance, Mkuu. Kafil's future is important, and I believe with the right support, he can achieve great things. Thank you for listening to my concerns and taking action to help him.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Blandina speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Mwasote, I am 10 years old and I am calling from Sumbawanga Mjini, Rukwa. Nice to meet you, Mwasote. What seems to be the problem? I am calling because I have been working to help my family survive. My parents are struggling to make ends meet, so I have to work to earn money. I'm sorry to hear that, Mwasote. Can you tell me more about the kind of work you are doing? I work at a construction site carrying heavy bricks and helping with other tasks. I also sell fruits on the street after school to earn extra money. It sounds like you are doing a lot of hard work for someone your age. Have you talked to your parents about how you feel? Yes, I have told them that I am tired and sometimes I miss school because of work. But they say we need the money to buy food and pay for school fees. It's important for children to go to school and have time to play and rest. Child labor is not allowed in Tanzania, and you have the right to be protected from this kind of work. But if I don't work, my family will not have enough to eat. What can I do? I understand your concern, Mwasote. Let's work together to find a solution that will help your family without putting your health and education at risk. I can help you connect with organizations that provide support for families in need. Thank you, Blandina. I feel better knowing that there are people who can help us.

Hey, um, hi there. Hello Sarki, my name is Mwanandeke and I'm here to help you. How can I assist you today? I'm Sarki, I'm 15 years old, and I'm calling from Dodoma, Dodoma. I'm having some problems with my school. I'm sorry to hear that, Sarki. Can you please tell me more about what's going on? Well, you see, my school has been denying me my right to education. They keep sending me home for not paying school fees, even though my family can't afford it. I just want to learn and have a better future, but it feels like they don't care about that. I understand how frustrating that must be, Sarki. Education is a fundamental right for every child. Have you tried talking to anyone at the school about your situation? I have, but they just tell me that I need to pay the fees or I can't attend classes. It's not fair, Mwanandeke. I want to study and improve my life, but it's like they're blocking me from doing that. I hear you, Sarki. It's important to know that you have the right to education, regardless of your financial situation. Have you talked to your parents or guardians about this issue? Yes, I have, but they're struggling to make ends meet. They want me to go to school, but they just can't afford the fees. I don't know what to do. I'm glad you reached out to us, Sarki. We can help you navigate this situation and advocate for your right to education. Let's work together to find a solution and ensure you can continue your studies without any obstacles.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Fadhili speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Ashura, I'm 39 years old, and I'm calling about a child named Balozi from Bukombe, Shinyanga. Nice to meet you, Ashura. How can I help you with Balozi today? Well, Balozi is 11 years old and has been struggling with school. He's been skipping classes and his grades are dropping significantly. I see, that does sound concerning. Have you tried talking to Balozi about his behavior and academic performance? Yes, I have tried speaking to him, but he seems disinterested in school. He used to enjoy learning, but lately, he's been avoiding going to school altogether. It's important to address this issue as soon as possible to prevent further academic decline. Has Balozi mentioned any specific reasons for his truancy? He mentioned feeling overwhelmed with his schoolwork and not being able to keep up with the lessons. He also mentioned feeling bullied by some of his classmates. It's crucial to address these issues promptly. Have you spoken to the school about Balozi's situation? Yes, I have, but they didn't seem to have a solution. They suggested seeking help from a counselor or a child helpline. I'm glad you reached out to us. We can provide support and guidance to help Balozi overcome these challenges. I recommend scheduling a meeting with a counselor at Balozi's school or visiting the nearest child helpline office for further assistance. Thank you for your advice, Fadhili. I will make sure to take the necessary steps to help Balozi get back on track with his education. You're welcome, Ashura. Remember, it's essential to provide Balozi with the support he needs to succeed in school. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need further assistance.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Suzana speaking, how can I help you today? Hello Suzana, my name is Peace, I am 54 years old, and I am calling about a young boy named Omar who lives in Kaliua, Tabora. He is 17 years old and I am really worried about him. What seems to be the issue with Omar, Peace? Well, lately he has been very withdrawn and sad. He used to be so full of life and energy, but now he barely speaks to anyone and spends most of his time alone in his room. I think he might be struggling with depression. I'm sorry to hear that, Peace. It must be difficult to see him going through this. Can you tell me if there have been any major life changes or events that could have triggered his depression? Yes, actually, Omar recently lost his father in a tragic accident at the River Bridge. It has been a very tough time for him and the whole family. I think he is still struggling to come to terms with the loss. I can imagine how difficult that must be for him. Losing a parent is a major life event and can have a significant impact on a young person's mental health. It's important that he receives the support and help he needs during this challenging time. Have you tried talking to him about how he is feeling? Yes, I have tried to talk to him but he is very closed off and doesn't want to share his feelings with me. I just want to make sure he gets the help he needs to overcome this depression. I understand your concern, Peace. It's important that Omar knows he is not alone and that there are people who care about him and want to help. I will provide you with some resources and information on how to support him through this difficult time. Thank you for reaching out to us.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Willy speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi Willy, my name is Christopher. I'm 16 years old and I'm from Chemba in Dodoma. I'm really struggling with my schoolwork and I don't know what to do. I'm sorry to hear that, Christopher. Can you tell me more about what specific difficulties you are facing with your schoolwork? I just can't seem to understand the lessons like the other students. It takes me longer to process information and I often feel lost in class. It sounds like you may be experiencing some learning difficulties. Have you spoken to your teachers or parents about this? I've tried talking to my teachers, but they just tell me to work harder. My parents are always busy with work, so I don't want to bother them. It's important to remember that it's okay to ask for help, Christopher. Have you considered speaking to a school counselor or seeking extra support outside of school? I haven't thought about that before. Do you think it would be helpful for me to seek additional support? Yes, seeking help from a counselor or a learning support program could provide you with the tools and strategies you need to overcome your learning difficulties. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this. Thank you, Willy. I will definitely consider reaching out for additional support. I appreciate your guidance and advice. You're welcome, Christopher. Remember, it's important to take care of your mental and emotional well-being. If you ever need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to reach out to us at the child helpline. Take care and best of luck with your studies.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Cyrus speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Ndweleifwa. I am 11 years old and I live in Unguja Kaskazini B, Kaskazini Unguja. Nice to meet you, Ndweleifwa. What seems to be the problem? I am calling because I am an orphan. My parents passed away last year, and I have been living with my grandmother since then. But she is very old and sick, and she can't take care of me anymore. I'm so sorry to hear that, Ndweleifwa. It must be really tough for you. Have you reached out to any other family members for help? I don't have any other family members who can take care of me. I am all alone now. I understand. It's important for you to know that you are not alone. There are organizations and shelters that can help children in situations like yours. Have you heard of St. Mary's Church in your area? Yes, I know St. Mary's Church. They sometimes provide food and clothes to children in need. That's great to hear. I suggest you go to St. Mary's Church and speak to the priest there. They may be able to connect you with resources and support to help you during this difficult time. Thank you, Cyrus. I will do that. I really appreciate your help. You're welcome, Ndweleifwa. Remember, it's important to reach out for help when you need it. You deserve to be taken care of and supported. Take care, and good luck.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Salima from the child helpline. How can I help you today? My name is Mwakalinga, I am 10 years old and I am calling from Unguja Kaskazini A, Kaskazini Unguja. I am feeling really sad and I don't know what to do. I'm sorry to hear that, Mwakalinga. Can you tell me more about why you're feeling sad? I don't know, I just feel like everything is too much and I can't handle it anymore. I feel like maybe I should just give up. It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed. Have you been having any thoughts of hurting yourself? Yes, sometimes I think about hurting myself. I don't know what to do. I'm glad you called us, Mwakalinga. It's important to talk about these feelings. You are not alone in this, and we are here to help you. Can you tell me more about what's been going on that's making you feel this way? I don't know, I just feel like nothing is going right in my life. I don't have any friends at school, and my parents are always fighting. It's understandable to feel sad when things are tough at home and at school. But please remember that there are people who care about you and want to help. It's important to keep talking about how you're feeling and not keep it all inside. Thank you, Salima. I feel a little better talking to you. I'm glad to hear that, Mwakalinga. Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you're feeling overwhelmed. You can always call us back if you need to talk more. And if you ever feel like hurting yourself, please reach out to someone you trust or call for help immediately. You are not alone in this.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Yahya, I'm 16 years old, and I'm calling from Mkalama, Singida. Hello Yahya, I'm Fahamu from the child helpline. How are you feeling today? I've been feeling really lonely and isolated lately. I don't have many friends here and I feel like I don't fit in. I'm sorry to hear that, Yahya. It must be tough feeling that way. Have you tried talking to anyone about how you're feeling? Not really. I don't think anyone would understand. I feel like I'm different from everyone else here. It's okay to feel that way, Yahya. Everyone is unique in their own way. Have you tried getting involved in any activities or clubs at school? I've tried, but it's hard to connect with people when you feel like you don't belong. I just feel so alone most of the time. I understand how that can be difficult. Is there anything specific that triggers these feelings of loneliness and isolation for you? I think it's mostly because I come from a different background than most people here. I feel like I don't have anyone to talk to who truly understands me. I'm here to listen, Yahya. You're not alone in feeling this way. Have you considered reaching out to a counselor or therapist to talk about these feelings? I haven't thought about that before. Maybe it would help to talk to someone who can help me understand why I feel this way. That's a great idea, Yahya. Remember, you can always call us at the child helpline if you need someone to talk to. Is there anything else on your mind that you'd like to share? Thank you, Fahamu. I appreciate you listening to me. I'll consider reaching out for more help. You're welcome, Yahya. Remember, you're not alone. Take care of yourself and feel free to call us anytime at +255 6952 623214.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Andengwisye. How can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Evelina. I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Arumeru Mashariki, Arusha. Nice to meet you, Evelina. What seems to be the problem? I'm going through a tough time at home. My parents have been physically abusing me for a while now. I'm sorry to hear that, Evelina. Can you tell me more about the situation? It started with just a few slaps here and there, but lately, it's been escalating to more severe beatings. I don't know what to do. That sounds really difficult, Evelina. No child should have to go through that. Have you tried talking to anyone about this? I haven't told anyone because I'm scared of what might happen if my parents find out. I understand your fear, Evelina. But it's important to seek help and protect yourself. You deserve to be safe and happy. Have you thought about reaching out to a trusted adult or authority figure? I haven't, but I'm glad I called you. I didn't know where else to turn. I'm glad you reached out, Evelina. We are here to support you. We can help you come up with a plan to address the abuse and ensure your safety. Would you like to talk more about this? Yes, please. I want to find a way to make it stop. I'm here to help you through this, Evelina. Let's work together to find a solution.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi there, my name is Fatma, I'm 13 years old, and I'm calling from Serengeti, Mara. Hello Fatma, this is Farasi from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? I'm really scared, Farasi. My parents fight all the time, and I don't know what to do. I'm so sorry to hear that, Fatma. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? My dad is always yelling at my mom, and sometimes he hits her. I hear them arguing late at night, and it's really scary. It sounds like you're going through a tough situation, Fatma. No one should have to experience violence in their home. Have you talked to anyone about what's been happening? I haven't told anyone. I'm afraid of what might happen if I do. It's important to speak up about what's going on, Fatma. Your safety and well-being are the top priority. We can help you find a safe place and support to deal with this situation. I don't want my family to get in trouble because of me. You're not alone in this, Fatma. We are here to support you and ensure that you're safe. It's not your fault, and you deserve to be in a safe and loving environment. Thank you, Farasi. I feel a little better knowing that I can talk to someone about this. I'm glad you reached out, Fatma. We will do everything we can to help you. You deserve to live in a home free from violence.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Dora speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Mwakipesile, I am 15 years old and I'm calling from Mwanga, Kilimanjaro. Hello, Mwakipesile. How can I help you today? I'm calling because I am experiencing physical abuse at home. My parents have been using corporal punishment on me, but lately, it has been escalating. I'm so sorry to hear that, Mwakipesile. Can you tell me more about what has been happening? My parents have always used physical punishment as a form of discipline, but recently it has become more severe. They hit me with belts and sticks, leaving bruises and marks on my body. I feel scared and unsafe at home. That sounds really difficult, Mwakipesile. No one should have to endure that kind of treatment. Have you spoken to anyone about this before? No, I haven't. I didn't know where to turn to for help until I heard about the child helpline. I'm glad you reached out to us, Mwakipesile. You don't deserve to be treated this way. It's important to remember that physical abuse is not acceptable, and there are people who can help you. Have you thought about talking to someone at school or a trusted adult in your community? I haven't, but I will consider reaching out to someone I trust. Thank you for listening and for your support, Dora. You're welcome, Mwakipesile. Remember, you have the right to feel safe and protected. If you ever feel in immediate danger, don't hesitate to call the police or reach out to us again. We are here to help you.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Zawadi, how can I assist you today? Hi Zawadi, my name is Joseph and I'm calling about my son, Vincent. He's 13 years old and we live in Kigoma Ujiji, Kigoma. Nice to meet you, Joseph. What seems to be the issue with Vincent? Well, I'm worried about his physical health. He's been feeling tired all the time, and he's been having frequent headaches. I took him to the doctor, but they couldn't find anything wrong. I'm sorry to hear that, Joseph. It's good that you took him to see a doctor. Have you noticed any changes in his behavior or mood recently? Yes, actually. He's been more irritable and withdrawn lately. I thought it was just teenage moodiness, but now I'm not so sure. It sounds like there could be a connection between his mental and physical health. Sometimes, emotional distress can manifest as physical symptoms. Have there been any recent changes or stressors in his life? Well, we did move to a new city a few months ago, so that could be affecting him. Plus, with the pandemic, he hasn't been able to see his friends as much. Moving to a new city and the pandemic can definitely be stressful for a young person. It's important to support him emotionally during this time. Maybe consider talking to him about his feelings and encouraging him to engage in activities he enjoys. Thank you, Zawadi. I'll try to have a heart-to-heart with Vincent and see if that helps. I appreciate your advice. You're welcome, Joseph. Remember, we're here to support you and Vincent. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need further assistance. Take care.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Franklin speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Lidia. I'm 17 years old and I'm calling from Meatu, Shinyanga. Nice to meet you, Lidia. What seems to be the problem? I was involved in a terrible accident near the River Bridge in my village. It was really scary and I can't stop thinking about it. I'm so sorry to hear that, Lidia. It's understandable to feel scared and overwhelmed after experiencing something like that. Can you tell me more about what happened? I was on my way to school when a speeding car lost control and crashed into the bridge. I saw everything and I couldn't move, I was frozen with fear. That must have been a traumatic experience for you. Have you talked to anyone about how you're feeling? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to talk to or where to turn for help. I've been having nightmares and I can't focus on anything. It's important to talk about your feelings and seek support after a traumatic event like this. It's not easy to deal with these emotions alone. Have you spoken to your family or friends about what happened? I haven't told anyone yet. I didn't want to worry them or burden them with my problems. It's okay to lean on others for support, Lidia. Your family and friends care about you and they would want to help you through this difficult time. It might also be helpful to speak with a counselor or therapist who can provide you with coping strategies and techniques to manage your trauma. Would you like me to help you find someone to talk to?

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Dativa speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Dativa, my name is Jacob. I'm 26 years old and I'm calling about a child named Faith who lives in Hanang, Manyara. I'm really worried about her. Tell me more about what's going on with Faith. Well, Faith comes from a family where substance abuse is a big problem. Her parents are struggling with addiction, and it's affecting Faith's well-being. She's only 13 years old and she's been through so much already. I'm so sorry to hear that, Jacob. It must be really tough for Faith to see her parents going through that. Have you noticed any specific ways that Faith is being impacted by the substance abuse in her family? Yes, Faith has been struggling in school and her behavior has become more erratic. She used to be such a bright and happy child, but now she seems withdrawn and anxious. I'm worried about her future if things don't change at home. It's understandable that you're concerned for Faith. It's important to address the root cause of her struggles, which seems to be the substance abuse in her family. Have you tried talking to her parents about getting help? I've tried, but they don't seem to be open to the idea of seeking help. They're in denial about their addiction and it's causing a lot of instability in Faith's recovery process. I understand how frustrating that must be. We can work together to find resources and support for Faith, even if her parents are resistant. There are programs and services available that can help her navigate this difficult situation. Let's start by creating a safety plan for Faith and identifying trusted adults in her life who can provide support. Thank you, Dativa. I appreciate your help in this difficult situation. Faith deserves a chance at a better future, and I'm grateful that there are resources available to help her through this challenging time. Let's make sure Faith knows that she's not alone in this, and that there are people who care about her well-being. We'll work together to ensure she gets the support she needs to overcome the challenges she's facing.

Hello, is this the child helpline? I need help. Yes, this is Mama from the child helpline. What can I assist you with today? My name is Faustina, I am 14 years old, and I live in Kigamboni, Dar es Salaam. I am facing a problem with school dropouts and truancy. I'm sorry to hear that, Faustina. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, I used to love going to school and learning new things. But lately, I've been feeling disconnected from the system. I don't feel motivated to attend classes anymore. That sounds tough, Faustina. Have you talked to anyone at school about how you're feeling? I tried to talk to my teachers, but they don't seem to understand. They just tell me to focus on my studies and not to worry about anything else. It's important for your teachers to listen to your concerns, Faustina. Have you spoken to your parents about this? My parents are always busy with work, and I don't want to burden them with my problems. I feel like I have no one to turn to. You're not alone, Faustina. We are here to support you. Have you thought about any solutions to help you feel more connected to school? I haven't really thought about it, Mama. But I know I need to make some changes to get back on track. It's great that you recognize the need for change, Faustina. Let's work together to come up with some strategies to help you feel more engaged with your education. Have you ever visited the Post Office in Kigamboni? They have resources that could assist you in reconnecting with your school and studies. Thank you, Mama. I will definitely check it out. I appreciate your help and support.
