Hello, Child Helpline, this is Silvia speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Faith. I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Morogoro Mjini. Nice to meet you, Faith. What's been going on? I'm really scared, Silvia. My stepfather has been hitting my mom almost every night. I don't know what to do. I'm so sorry to hear that, Faith. It must be really difficult for you to witness that kind of violence. It's terrifying. I don't know how to make it stop. Have you talked to anyone about what's been happening at home? No, I haven't. I'm too afraid. But I can't just sit back and do nothing. You're very brave for reaching out, Faith. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this. There are people who can help. But what can I do? I feel so helpless. There are organizations and resources available to support you and your family in situations like this. Have you ever heard of the Community Center in your area? Yes, I have. It's not too far from where I live. I would encourage you to go there and speak to someone about what's been happening. They have counselors who can provide guidance and support for you and your family. Thank you, Silvia. I will do that. I just want things to get better at home. I'm here for you, Faith. Remember, you deserve to feel safe and loved in your own home. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need anything else.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Hassan speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Hassan, my name is Emmanuel and I'm calling about a child named Eda from Njombe, Iringa. She's 13 years old and she's been working to help her family survive financially. I'm glad you reached out, Emmanuel. It's important to address issues like child labor. Can you tell me more about the type of work Eda is doing? She's been working at a nearby farm, helping with harvesting and other tasks. Her family doesn't have much money, so she feels like she has to work to contribute. I understand the difficult situation Eda and her family are in. It's commendable that she wants to help, but it's also crucial for her to have the opportunity to be a child and go to school. Has she expressed any concerns or struggles related to her work? Yes, she's mentioned feeling tired and missing out on time with her friends. She's also finding it hard to keep up with her schoolwork because of the long hours she's putting in at the farm. It's important for Eda to have a balance between work and education. We can explore potential solutions to support her and her family. Have you discussed this with Eda's parents or guardians? I've spoken to them, but they feel like they have no other choice but to rely on Eda's income. They're willing to listen to advice and support, though. I'm glad to hear that they're open to guidance. We can connect Eda and her family to resources that can help them improve their financial situation without compromising Eda's well-being and education. Thank you for reaching out, Emmanuel. Let's work together to find the best way to support Eda.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Lulu speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Lulu, my name is Jane, I'm 15 years old and I'm from Mbeya Vijijini in Mbeya. I'm calling because I'm really struggling with my basic needs, especially clothing and hygiene. I'm sorry to hear that, Jane. Can you tell me more about your situation? Well, my family is going through a tough time financially and we can't afford to buy new clothes or even basic hygiene products like soap and toothpaste. It's really affecting my self-esteem and I feel embarrassed to go to school. I understand how difficult that must be for you, Jane. Have you tried talking to anyone about this issue? I've tried talking to my parents, but they're already struggling to provide for our family. I don't want to burden them even more. It's important for you to take care of yourself, Jane. You deserve to have clean clothes and maintain good hygiene. We can help connect you with resources in your community that provide assistance with clothing and hygiene products. Would you like me to help you with that? Yes, that would be great. Thank you so much, Lulu. Of course, Jane. I'm here to help. Can you please give me a landmark near your location so we can find the nearest resources for you? Sure, I live near the Bus Stand in Mbeya Vijijini. Thank you, Jane. I will make sure to follow up with you and provide you with the necessary support. In the meantime, please feel free to call the helpline again if you need further assistance. Our phone number is +255 7197 325449. Thank you, Lulu. I really appreciate your help.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Brenda, I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Ubungo, Dar es Salaam. Hello Brenda, I'm Habiba from the child helpline. What seems to be the problem? I'm really worried about my friend, Fatima. She's the same age as me, and she's been working at a construction site near our neighborhood. That sounds concerning, Brenda. Can you tell me more about what's going on? Fatima's been working long hours carrying heavy bricks and rocks, and she's always tired and covered in bruises. I don't think she should be doing this kind of work at our age. It sounds like Fatima might be involved in hazardous child labor, Brenda. It's important to make sure children are safe and protected. Have you talked to anyone about this issue before? I haven't, but I wanted to reach out to someone who could help. I don't want Fatima to get hurt. I'm glad you called, Brenda. It's important to speak up when you see something wrong. We'll do everything we can to help Fatima and make sure she's safe. Can you give me more details about the construction site and where Fatima works? Yes, I can. Thank you for listening and for helping us, Habiba. I hope we can get Fatima out of that dangerous situation soon. Don't worry, Brenda. We'll do our best to assist Fatima. Your courage in speaking up is commendable. Thank you for reaching out to us.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Andengwisye speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Emmy, I'm 15 years old and I live in Ruangwa, Lindi. I'm having a problem with bullying at school. I'm sorry to hear that, Emmy. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, there's this group of girls at school who have been picking on me. They call me names, push me around, and even sometimes hit me. It's been going on for a while now and I don't know what to do. That sounds really tough, Emmy. No one should have to go through that. Have you tried talking to a teacher or a school counselor about what's been happening? I did try talking to my teacher once, but she just told me to ignore them and that they were just being silly. But it's not just silly, it's making me feel really bad about myself. I understand, Emmy. Bullying is a serious issue and it's important that you feel supported and safe at school. Have you talked to your parents or any other adults about what's been happening? I haven't told my parents because I'm scared they'll be worried or angry. But I just can't handle it anymore, it's affecting my schoolwork and my mood. It's important to reach out for help, Emmy. Your parents and other adults in your life care about you and want to support you. I can help you come up with a plan to address the bullying and talk to someone at your school who can help. You're not alone in this, we're here to support you.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Mwinyi speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Mwinyi, my name is Rachel. I'm 16 years old and I'm from Kiteto, Manyara. I'm calling because I'm experiencing physical abuse from my older sister. I'm sorry to hear that Rachel. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, my sister and I have always had a rocky relationship, but lately, things have gotten worse. She's been hitting me and pushing me around whenever we have an argument. It's really starting to affect me mentally and emotionally. That sounds really tough, Rachel. No one deserves to be treated that way, especially by a family member. Have you tried talking to your parents about this? I have, but they always brush it off as just sibling rivalry. They don't take it seriously and it's making me feel really alone and helpless. I understand how that must make you feel. It's important for you to know that what you're experiencing is not okay and you deserve to feel safe. Have you thought about reaching out for help before? I didn't know where to turn to until I found out about this helpline. I just needed someone to talk to and to tell me that what I'm going through is not normal. I'm glad you reached out, Rachel. You're not alone in this and we're here to support you. We can help you come up with a safety plan and connect you with local resources to address the situation with your sister. You deserve to feel safe and respected in your own home.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Asma speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Assa, I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Mbeya Vijijini in Mbeya. I need some help with a physical health concern. Of course, Assa. Can you tell me more about what's going on? I was playing football with my friends earlier, and I fell and hurt my ankle pretty badly. It's swollen and I can't walk properly. I'm sorry to hear that, Assa. Have you tried applying ice to the injury and elevating your leg? Yes, I did that, but it's still really painful. I'm worried it might be serious. It's important to take care of yourself, Assa. Have you spoken to a parent or guardian about this? Yes, I told my aunt, but she said we can't afford to go to the hospital right now. I understand your concern. Is there a nearby health facility or clinic you can visit for an assessment? There's a clinic not too far from my house, but I'm scared to go alone. Would you like me to help you find a trusted adult who can accompany you to the clinic, Assa? Yes, that would be really helpful. Can you please direct me to someone nearby, like the police station? I can definitely help with that. Let me provide you with the contact information for the police station in your area. Please stay on the line while I gather that information for you.

Hello, umm... hi there. Good afternoon, this is Jacqueline from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? Hi Jacqueline, my name is Emma. I'm 12 years old, a girl from Rufiji, Pwani. Nice to meet you, Emma. What seems to be troubling you today? Well, it's about my parents. They've been arguing a lot lately and I don't know what to do. I'm sorry to hear that, Emma. It must be really tough for you. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? My parents are talking about getting a divorce and they keep fighting about who I should live with. It's really scary and I feel stuck in the middle. That sounds really difficult, Emma. It's important for you to know that it's not your fault and you deserve to feel safe and supported. Have you tried talking to your parents about how you feel? I've tried, but they just keep arguing and don't listen to me. I don't know what to do. I understand, Emma. It's important for you to know that there are people who can help you through this tough time. Have you thought about reaching out to a trusted adult or a counselor at school? I haven't, but I feel better talking to you. Thank you for listening, Jacqueline. You're welcome, Emma. Remember, you can always call us back if you need to talk or if you feel unsafe. If things get really bad, you can also go to the Police Station for help. Take care of yourself, okay? Thank you, Jacqueline. I will.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Julius speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Leticia. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Kongwa, Dodoma. Nice to meet you, Leticia. How can I help you today? I've been feeling really sick lately, Julius. I have this chronic health condition that makes me feel weak all the time. I'm sorry to hear that, Leticia. It's important to take care of your health. Have you seen a doctor about your condition? Yes, I have. But my family doesn't have enough money to afford all the medicine and treatments I need. I understand how difficult that must be for you, Leticia. Is there anyone at home who can help you manage your condition? My mom tries her best, but she's also struggling to make ends meet. I feel like a burden to her. You're not a burden, Leticia. It's important to communicate with your family about your feelings and work together to find solutions. I'll try to talk to my mom about it, Julius. But I'm really scared about my health getting worse. It's normal to feel scared, Leticia. But remember, there are people who care about you and want to help. You can also reach out to community health centers for support. Thank you, Julius. I feel a little better talking to you about it. I'll try to be more open with my family about how I'm feeling. I'm glad I could help, Leticia. Remember, you're not alone in this. Feel free to call us anytime you need someone to talk to. Take care of yourself.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Yohana speaking, how can I assist you today? Hello, my name is Josephine, I'm 54 years old, and I'm calling about a child named Asante who is 9 years old. We live in Mkuranga, Pwani. Thank you for reaching out, Josephine. What seems to be the issue with Asante? Well, Asante has been asking me some questions about sexual identity that I'm not sure how to answer. I want to make sure I give her the right information and support. I understand your concern, Josephine. It's great that you're looking out for Asante. It's important to provide age-appropriate and accurate information about sexual and reproductive health. How can I assist you in addressing Asante's questions? I just want to make sure that I am providing Asante with the right information and support as she navigates this topic. Can you help me understand how to talk to her about sexual identity in a way that is helpful and supportive? Of course, Josephine. It's important to create a safe and open environment for Asante to ask questions and express her feelings. You can start by acknowledging her questions and concerns, and providing her with accurate information about sexual identity. If you feel uncomfortable discussing this topic with Asante, it may be helpful to seek support from a counselor or a healthcare provider. Thank you, Yohana. I will make sure to create a safe space for Asante to talk to me about her questions. I appreciate your guidance on this matter. You're welcome, Josephine. Remember that you can always reach out to us at the Tanzanian Child Helpline for support and guidance. If you feel that Asante needs further assistance, you can also visit the Police Station in Mkuranga for additional support and resources. Thank you for reaching out, and take care.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Hekima speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Florentina. I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Mpwapwa, Dodoma. Nice to meet you, Florentina. What's on your mind today? I have a problem. I really like this boy in my class, but I don't know how to tell him. That sounds like a challenging situation. Can you tell me more about it? Well, I've never had a crush on anyone before, so I don't know how to handle these feelings. I'm afraid he won't like me back. It's completely normal to feel nervous about telling someone you like them. Have you talked to your friends or family about this? No, I haven't. I thought it would be better to talk to someone who can give me advice without judging me. I'm glad you reached out to us. It's important to remember that it's okay to have feelings for someone, and it's okay to be nervous about expressing them. Have you tried talking to the boy in a casual way to see how he responds? Not really. I'm too shy to start a conversation with him. Maybe you can start by asking him about something school-related or something you both have in common. It could help break the ice and make it easier to talk to him about your feelings. That's a good idea. I'll try that. Thank you for your advice, Hekima. You're welcome, Florentina. Just remember to be yourself and take things one step at a time. If you ever need to talk more, don't hesitate to call us again. Take care.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Natron, how can I help you today? Hi Natron, my name is Elimu. I'm 12 years old and I live in Mvomero, Morogoro. Nice to meet you, Elimu. How can I assist you today? I need help, Natron. I think my friend Rahma is being forced to work by a man in our village. She looks very tired and scared all the time. I'm sorry to hear that, Elimu. It sounds like Rahma might be a victim of human trafficking. Do you have any more information about the man who is making her work? Yes, his name is Mr. Kibwana. He promised Rahma's family that he would take care of her and send her to school, but instead, he makes her work long hours on his farm without pay. That does sound like labor trafficking, Elimu. It's important that we help Rahma. Can you tell me more about where Mr. Kibwana's farm is located? It's in the outskirts of our village, near the river. It's a big farm with a lot of crops and animals. Thank you for sharing that information, Elimu. I will make sure to report this to the authorities so they can investigate further. In the meantime, is there anything else you would like to share or ask? No, that's all, Natron. Thank you for listening and for helping Rahma. You're welcome, Elimu. Remember, you did the right thing by speaking up. If you ever need help or have any other concerns, don't hesitate to call us again. Take care.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Tina, how can I assist you today? Hi Tina, my name is Cyprian. I'm 38 years old and I'm calling about a child named Elda. She's 13 years old and she's from Micheweni, Kaskazini Pemba. Thank you for providing that information, Cyprian. What seems to be the issue with Elda? I believe Elda is a victim of human trafficking. She was promised a job in the city but hasn't been heard from since. I'm worried that she might have been trafficked for labor purposes. That is a serious concern, Cyprian. It's important that we take action quickly to ensure Elda's safety. Do you have any information on where she was supposed to be working in the city? Unfortunately, I don't have specific details about her supposed job location. But I know that she was approached by a recruiter who promised her a well-paying job in the city. Thank you for sharing that information, Cyprian. We will do everything we can to locate Elda and ensure her safety. Can you please provide me with your contact information in case we need to reach out to you for further details? Of course, my phone number is 07890 461050. Please let me know if there's anything else I can do to help find Elda. Thank you, Cyprian. Your help in this matter is greatly appreciated. We will make sure to follow up on this case and keep you informed of any developments.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Radhi speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Josphat. I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Tunduru in Ruvuma. Hello, Josphat. How can I assist you today? I'm having a problem at home. My parents are always criticizing me and making me feel small. I'm sorry to hear that, Josphat. It sounds like you're experiencing emotional and psychological abuse. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? They always tell me I'm not good enough, that I can't do anything right. It makes me feel really sad and worthless. That must be very tough for you to hear. You deserve to feel loved and supported, not constantly criticized. Have you tried talking to your parents about how their words are affecting you? I've tried, but they just get angry and say I need to toughen up. I don't know what to do anymore. It's not easy to handle situations like this on your own, Josphat. You're very brave for reaching out for help. It's important to remember that you are not alone in this. We are here to support you and help you through this difficult time. Thank you, Radhi. I feel a little better just talking to you about it. I'm glad to hear that, Josphat. Remember, it's not your fault and you deserve to be treated with kindness and respect. If you ever feel overwhelmed or need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to call us again. Is there a safe place you can go to when things get tough at home? Yes, I can go to the Bus Stand and sit there for a while to calm down. That's a good idea, Josphat. Remember to take care of yourself and reach out for help whenever you need it. You are strong and deserving of love and respect.

Hello, Child Helpline, how may I assist you today? Hi, this is Faraji. I'm 17 years old, calling from Sumbawanga Mjini in Rukwa. Hello Faraji, I'm Imani from the child helpline. How can I help you? I need some advice. I've been working at a construction site for the past few months, and I think it's exploitative. I'm sorry to hear that, Faraji. Can you tell me more about your situation? Well, I was desperate for money, so I took the job. But now I'm working long hours in unsafe conditions, and I'm not being paid fairly. That sounds like a difficult situation to be in. It's important to prioritize your safety and well-being. Have you spoken to anyone about this issue? No, I haven't. I don't know who to turn to for help. You've done the right thing by reaching out to us. Child labor is illegal and harmful to your development. We can help you navigate this situation and find a solution. Thank you, I really appreciate it. I just want to be treated fairly and have a chance to go to school like other kids my age. You deserve to have a safe and healthy environment to grow and learn in, Faraji. We will work together to address this issue and ensure your rights are protected. I feel relieved knowing that there's someone who can help me. Thank you, Imani. You're welcome, Faraji. We will do our best to support you through this challenging time. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need anything else.

Hello, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Asubuhi. I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Mtwara Vijijini. Hello Asubuhi, I'm James from the child helpline. What's on your mind today? I... I don't know who to talk to about this, but something bad happened to me. I'm here to listen, Asubuhi. You can trust me. What happened? I was talking to someone online, and they started saying things that made me feel uncomfortable. They wanted me to do things I didn't want to do. I'm so sorry to hear that, Asubuhi. No one should ever make you feel that way. It's important to tell someone when something like this happens. Have you spoken to anyone else about this? No, I was too scared. But I remembered the number for the child helpline, so I decided to call. I'm glad you called, Asubuhi. It's really brave of you to reach out for help. We can work together to make sure you stay safe. Have you heard of the Community Center in your area? Yes, I know where that is. Good. I can help you get in touch with them. They have resources and support for children who have experienced what you've been through. You don't have to go through this alone. Thank you, James. I feel a bit better knowing there's someone I can talk to about this. I'm here for you, Asubuhi. You deserve to feel safe and supported. Let's make a plan to keep you safe and get you the help you need.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Asya speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Asya, my name is Evelina. I am 13 years old and I am calling from Rorya, Mara. I have been feeling really sick lately, and I am worried about my health. I'm sorry to hear that, Evelina. Can you tell me more about what's been going on with your health? I have been feeling very weak and tired all the time. I also have been losing weight without trying to. My parents don't have much money, so we don't always have enough food to eat. I see, Evelina. It sounds like you may be experiencing some nutritional health issues. It's important to make sure you are getting the right nutrients to stay healthy. Have you talked to your parents about how you are feeling? Yes, I have told them, but they say that they are doing the best they can with what we have. I just don't know what to do anymore. I understand how difficult this must be for you, Evelina. It's important to take care of your health, especially at your age. Have you tried talking to a healthcare provider about your concerns? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to for help, so I decided to call the child helpline. I'm glad you reached out to us, Evelina. We can help connect you with resources and support in your area to address your health concerns. It's important to take care of yourself, and we are here to help you through this. Thank you for sharing your concerns with me today.

Hello, um, hi there. Can I speak to someone? I need help. Hi, this is Dada from the child helpline. You can talk to me. What's your name? My name is Frank. I'm 10 years old and I'm a boy from Mtwara Mikindani in Mtwara. Nice to meet you, Frank. How can I help you today? I've been feeling really sad lately. I don't know what to do. I've been thinking about hurting myself. I'm sorry to hear that, Frank. It's really brave of you to reach out for help. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? I just feel so alone. My parents are always fighting and I don't have any friends at school. I feel like nobody cares about me. That sounds really tough, Frank. It's important to remember that you are not alone, and there are people who care about you. Have you ever thought about hurting yourself before? Yeah, I have. Sometimes I feel like cutting myself just to make the pain go away. I'm glad you reached out to us, Frank. It's really important to talk about these feelings. Have you ever tried to hurt yourself before? No, not yet. But I don't know how much longer I can keep feeling like this. I understand, Frank. It's really important to stay safe. Have you heard about the District Hospital in your area? They have professionals who can help you with your feelings. Yes, I know where it is. Do you think they can really help me? I believe they can, Frank. It's important to talk to someone about how you've been feeling. Would you like me to help you make an appointment at the hospital? Yes, please. I want to feel better. Thank you for listening to me. You're welcome, Frank. Remember, you are not alone in this. We are here to support you. Let's make sure you get the help you need.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Yahya speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Yahya, my name is Avelina, I'm 13 years old and I'm from Unguja Kaskazini B in Kaskazini Unguja. I'm calling because I need help with something. Of course, Avelina. What can I assist you with today? Well, recently there was a big storm in my village, and it caused a lot of damage to our homes and crops. Many families have lost everything, and it's been really difficult for us to recover. I'm so sorry to hear that, Avelina. Natural disasters can be really tough to deal with. Have you and your family been able to get any support or assistance? Some organizations have come to provide us with food and temporary shelter, but we still need help rebuilding our homes and replanting our crops. It's been hard for us to move forward from this. I understand how overwhelming this situation must be for you and your community. It's important to reach out for help during times like these. Have you spoken to any local authorities or organizations about your needs? Yes, we have, but the resources are limited, and there are so many families in need. I just don't know where else to turn for help. Don't worry, Avelina. We can work together to find more resources and support for you and your community. I will connect you with organizations that specialize in disaster recovery and rebuilding efforts. You are not alone in this, and we will do everything we can to help you through this difficult time. Thank you so much, Yahya. I really appreciate your help and support. It means a lot to me and my family.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Raya speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Constantine. I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Longido, Arusha. I don't know what to do, I need help. I'm here to listen, Constantine. What's been going on? My parents recently got divorced, and ever since then, my dad has been coming to our house and yelling at my mom. He gets really angry and sometimes he hits her. I'm scared for my mom and for myself. I'm so sorry to hear that, Constantine. It's not right for anyone to be treated like that. Have you talked to anyone about this before? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to or where to go for help. But I heard about the child helpline and I decided to give it a try. I'm glad you reached out, Constantine. You did the right thing by seeking help. No one deserves to live in fear or be subjected to violence. Have you talked to your mom about what's been happening? Yes, I have. She's scared too, but she doesn't know what to do. She's afraid of what my dad might do if she tries to stop him. It's important for both you and your mom to stay safe, Constantine. I can connect you with local services that can help provide support and guidance in this situation. Is there a safe place you can go to if things escalate at home? There's a bus stand nearby where I can go if things get out of hand. Thank you for listening and for offering to help, Raya. I feel a little better already knowing that there are people out there who care.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Adelaida, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Adelina. I'm 13 years old and I'm from Nachingwea, Lindi. I have some questions about sexual health and my identity. Of course, Adelina. I'm here to help. What specifically would you like to know? Well, I've been feeling confused lately about my sexual identity. I don't know if I like boys or girls, and it's been bothering me. It's completely normal to have questions about your sexual identity, Adelina. It's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique and there's no rush to figure everything out right away. Have you talked to anyone else about these feelings? No, I haven't. I don't know who to talk to about it. I'm scared of being judged or not understood. I understand your concerns, Adelina. It's great that you reached out to us here at the child helpline. We are here to provide support and guidance without judgment. It's important to remember that your feelings are valid, and you have the right to explore your identity in a safe and supportive environment. Thank you, Adelaida. I feel a bit better talking to you about this. Can you give me some advice on how to understand my feelings better? Of course, Adelina. It's important to take your time and explore your feelings at your own pace. You can also consider talking to a trusted adult, a counselor, or a healthcare provider for additional support. Remember, you are not alone in this journey, and there are resources available to help you navigate your feelings and questions about sexual identity. Thank you so much, Adelaida. I feel more hopeful now. I will definitely consider reaching out to someone for further support. I'm glad I could help, Adelina. Remember, you are strong and brave for reaching out. If you have any more questions or need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to contact us again. Take care of yourself.

Hello, how can I help you today? Hi there, I'm Jon. I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Manyoni, Singida. Nice to meet you, Jon. I'm Dionisia from the child helpline. What seems to be the problem today? Well, I'm really scared because there's been a big storm here and our house got damaged. I don't know what to do. I'm sorry to hear that, Jon. It must have been really scary for you. Are you and your family safe? Yes, we're all okay, but our house is in bad shape. We don't have anywhere to sleep tonight. I understand how stressful that must be. Have you been able to contact any emergency services for help? No, we don't have a phone that works right now. That's why I called you. I'm glad you reached out to us, Jon. I can help connect you with the local authorities who can provide assistance in situations like this. Can you tell me more about the damage to your house? The roof is leaking and some of the walls are cracked. It's not safe for us to stay there. Okay, Jon. I will make sure to get in touch with the right people to help you and your family. In the meantime, try to stay calm and stay together with your family. Thank you, Dionisia. I really appreciate your help. I was so worried about what we were going to do. You're welcome, Jon. That's what we're here for. Remember, you can always call us if you need anything else. Stay safe.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, it is. My name is Faraji. How can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Mwipopo. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Chemba, Dodoma. Nice to meet you, Mwipopo. How can I help you today? I'm calling because I feel like I'm being neglected at home. My parents are always busy with work and they don't spend much time with me. I'm sorry to hear that, Mwipopo. Can you tell me more about what's been happening at home? Well, my parents are always working late, and when they are home, they are always tired and don't have time for me. I have to make my own meals and do my homework alone. That sounds really tough, Mwipopo. It's important for parents to spend time with their children and make sure they are taken care of. Have you tried talking to your parents about how you feel? I've tried, but they always say they are too busy with work and that I should be more independent. But I feel lonely and neglected. I understand, Mwipopo. It's not easy to feel neglected and alone. You deserve to feel loved and supported. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to talk to until I found this helpline number. I'm glad you reached out, Mwipopo. You can always talk to us whenever you need to. We are here to support you. Would you like me to provide you with some resources or guidance on how to address this issue with your parents? Yes, please. That would be helpful. Thank you for listening to me, Faraji. You're welcome, Mwipopo. Remember, you deserve to feel safe and cared for. If you ever need to talk, you can always reach out to us at the child helpline. Take care.

Hello, thank you for calling the Child Helpline. This is Sakina speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Sakina, my name is Stella and I'm 10 years old. I'm calling from Bukoba Vijijini in Kagera. Nice to meet you, Stella. What's on your mind today? I've been feeling really stressed and anxious lately. My family is going through a lot of instability and it's really affecting me. I'm sorry to hear that, Stella. It must be tough for you. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? My parents have been arguing a lot and my dad hasn't been coming home much. I'm worried about what will happen to our family. It's understandable that you're feeling anxious in this situation. It's important to remember that it's not your fault and you deserve to feel safe and supported. I just don't know what to do. I feel like everything is falling apart. It's okay to feel that way, Stella. It's important to talk about your feelings and find ways to cope with the stress. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling? Not really. I didn't know who to turn to. But I'm glad I called the helpline. I'm glad you did too, Stella. Remember, you're not alone in this. There are people who care about you and want to help. Have you thought about talking to a trusted adult or a teacher about what's going on? I haven't, but I think I will. Thank you for listening to me, Sakina. You're welcome, Stella. Remember, you can always call us whenever you need someone to talk to. Take care of yourself, okay? Thank you, Sakina. Goodbye. Goodbye, Stella. Take care.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Etana from the child helpline. How can I help you today? My name is Alfajiri, I'm 14 years old, and I'm from Wete, Kaskazini Pemba. I'm calling because I need help with something. Of course, Alfajiri. What's going on? I've been experiencing gender discrimination at home and in my community. My parents treat me and my sisters differently just because we're girls. They don't give us the same opportunities as my brothers. I'm sorry to hear that, Alfajiri. Gender discrimination is never okay. Have you talked to anyone about this before? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I heard about the child helpline. I'm glad you reached out to us. It's important to speak up about these issues. You have the right to be treated equally regardless of your gender. Have you faced any other forms of gender-based violence? Sometimes I hear people in my community making hurtful comments about girls and women. It makes me feel like I'm not valued just because of my gender. That sounds really tough, Alfajiri. You deserve to be respected and treated with dignity. It's important to stand up against gender discrimination and violence. We can help you find ways to address this issue and support you through this difficult time. Thank you, Etana. I feel better knowing that I'm not alone in this. I want to make a change in my community and fight against gender discrimination. That's great to hear, Alfajiri. We're here to support you every step of the way. Remember, you have the right to be treated equally and with respect. Don't hesitate to reach out to us whenever you need help or guidance. Thank you, Etana. I appreciate your support.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Caleb, how can I help you today? Hi Caleb, my name is Christina. I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Bagamoyo, Pwani. I need help with something really important. Of course, Christina. What seems to be the issue? I think my educational rights are being denied. I've been trying to go to school, but my parents keep telling me that I need to stay home and help with household chores instead. I'm sorry to hear that, Christina. Every child has the right to education. Have you tried talking to your parents about your desire to go to school? Yes, I've tried talking to them multiple times, but they just won't listen to me. They say that I don't need to go to school because I'm a girl and my place is at home. I understand how frustrating that must be for you. It's important for you to know that as a child, you have the right to access education and pursue your dreams. Have you spoken to anyone at your school or in your community about this issue? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to for help. That's why I decided to call the child helpline. I'm glad you reached out to us, Christina. We are here to support you and help you access your rights. I will connect you with our legal team who can provide you with further assistance on this matter. Is that okay with you? Yes, that would be great. Thank you so much, Caleb.

Hey, is this the child helpline? I need someone to talk to. Hello, I'm Alice from the child helpline. How can I help you today? My name is Hussein, I'm 13 years old and I'm calling from Sengerema, Mwanza. I've been feeling really stressed out lately because of some things happening at school. What's been going on, Hussein? Well, my friends have been pressuring me to cheat on tests and copy their homework. They say it's no big deal and everyone does it, but I know it's wrong. I don't want to get in trouble. I'm glad you reached out for help, Hussein. It's important to stand up for what you believe is right, even if others are pressuring you to do something different. Have you talked to anyone at school about this? No, I haven't. I'm scared they won't believe me or that my friends will get mad at me. It's understandable to feel that way, but it's important to prioritize your own values and integrity. Academic dishonesty can have serious consequences and it's important to make the right choices, even if it's difficult. Have you thought about talking to a teacher or counselor at school about what's been going on? I haven't, but I think I will. I don't want this pressure to keep affecting me. Thank you for listening and giving me advice, Alice. You're welcome, Hussein. Remember, you can always reach out to us at the child helpline if you need someone to talk to. And if you ever feel overwhelmed, you can also visit the Central Hospital for support. Take care of yourself and stay strong in your values.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Cornelius from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi Cornelius, my name is Leila. I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Iramba, Singida. Nice to meet you, Leila. How are you feeling today? I've been feeling really anxious and stressed lately. I don't know what to do. I'm sorry to hear that, Leila. Can you tell me more about what's been making you feel this way? Well, my parents are planning to go to Dar es Salaam for a few days, and I'm really scared to be away from them. I have separation anxiety. It's totally normal to feel anxious about being away from your parents, Leila. Have you talked to them about how you're feeling? Yes, I have. They've tried to reassure me that everything will be okay, but I just can't shake this feeling of dread. It's okay to feel this way, Leila. Have you tried any coping mechanisms to help manage your anxiety? I've been trying to take deep breaths and distract myself with activities I enjoy, but it's been really hard. I'm glad to hear that you're trying to help yourself, Leila. Have you thought about talking to a school counselor or a trusted adult about how you're feeling? Not really, but maybe I should. Do you think that would help? It could definitely be beneficial to have someone to talk to about your feelings, Leila. Remember, it's important to take care of yourself and reach out for support when you need it. Is there anything else you'd like to discuss? Thank you, Cornelius. I feel a bit better now. I'll try talking to someone about my anxiety.

Hello, thank you for calling the Child Helpline. This is Filbert, how can I assist you today? Hi Filbert, my name is Enzi. I'm 47 years old and I'm calling about a child named Angolwisye from Ulanga, Morogoro. Thank you for sharing that information, Enzi. How can I help with Angolwisye's situation? I'm really worried about Angolwisye. I found out that he has been having suicidal thoughts and has been engaging in self-harm as a way to cope. That's a serious concern, Enzi. It's important that we address this issue immediately. Can you tell me more about Angolwisye's behavior and what has led him to feel this way? Well, Angolwisye has been going through a lot of challenges at home and at school. His parents are always fighting and he's been having trouble with bullying at school. He feels overwhelmed and doesn't know how to cope. I'm sorry to hear that Angolwisye is going through such difficult times. It's understandable that he may be feeling overwhelmed. It's important that we provide him with the necessary support and guidance. Can you tell me if there are any specific triggers that lead him to have suicidal thoughts or engage in self-harm? One of the triggers seems to be the constant fighting between his parents. It makes him feel helpless and he resorts to self-harm as a way to cope with the emotional pain. It's important for Angolwisye to know that he is not alone and that there are people who care about him. We can work together to ensure that he receives the support and help he needs. I suggest that we involve his parents and school in this process as well. Let's make a plan to ensure his safety and well-being. Enzi, can you help us in getting Angolwisye to the nearest Bus Stand, where we can arrange for him to be taken to a safe place for further assistance?

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Sarah speaking. How can I help you today? Hi Sarah, my name is Basilisa. I'm 11 years old, and I'm calling from Bariadi, Shinyanga. I wanted to talk to someone about natural disasters and accidents. Of course, Basilisa. I'm here to listen. What specifically about natural disasters or accidents would you like to discuss? Well, recently there was a big flood in my town, and it caused a lot of damage to homes and crops. Many families lost everything they had, and it's been really hard for everyone here. I'm so sorry to hear that, Basilisa. It must be a very difficult time for you and your community. Have you been personally affected by the flood? Yes, my family's home was damaged, and we had to move to a temporary shelter. It's been tough to adjust to our new living situation, and I'm worried about what will happen next. I can imagine how stressful and overwhelming that must be for you. It's important to remember that it's okay to feel scared or upset during times like this. Have you been able to talk to anyone about how you're feeling? Not really. I've been trying to stay strong for my family, but it's been hard to keep my feelings to myself. I just don't know what to do next or where to turn for help. It's okay to feel overwhelmed, Basilisa. You're not alone in this. There are resources available to support you and your family during this difficult time. Have you considered reaching out to the local authorities or organizations for assistance? I haven't thought about that, but maybe I could go to the police station and ask for help. Thank you for listening to me, Sarah. It feels good to talk about how I'm feeling. You're welcome, Basilisa. Remember, it's important to take care of yourself during times of crisis. Don't hesitate to reach out for support whenever you need it. We're here for you.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Alamisi speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Alamisi, my name is Lydia. I'm calling about my son, Constantine. He's 12 years old and we live in Nkansi, Rukwa. I'm really worried about him. What seems to be the problem, Lydia? I think Constantine is getting involved in some risky behavior. His friends have been pressuring him to do things that I know he shouldn't be doing at his age. Can you give me some examples of what kind of risky behavior he's getting into? I recently found out that Constantine and his friends have been sneaking out at night and hanging out with older kids. I'm afraid they might be getting involved in things like drugs or even sexual activities. That does sound concerning. Have you spoken to Constantine about this? Yes, I have tried talking to him, but he just brushes it off and says I'm overreacting. I don't know what else to do. It's important to address these issues before they escalate. Have you considered talking to Constantine's school or seeking help from a counselor? I haven't thought about that. I just didn't know where to turn for help. Thank you for suggesting that. I will definitely reach out to his school and see if they can offer any support. That's a good step to take, Lydia. Remember, you're not alone in this. Feel free to call us back if you need further assistance or guidance.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Valentina, how can I help you today? Hi, Valentina. My name is Neema, I'm 13 years old and I'm calling from Kibiti, Pwani. Nice to meet you, Neema. How can I assist you today? I'm feeling really scared and confused. My friend has been pressuring me to do things I'm not comfortable with. I'm sorry to hear that, Neema. Can you tell me more about what your friend is asking you to do? He keeps asking me to do things of a sexual nature, like touching him inappropriately and sending him explicit pictures. I've told him I'm not comfortable with it, but he won't stop. I'm so sorry you're going through this, Neema. It's important to remember that you have the right to say no to anything that makes you uncomfortable. Have you tried talking to anyone else about this? No, I haven't. I was too scared to tell anyone. But I knew I had to talk to someone, so I called the helpline. I'm glad you reached out, Neema. It's important to speak up when you're feeling uncomfortable or unsafe. We can help you figure out a plan to handle this situation. Would you like to talk about some options? Yes, please. I don't want this to continue, but I don't know what to do. We can explore different ways to address this issue, whether it's talking to someone you trust, seeking help from a counselor, or even involving the authorities if necessary. You're not alone in this, Neema.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Aziza speaking, how can I assist you today? Hello Aziza, my name is Etana. I am a 52-year-old male from Missenyi, Kagera. I am calling about my niece, Eveline, who is 14 years old. I have some concerns about her growth and development. I'm glad you reached out, Etana. Could you tell me more about Eveline's current situation? Well, she has always been a picky eater and I'm worried that she is not getting the proper nutrition she needs for her age. She seems to be smaller than other children her age and I'm concerned about her health and development. I understand your concerns, Etana. It's important to ensure that Eveline is getting the right nutrients for her growth. Have you tried speaking to a healthcare provider about her nutrition needs? Yes, we have visited the local health center before, but I still feel unsure about what exactly she needs in terms of her diet. I want to make sure she is getting everything she needs to grow and develop properly. I'm glad you are taking proactive steps to address this issue, Etana. It might be helpful to consult with a nutritionist or a healthcare provider who specializes in child nutrition. They can provide you with guidance on Eveline's specific dietary needs. Thank you, Aziza. I will look into finding a nutritionist or healthcare provider who can help us with Eveline's nutrition needs. I appreciate your guidance on this matter. You're welcome, Etana. If you have any more questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out to us at the child helpline. Our phone number is +255 6824 365365. Take care and best of luck with Eveline's nutrition journey.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Betina, how can I assist you today? Hi Betina, my name is Mariana. I'm calling about a child named Buyu, he's 9 years old and he's from Liwale, Lindi. Nice to meet you, Mariana. How can I help you with Buyu today? I have some questions about Buyu's feeding practices. I want to make sure he's getting the right nutrition. Of course, that's very important. What specific questions do you have about Buyu's feeding practices? Well, Buyu is a picky eater and I'm struggling to get him to eat balanced meals. Do you have any tips on how to encourage him to eat healthier? I understand your concern. It can be challenging when children are picky eaters. Have you tried involving Buyu in meal preparation or offering him a variety of food choices? Yes, I've tried that but it hasn't been very successful. Buyu tends to just eat the same few things over and over again. It's common for children to have food preferences, but it's important to ensure they're getting the nutrients they need. Have you considered consulting a nutritionist for personalized advice on Buyu's diet? I haven't thought about that, but it sounds like a good idea. Can you recommend any nutritionists in the Liwale area? I can provide you with a list of nutritionists in your area. It's important to seek professional advice to ensure Buyu's nutritional needs are being met. Thank you for reaching out, Mariana, and I hope you find the support you need for Buyu's health and well-being.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Debora speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Debora, my name is Azize and I am calling about a child named Hafsa. She is 15 years old and she lives in Singida Vijijini, Singida. Thank you for providing that information, Azize. What seems to be the issue regarding Hafsa? Well, Debora, the issue is that Hafsa is living in a home where there is substance abuse. Her parents are struggling with alcoholism, and it is affecting her greatly. I'm sorry to hear that, Azize. It must be very challenging for Hafsa to cope with such a situation. Have you noticed any specific ways in which this is impacting her? Yes, Debora. Hafsa has been feeling neglected and isolated. She often talks about feeling scared and unsure about her future. She has also mentioned that her parents' behavior when they are under the influence of alcohol is causing her a lot of distress. It's important that Hafsa has someone to talk to about these feelings and experiences. Have you tried talking to her parents about their alcoholism and its impact on Hafsa? I have tried, but they are not receptive to feedback and refuse to acknowledge the problem. I am worried about Hafsa's well-being and I feel like she needs professional help to cope with this situation. Thank you for reaching out, Azize. We can connect Hafsa with counselors and support services that can help her navigate this difficult situation. It's important to prioritize her safety and well-being. Would you like me to provide you with more information on how we can assist Hafsa? Yes, please, Debora. I want to do everything I can to support Hafsa during this challenging time. Thank you for your help.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Milka speaking. How can I help you today? Hi Milka, my name is Akuji. I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Mpwapwa in Dodoma. Nice to meet you, Akuji. What seems to be troubling you today? I've been having some issues with my friends at school. They've been excluding me from activities and it's really been getting to me. I'm sorry to hear that, Akuji. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, we used to be really close and do everything together. But lately, they've been leaving me out of things and not inviting me to hang out with them. That sounds tough, Akuji. Have you tried talking to them about how you're feeling? I did try to bring it up once, but they just brushed it off. I feel like they don't value our friendship anymore. It's important to communicate your feelings, Akuji. Maybe you could try talking to them again and expressing how their actions are affecting you. I'll try that, Milka. Thank you for the advice. I just don't want to lose my friends, but I also don't want to be constantly left out. It's understandable, Akuji. Remember, true friends will listen to your concerns and work together to find a solution. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about? No, that's all for now. Thank you for listening, Milka. I feel a bit better after talking to you. I'm glad I could help, Akuji. Remember, you can always call us if you need someone to talk to. Take care of yourself. Thank you, Milka. Goodbye.

Hello, is this the child helpline? I need help. Yes, this is Bakari from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? My name is Asukile, I am a 10-year-old boy from Kondoa, Dodoma. I am facing a problem at home. I'm sorry to hear that, Asukile. Can you tell me more about what's going on? My parents are always fighting and they don't pay attention to me. They never help me with my schoolwork or ask about my day. It sounds like you are feeling neglected, Asukile. I'm here to listen and support you. Have you tried talking to your parents about how you feel? Yes, but they just brush me off and tell me to figure things out on my own. I understand how frustrating that must be for you. It's important for parents to support their children, especially with their education. Have you spoken to a teacher or another adult you trust about what's going on at home? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I found this helpline number. I'm glad you reached out, Asukile. You deserve to feel loved and supported. I want to help you figure out a solution to this neglect. Would you like me to connect you with a local organization that can provide support for you and your family? Yes, please. I just want things to get better at home. Thank you for listening, Bakari. You're welcome, Asukile. I'm here for you whenever you need someone to talk to. Remember, you are not alone in this. We will work together to make things better for you.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline, this is Rahel speaking. How can I help you today? Hi Rahel, my name is Gloria and I am 10 years old. I'm calling from Musoma Mjini in Mara. Nice to meet you, Gloria. What seems to be on your mind today? I've been feeling really sad and lonely lately. My parents got divorced a few months ago, and it's been really hard on me. I'm sorry to hear that, Gloria. It's completely normal to feel sad after such a major life change. Have you been able to talk to anyone about how you're feeling? Not really. I don't want to burden my mom with my feelings because I know she's going through a tough time too. And my friends don't really understand what I'm going through. It's important to remember that it's okay to feel sad and to reach out for help when you need it. Talking about your feelings can help you feel better. Have you tried any activities that usually make you happy? I used to love playing soccer, but I haven't felt like doing anything lately. It's like I've lost interest in everything. It's understandable that you may not feel like doing the things you used to enjoy right now. But it's important to try and find ways to take care of yourself during this tough time. Would you be interested in talking to a counselor or therapist about how you're feeling? I think that might help. I just don't know where to start. I can help you find a counselor in your area who can provide you with the support you need. Remember, you're not alone in this, Gloria. It's okay to ask for help and to take care of yourself.

Hello, good afternoon. My name is Mwalimu, I am calling about a child named Helena. She is 13 years old and she lives in Kati Unguja, Kusini Unguja. Hello, Mwalimu. This is Lydia from the child helpline. How can I assist you today regarding Helena? Well, Helena recently lost both of her parents in a tragic accident. She is now left all alone and struggling to cope with the loss. She has no other family members to turn to for support. I am so sorry to hear about Helena's situation. Losing both parents at such a young age must be incredibly difficult for her. Is she receiving any support or assistance from the community? Unfortunately, the community is also struggling to provide the necessary support for Helena. She is feeling abandoned and lost, and I am concerned about her well-being. It is important for Helena to receive the support she needs during this difficult time. We can work together to explore options for her care and well-being. Is there any specific assistance or resources that Helena may need at the moment? She may need counseling to help her process her grief and emotions. Additionally, she may require assistance with basic needs such as food, shelter, and education. Is there any way the child helpline can assist in connecting Helena with these resources? Yes, we can definitely help in connecting Helena with counseling services and other resources to support her. Thank you for reaching out and providing this important information. We will do our best to ensure Helena receives the care and assistance she needs during this challenging time.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Etana speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Conrad. I'm 13 years old, and I'm calling from Moshi Mjini in Kilimanjaro. I'm feeling really stressed about school. Hey Conrad, nice to meet you. Can you tell me more about what's going on? Well, I have so much pressure to do well in school. My parents and teachers expect me to get good grades, but I'm struggling to keep up. I'm worried about my future and what will happen if I don't succeed. I hear you, Conrad. It sounds like you're feeling a lot of stress and anxiety about your academics. It's okay to feel overwhelmed sometimes. Have you talked to anyone about how you're feeling? Not really. I don't want to disappoint my parents, so I keep all my worries to myself. It's important to remember that it's okay to ask for help when you need it. Your parents and teachers care about you and want to support you. Have you thought about talking to them about how you're feeling? I guess I haven't really considered that. I just feel like I have to figure everything out on my own. It's normal to feel that way, but it's also important to remember that you're not alone. Talking to someone you trust can help you feel better and come up with a plan to manage your stress. Would you like some tips on how to start that conversation? Yes, that would be really helpful. Thank you, Etana. I feel a little better already just talking to you.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Luciana, how can I help you today? Hi Luciana, my name is Debora, I'm 17 years old and I'm calling from Kusini Unguja. I'm feeling really lost and I don't know what to do. I'm sorry to hear that, Debora. Can you tell me a bit more about what's going on? I've been having these thoughts lately, you know, about not wanting to be here anymore. I feel like nobody understands me, and I don't see a way out. It sounds like you're going through a really tough time. Have you been feeling like this for a while? Yeah, it's been building up for a few months now. I just don't know how to handle everything anymore. I'm glad you reached out to us, Debora. It takes a lot of courage to talk about these feelings. Have you ever thought about hurting yourself? Sometimes, I've been cutting myself as a way to cope with all the emotions. It helps me feel something, you know? I'm sorry to hear that you're using self-harm as a way to cope. It's important to find healthier ways to deal with your emotions. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling? No, I haven't really had anyone to talk to about this. I feel like I'm all alone in this. You're not alone, Debora. We're here to support you and help you through this difficult time. Have you thought about speaking to a counselor or therapist about what you're going through? I haven't, but maybe it's time I do. Thank you for listening to me, Luciana. It feels good to finally talk about it. I'm glad you called, Debora. Remember, there are people who care about you and want to help. You can always reach out to us whenever you need someone to talk to.

Hello, child helpline, this is Angaza speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Tefo. I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Kwimba, Mwanza. Nice to meet you, Tefo. What seems to be the problem? I've been experiencing physical abuse at home. My parents have been using corporal punishment on me, but lately, it's been escalating. I'm sorry to hear that, Tefo. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, it started with just a few spankings here and there for small things, but now it's gotten to the point where they're hitting me with belts and sticks. It's really starting to hurt, both physically and emotionally. That sounds really tough, Tefo. No one should have to go through that. Have you tried talking to your parents about how you feel? I've tried, but they just say it's for my own good and that I deserve it for misbehaving. I see. It's important for you to know that you don't deserve to be hurt, no matter what. Have you thought about reaching out for help before? I didn't know where to turn, but I remembered seeing the child helpline number on a poster near Main Road, so I decided to give it a try. I'm glad you did, Tefo. You've taken a brave step in seeking help. We can work together to find a solution and ensure your safety. Have you thought about any options for your immediate safety? I haven't, but I'm willing to explore them with your help. Great, Tefo. Let's work together to ensure your safety and well-being. You're not alone in this, and we're here to support you every step of the way.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Cyrus speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Cyrus, my name is Lydia and I'm 17 years old. I'm calling from Mbulu, Manyara. Nice to meet you Lydia. How can I help you today? I have some questions about sexual health education. I feel like I don't know enough about it and I want to learn more. That's great that you want to learn more about sexual health. It's important to have the right information. What specifically would you like to know? I want to know more about safe sex practices, consent, and how to protect myself from sexually transmitted infections. Those are important topics, Lydia. It's great that you're taking the initiative to educate yourself. Have you received any sexual health education in school or from any other sources? Not really, we haven't had much education on sexual health in school and my parents don't talk about it much either. I see. It's important to have access to accurate information about sexual health. Would you like me to provide you with some resources or information on where you can learn more about these topics? Yes, that would be really helpful. Thank you, Cyrus. Of course, Lydia. I can provide you with some resources and information on sexual health education. If you have any more questions or need further assistance, feel free to call us back at 06353 692309. Thank you so much, Cyrus. I really appreciate your help. You're welcome, Lydia. Take care and stay safe.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Nelly, I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Gairo, Morogoro. Hello Nelly, I'm Sadiki from the child helpline. What seems to be the problem? I think I might be in danger of human trafficking. I've been approached by some people offering me a job in the city, but I'm not sure if it's safe. That sounds concerning, Nelly. Can you tell me more about what they said to you? They told me that they could provide me with a job in the city that pays well, but I have to leave my family and follow them. Have you spoken to anyone else about this, Nelly? No, I haven't. I'm not sure who I can trust and I don't want to put my family in danger. It's good that you called us, Nelly. Human trafficking is a serious issue and it's important to protect yourself. Do you have a safe place to stay? Yes, I'm currently at home with my family. But I'm worried that these people might come looking for me. I understand your concerns, Nelly. It's important to stay safe and not to trust strangers who promise you things that seem too good to be true. Have you thought about talking to the local authorities about this? I haven't, but I will definitely consider it. Thank you for your help, Sadiki. You're welcome, Nelly. Remember, you can always call us if you need further assistance or support. Take care and stay safe.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Fabiola speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Gift, I'm 16 years old, and I'm calling from Musoma Mjini in Mara. I'm feeling really overwhelmed with school right now. Hey Gift, it's okay, you're not alone in feeling that way. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? Well, my parents have really high expectations for my grades, especially in math and science. They always compare me to my older siblings who were top students in school. I feel like I'm constantly under pressure to perform well. I'm sorry to hear that, Gift. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of academic pressure. Have you tried talking to your parents about how you're feeling? I've tried, but they just tell me to work harder and study more. It's like they don't understand how stressed out I am. I feel like I'm not good enough no matter how hard I try. It's important for your parents to understand how their expectations are affecting you. Have you considered talking to a teacher or school counselor about how you're feeling? I haven't thought about that, but maybe it's worth a try. I just feel so lost and overwhelmed, especially with exams coming up soon. Gift, it's important to remember that your worth is not defined by your grades. It's okay to ask for help and support when you need it. You're not alone in this. Have you ever visited the River Bridge in Musoma Mjini? It's a peaceful spot that might help you clear your mind. Thank you, Fabiola. I'll try talking to a teacher and maybe visit the River Bridge to relax. I appreciate your help and support.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Enzi, how can I help you today? Hey, Enzi. My name is Darweshi, I'm 16 years old, and I'm calling from Muheza, Tanga. Nice to meet you, Darweshi. What seems to be the problem? Well, it's about my family. My dad has been drinking a lot lately, and it's causing a lot of problems at home. I'm sorry to hear that, Darweshi. How has his drinking been affecting you and your family? It's been really tough. He's always angry and yelling, and sometimes he even gets violent. My mom and I are scared all the time. And he spends all our money on alcohol, so we don't have enough for food or other things we need. That sounds really difficult, Darweshi. It's important to remember that none of this is your fault. Have you talked to anyone else about what's been happening at home? I haven't really told anyone. I didn't know who to talk to. But I just can't take it anymore, Enzi. I don't know what to do. It's brave of you to reach out for help, Darweshi. You deserve to feel safe and supported. We can help you find resources to support you and your family, and we can also talk about ways to stay safe in the meantime. Would you like me to connect you with a counselor or social worker who can help you further? Yes, please. I really need help. Thank you, Enzi.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Blandina speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Sarki. I'm 17 years old and I'm calling from Kilolo, Iringa. Nice to meet you, Sarki. What's on your mind today? I... I don't really know how to say this, but I think I've been a victim of sexual abuse. I'm so sorry to hear that, Sarki. Can you tell me a bit more about what happened? Well, it's not like someone forced themselves on me or anything like that. It's more like... my friends have been pressuring me into doing things I'm not comfortable with. That sounds really tough, Sarki. Can you give me some examples of what they've been pressuring you to do? They keep pushing me to go further with girls, even when I tell them I'm not ready. And if I refuse, they make fun of me and call me names. It's important to remember that you have the right to say no to anything that makes you uncomfortable, Sarki. No one has the right to pressure you into doing something you don't want to do. I know, but it's hard when it feels like everyone around me is doing it. I feel like I'm being left out if I don't go along with it. It's completely understandable to feel that way, Sarki. But remember, your well-being and comfort should always come first. Have you talked to anyone else about what you're going through? No, this is the first time I've really opened up about it. I just didn't know who to turn to. I'm glad you reached out to us, Sarki. We're here to support you and help you through this. Would you like to talk more about what you're going through or explore some options for how to handle the situation with your friends? Yes, that would be really helpful. Thank you so much, Blandina.

Hello, Child Helpline. How can I help you today? Hi there, this is Vinza. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Rorya, Mara. Hello Vinza, I'm Bahari from the child helpline. What seems to be the issue today? I think I made a mistake. I called the helpline as a prank to see if it was real, but now I feel bad about it. It's okay, Vinza. It's important to know that the helpline is here to help children with real problems. Prank calling can tie up the line for children who really need help. I know, I didn't think about that before. I just wanted to see if someone would actually answer. It's understandable, but it's important to remember that the helpline is a resource for children who are in trouble or need someone to talk to. Prank calling can take away from those who need it most. I didn't realize how serious it was. I'm sorry for wasting your time. Thank you for apologizing, Vinza. It takes courage to admit when we've made a mistake. Just remember for next time that the helpline is here for those who need it most. I will, thank you for explaining it to me. I won't prank call again. That's great to hear, Vinza. If you ever have a real problem or need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to give us a call. We're here to help. Thank you, Bahari. I appreciate your understanding and I won't make this mistake again.

Hello, is this the child helpline? I need to talk to someone. Yes, this is Kamili from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi Kamili, my name is Geni. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Newala, Mtwara. I have a question about sexual and reproductive health. Of course, Geni. I'm here to listen and help. What specifically would you like to talk about? Well, I have noticed some changes in my body recently and I'm not sure what they mean. I have started getting my period, but I don't really understand what is happening. It's completely normal to have questions about your body and what you are experiencing, Geni. Getting your period is a natural part of growing up and becoming a young woman. Have you talked to anyone about this before? No, I haven't. I feel a bit embarrassed to talk to my parents about it. I was hoping I could get some information and advice from someone else. I'm glad you reached out to us, Geni. It's important to have someone to talk to about these things. I can explain to you what is happening to your body and answer any questions you may have about your period and reproductive health. Thank you, Kamili. I feel better already knowing that I can talk to someone about this. Can you please tell me more about what to expect with my period and how to take care of myself during this time? Of course, Geni. Let's start by discussing the menstrual cycle and how you can manage your period.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Rhoda speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Natori. I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Mbeya Vijijini in Mbeya. Nice to meet you, Natori. What seems to be the problem today? I've been feeling really tired lately, and my stomach hurts a lot. I'm sorry to hear that, Natori. Have you been eating well and getting enough sleep? I try to eat my vegetables, but sometimes I don't feel like eating much. And I have trouble sleeping because I keep thinking about things. It sounds like your mental health might be affecting your physical health, Natori. Have you been feeling sad or worried about something? Yeah, I miss my dad a lot. He's been working in another town for a long time, and I don't get to see him often. It's completely normal to miss someone you love, Natori. But it's important to take care of yourself too. Have you talked to anyone about how you're feeling? Not really. I didn't want to bother my mom because she's always busy with work. It's not a bother, Natori. Your mom loves you and wants to help you feel better. Maybe you can talk to her about how you've been feeling and she can help you figure out a way to feel better. Okay, I'll try talking to her. Thank you, Rhoda. You're welcome, Natori. Remember, it's important to take care of both your mental and physical health. Don't hesitate to call us back if you need more help. Take care.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Sanyu. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Peter. I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Mjini Unguja, Mjini Magharibi. Nice to meet you, Peter. What seems to be the issue today? Well, I have a friend who ran away from home a few days ago. He hasn't come back, and I'm really worried about him. I'm sorry to hear that, Peter. It's important to take missing children seriously. Have you talked to anyone about this? Your parents, teachers, or the police? No, I haven't. I didn't think anyone would listen to me. It's important to speak up, Peter. Your friend's safety is at stake. We can help you get in touch with the authorities to report a missing child. It's not safe for children to be out on their own. I know, but my friend doesn't want to go back home. He said he's scared of his parents. I understand, Peter. It's important to address the underlying issues that led to your friend running away. We can connect you with counselors who can help both your friend and his family work through their problems. Thank you, Sanyu. I didn't know there were people who could help like this. I just want my friend to be safe. You're doing the right thing, Peter. It takes courage to speak up and seek help. We're here for you and your friend. Let's work together to ensure his safety and well-being. Thank you, Sanyu. I feel better knowing that there are people who care.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Zuberi, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Japhet, I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Nzega, Tabora. Nice to meet you, Japhet. What seems to be the issue you're facing today? I feel like I'm being neglected when it comes to my education. My parents don't seem to care about my schoolwork or how I'm doing in class. I'm sorry to hear that, Japhet. Education is really important. Have you tried talking to your parents about how you feel? Yes, but they just brush it off and tell me to focus on my own studies. That must be really frustrating. Have you tried talking to a teacher or a school counselor about this? I haven't, I didn't know who to turn to for help. It's good that you reached out to us. We can help you figure out a plan to address this neglect. Education is your right, and we want to make sure you have the support you need to succeed in school. Would you like us to contact your school to discuss your concerns? Yes, that would be really helpful. Thank you so much for listening to me and offering to help. Of course, Japhet. We're here to support you. Remember, you have the right to a good education and we'll do our best to make sure that happens. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about or any other way we can assist you? No, that's all for now. Thank you for your support, Zuberi. You're welcome, Japhet. Take care and don't hesitate to call us if you need anything else.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Claudia, how can I help you today? Hi Claudia, my name is Rosemary. I'm 13 years old and I'm from Temeke, Dar es Salaam. Hi Rosemary, it's nice to meet you. How are you feeling today? I'm not doing so well, Claudia. I've been feeling really sad and hopeless lately. I've been having thoughts of hurting myself. I'm really sorry to hear that, Rosemary. It takes a lot of courage to reach out for help. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? I just feel like everything is too much to handle.
