School is stressful, and I don't have anyone to talk to about how I'm feeling. I feel so alone. It's understandable to feel overwhelmed, Rosemary. But please remember that you're not alone. You have taken a very important step by reaching out to us. We are here to listen and support you. I just don't see a way out of this, Claudia. I feel like I can't go on like this. I hear you, Rosemary. It's important to talk about these feelings and not keep them inside. Have you ever thought about hurting yourself? Yes, I have. I've thought about hurting myself a few times. I don't know what to do. I want you to know that your life is valuable, Rosemary. You deserve to be happy and safe. It's important to reach out for help when you're feeling this way. Have you thought about talking to a trusted adult about how you're feeling? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to talk to. That's why I called the helpline. I'm glad you called, Rosemary. It's important to have someone to talk to about your feelings. You can also call us anytime you need to talk. And remember, you can also reach out to trusted adults in your life, like a teacher or a family member. Your feelings matter, and there are people who care about you. Would you like me to provide you with some resources for additional support? Yes, please. That would be helpful. Thank you, Claudia, for listening to me. You're welcome, Rosemary. I'm here to help. Remember, you can always call us at +255 7203 679667 if you need someone to talk to. Take

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Salim speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi Salim, my name is Rose, I'm 38 years old and I'm calling about a child named Mwalimu who is 7 years old from Rufiji, Pwani. I'm really worried about him. What seems to be the issue with Mwalimu, Rose? Well, Mwalimu has been showing signs of depression. He seems to be constantly sad, withdrawn, and not interested in things he used to enjoy. I've noticed that he's been struggling to sleep and eat properly as well. I'm sorry to hear that, Rose. It's important to address these concerns early on. Has Mwalimu experienced any significant changes or traumatic events recently that could be contributing to his feelings of depression? Yes, his parents have been going through a difficult divorce, and he has been caught in the middle of their conflicts. He's been witnessing a lot of arguments and tension at home, which I believe is causing him a lot of stress. It's understandable that Mwalimu may be experiencing chronic stress in this situation. It's crucial for him to receive support and guidance during this challenging time. Have you spoken to him about how he's feeling and offered him any emotional support? Yes, I've tried talking to him and comforting him, but I feel like he needs professional help to cope with his emotions. I want to ensure that he gets the support he needs to overcome his depression. I appreciate your concern, Rose. It's important to seek help from professionals to address Mwalimu's mental health needs. I can provide you with information on counseling services and support resources in your area to help Mwalimu through this difficult time. Let's work together to ensure that Mwalimu receives the necessary support and care he deserves.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Bakari speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Willy. I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Muleba, Kagera. I don't know what to do, I'm feeling really lost and sad. I'm sorry to hear that, Willy. Can you tell me a bit more about what's been going on? I've been feeling really down lately, like nothing is going right. I can't stop thinking about hurting myself, and sometimes I even think about ending everything. I'm glad you reached out for help, Willy. It takes a lot of courage to talk about these feelings. Have you ever hurt yourself before? Yes, I have. I've been cutting myself when I feel overwhelmed and it helps me feel a little better, but I know it's not a good solution. I'm really glad you recognize that, Willy. It's important to find healthier ways to cope with your emotions. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling? No, I haven't told anyone. I'm scared they won't understand or they'll think I'm just seeking attention. It's okay to feel scared, but it's important to remember that you're not alone in this. We're here to support you and help you find ways to feel better. Would you be open to talking to a counselor or a trusted adult about what you're going through? I think I could try talking to someone, but I'm still really scared. That's okay, Willy. It's normal to feel scared, but remember that asking for help is a brave thing to do. We can help you find resources and support to help you through this tough time. You're not alone in this, and we care about your well-being.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Francis speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Francis, my name is Eda. I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Singida Mjini in Singida. I'm really worried about my younger brother, he's only 6 years old. What seems to be the issue, Eda? Well, our parents have been neglecting his health. He's been sick for a while now, but they haven't taken him to see a doctor. They keep saying they can't afford it, but I'm really scared for him. I'm so sorry to hear that, Eda. Neglecting a child's medical needs is a serious issue. Have you tried talking to your parents about this? Yes, I have, but they just brush it off. I don't know what to do anymore. I don't want my brother to get even sicker. It's really good that you reached out for help, Eda. We can help you get the support your brother needs. Is there a district hospital or clinic nearby where he can receive medical attention? Yes, there's a district hospital not too far from where we live. But I don't know how we can afford the treatment. Don't worry, Eda. We can help you navigate the system and find resources to cover the medical expenses. Your brother's health is important and we will do everything we can to ensure he gets the care he needs. Thank you so much, Francis. I really appreciate your help. I just want my brother to get better. You're welcome, Eda. Let's work together to make sure your brother gets the care he deserves. I will guide you through the process of seeking help for him at the district hospital.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Subira speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, Subira. My name is Wema, I'm 15 years old, and I'm calling from Arumeru Mashariki in Arusha. Nice to meet you, Wema. How can I assist you today? I'm really scared and I don't know what to do. My caregiver has been hitting me a lot lately, and I don't know why. I'm so sorry to hear that, Wema. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? She gets really frustrated easily, especially when things don't go her way. She starts yelling and then she hits me. That sounds really tough, Wema. No one deserves to be treated that way. Have you tried talking to her about how it makes you feel? I've tried, but she just gets angrier. I'm really scared to even bring it up now. I understand, Wema. It's important to prioritize your safety. Have you thought about reaching out to someone for help, like a trusted adult or the authorities? I don't know who to turn to. I don't have any family nearby, and I'm scared to involve the police. It's understandable to feel scared, Wema. But your safety is the most important thing. The police station in your area may be able to assist you and provide you with resources to help you through this difficult situation. Thank you, Subira. I will try to gather the courage to reach out for help. I really appreciate your support. You're welcome, Wema. Remember, you deserve to feel safe and supported. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need any more assistance. Take care.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Denice, how can I help you today? Hi Denice, my name is Janet and I'm 16 years old. I'm calling from Magharibi Unguja, Mjini Magharibi. Nice to meet you, Janet. How can I assist you today? I need help, Denice. I think I might be a victim of human trafficking. I'm so sorry to hear that, Janet. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? I met a man online who promised me a job in the city. He said I could make a lot of money and have a better life. But when I got here, he forced me into prostitution. I feel trapped and scared. That sounds like a really difficult situation, Janet. You are very brave for reaching out for help. Can you tell me more about where you are currently located? I'm not exactly sure, Denice. I think it's a hotel in the city. I'm not allowed to leave and I'm constantly monitored. It's important that you stay safe, Janet. We can help you get out of this dangerous situation. Do you have any trusted adults or friends you can reach out to for support? No, Denice. I don't have anyone I can trust here. That's why I called the helpline. I'm glad you reached out to us, Janet. We will do everything we can to help you. Please stay on the line while I connect you to the appropriate authorities who can assist you in getting to a safe place. Thank you, Denice. I feel a little better knowing that help is on the way.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Mwashiuya speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi there, my name is Mwipopo. I'm 26 years old and I'm calling about a young boy named Justin from Ukerewe, Mwanza. He's been having some difficulties with his learning and I'm really concerned. I see, Mwipopo. Can you tell me more about Justin's learning difficulties? Well, Justin is 16 years old, but he's struggling a lot in school. He has trouble reading, writing, and understanding basic concepts. His grades are suffering, and he's starting to lose confidence in himself. It sounds like Justin may have some undiagnosed learning disabilities. It's important for him to get the proper support and resources to help him succeed in school. Have you spoken to his teachers or school counselor about your concerns? Yes, I have. They've noticed his struggles too and have suggested that he may need to be evaluated for learning disabilities. But Justin's parents are hesitant to take any action. They think he's just being lazy and not trying hard enough. It's important for Justin's parents to understand that learning disabilities are real and not a result of laziness. Encouraging them to seek a professional evaluation for Justin is crucial in helping him get the support he needs to thrive academically. I'll definitely try to talk to them again and emphasize the importance of getting Justin the help he needs. Thank you for your advice, Mwashiuya. I really appreciate your support. You're welcome, Mwipopo. Remember, we're here to help and support you and Justin through this process. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need any further assistance.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Dorcas. I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Mwanga, Kilimanjaro. Hello Dorcas, my name is Dina and I'm here to listen and help you. What seems to be the problem? I think something bad is happening in my village. Some girls from my school have gone missing and I heard they might have been taken away by people who want to do bad things to them. That sounds really concerning, Dorcas. It's important to talk about these things. Are you talking about human trafficking? Yes, I think so. I heard some older kids talking about how girls are being taken to other towns and forced to do things they don't want to do. I'm glad you called us, Dorcas. Human trafficking is a serious issue, especially sex trafficking. It's when people are forced or tricked into doing things against their will. It's illegal and very dangerous. I'm really scared for those girls, Dina. Is there anything we can do to help them? Yes, Dorcas, there are things we can do. It's important to report any suspicious activities to the authorities. You can also encourage your friends to be careful and stay safe. We can also provide counseling and support for those who have been affected by human trafficking. Thank you, Dina. I will make sure to tell my friends to be careful and I will keep an eye out for anything suspicious. That's great, Dorcas. Remember, you're not alone in this. If you ever need to talk or have any more concerns, don't hesitate to call us. We're here to help.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Tina. I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Meatu, Shinyanga. Hello Tina, my name is Mwakalinga and I'm here to listen and help you. What seems to be the problem? I'm having trouble with my schoolwork. I find it hard to understand what the teacher is saying and I struggle to remember things. I'm sorry to hear that, Tina. It sounds like you might be having some learning difficulties. Have you talked to your teacher or parents about this? Yes, I have. My teacher says I need to study harder and pay more attention in class. But no matter how hard I try, I just can't seem to get it. It's great that you've already spoken to your teacher about this. It's important to communicate with adults about your struggles. Have you noticed if there are specific subjects or topics that are more challenging for you? Math and science are the hardest for me. I get confused with all the numbers and formulas. It's like my brain just can't process the information. It's okay, Tina. Everyone learns at their own pace and in their own way. It's possible that you might have processing difficulties, which can make it harder for you to understand certain things. Have you ever talked to a counselor or professional about this? No, I haven't. I didn't know where to turn to until I found this helpline number. Thank you for listening to me, Mwakalinga. You're welcome, Tina. It's important to seek help when you're facing challenges. I can help you find resources and support to address your learning difficulties. Would you like me to assist you with that?

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Ana speaking. How can I help you today? Hi Ana, my name is Warda. I'm 17 years old, and I'm calling from Namtumbo in Ruvuma. Nice to meet you, Warda. How can I assist you today? I'm facing some gender discrimination issues in my community, and I don't know what to do. I'm sorry to hear that, Warda. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, in my village, girls are not allowed to go to school past a certain age. They are expected to stay home and help with household chores while boys continue their education. It's not fair. That does sound like a challenging situation, Warda. Have you tried talking to anyone about this issue? I've tried to speak to my parents, but they say it's just how things are and that I should accept it. But I don't think it's right. I understand your frustration, Warda. Gender discrimination is a serious issue, and it's important to speak up about it. Have you thought about reaching out to any local organizations for support? I haven't, but I will look into it. Thank you for listening to me, Ana. Of course, Warda. Remember, you deserve to be treated equally and have access to education. Don't hesitate to seek help if you need it. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about? No, that's all for now. Thank you for your advice, Ana. You're welcome, Warda. Take care of yourself, and remember, you're not alone in this. If you ever need to talk again, don't hesitate to reach out to us. Goodbye.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Angolwisye, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Angosisye. I'm 12 years old, a boy, from Handeni Mjini in Tanga. Nice to meet you, Angosisye. What seems to be the issue you're facing today? I'm experiencing gender-based violence at school. The teachers always favor the girls in my class and treat us boys unfairly. I'm sorry to hear that, Angosisye. It's important that all children are treated equally and with respect. Have you tried talking to anyone about this issue before? I've tried talking to my parents, but they don't seem to understand. They just tell me to focus on my studies and not to cause trouble. It's brave of you to reach out for help. Remember, you have the right to be treated fairly and with dignity. Have you thought about speaking to someone at school about what's been happening? I'm scared they won't believe me or that things will get worse if I speak up. I understand your concerns, Angosisye. It's important to speak up about any form of violence or discrimination you may be facing. You can trust me to listen and support you through this. You deserve to feel safe and respected at school. Would you like me to help you come up with a plan to address this issue? Yes, please. I want things to change at my school. Great. Let's work together to make sure your voice is heard. Remember, you can always reach out to us at the child helpline for support. Our number is +255 6420 825747.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Janet from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi Janet, my name is Cyprian. I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Micheweni, Kaskazini Pemba. Nice to meet you, Cyprian. What can I assist you with? I have a question about the helpline. I was wondering if you could provide me with some information. Of course, I'll do my best to help you. What do you need to know? Well, I've heard about the child helpline but I'm not sure how it works. Can you explain to me how to get in touch with you and what kind of support you provide? Absolutely, Cyprian. The child helpline is a confidential service where children can call or text for help and support. You can reach us by dialing the toll-free number or sending a message through our website. We offer counseling, referrals to other services, and support for various issues that children might be facing. That's good to know. Is there a physical location for the helpline where I can go for help? We don't have a physical location, but there are outreach centers in different areas where you can access our services. In Micheweni, you can visit the Post Office, where they have information about our helpline and can connect you with a counselor if needed. Thank you, Janet. I appreciate your help and I'll make sure to reach out if I ever need support. You're welcome, Cyprian. Remember, we're here to help you whenever you need it. Take care and stay safe.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Fabiano from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? My name is Ibada, I am 13 years old and I am calling from Kilolo, Iringa. I need help with something. Of course, Ibada. What seems to be the problem? I have been working at a construction site to help my family make ends meet. I know it's not right, but we are struggling financially. I understand, Ibada. It sounds like you are facing child labor issues. It's important for children like you to be in school and not working in dangerous conditions. I know, but my parents can't afford to send me to school. I feel trapped. It's not your responsibility to provide for your family at such a young age. Have you talked to your parents about your concerns? Yes, but they say we have no other choice. I want to go to school and have a better future. I will do my best to connect you with local organizations that can provide support for your family. You deserve to have a childhood and education. Thank you, Fabiano. I really appreciate your help. It's hard for me to see my friends go to school while I work all day. You are brave for reaching out, Ibada. Remember, there is always help available for children in need. Stay strong and we will work together to find a solution. Thank you, Fabiano. I will keep in touch. And oh, I can see the mosque from where I am standing right now. That's a good landmark. Stay safe, Ibada, and we will work on finding a way to improve your situation.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi there, this is Mwakalinga from Nkansi, Rukwa. I'm 16 years old. Hello Mwakalinga, I'm Rebeka from the child helpline. How can I assist you? I wanted to talk about orphaned and abandoned children in my community. I see so many kids who are struggling without proper care. That's a very important issue, Mwakalinga. Could you tell me more about what you're seeing? Well, there are children who have lost their parents and are left to fend for themselves. Some are living on the streets, others are taken in by relatives who can't provide for them. It's heartbreaking. I can imagine how difficult that must be for both the children and the community. Have you tried reaching out to any local organizations for support? Yes, we have some NGOs that provide temporary help, but many of these children are aging out of care with no long-term solutions. They need more sustainable support. It's great that there are organizations offering temporary assistance, but you're right, there needs to be more long-term solutions in place. Have you spoken to any authorities about this issue? I've tried, but it feels like our voices are not being heard. I want to advocate for these children and make sure they have the support they need to thrive. That's very admirable, Mwakalinga. Your advocacy for these vulnerable children is so important. Have you thought about starting a community initiative or reaching out to larger organizations for support? I've been thinking about it, but I wasn't sure where to start. Do you have any advice on how I can make a difference for these children in need? I can definitely provide you with some resources and guidance on how to advocate for orphaned and abandoned children in your community. Let's work together to create a plan of action and make a positive impact.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Naima. How can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Babu. I'm 31 years old and I'm calling about a child named Anyelwiswe who is 13 years old from Muheza, Tanga. Hello Babu, thank you for reaching out. What seems to be the issue with Anyelwiswe? Well, Anyelwiswe is going through some tough times at home. There are a lot of conflicts between her parents and she's caught in the middle of it all. It's really affecting her emotionally and mentally. I'm sorry to hear that. It must be difficult for her to witness such conflicts between her parents. Have you talked to Anyelwiswe about how she's feeling? Yes, she's opened up to me about how stressed and anxious she feels because of the constant arguments at home. She feels like she's being pulled in different directions by her parents. It's important for Anyelwiswe to know that she's not alone in this situation. It's not her fault that her parents are having conflicts. Have you tried talking to her parents about how their arguments are affecting her? I've tried to talk to them, but they don't seem to listen. They're so focused on their own issues that they're not realizing the impact it's having on Anyelwiswe. I understand. It can be challenging when parents are going through their own struggles. Have you thought about involving a mediator or counselor to help them work through their issues in a healthier way? That's a good idea. I'll suggest that to Anyelwiswe's parents and see if they're open to getting help. Thank you for your advice, Naima. You're welcome, Babu. Remember, the child helpline is here to support both children and adults in difficult situations. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need further assistance.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Mwinyimkuu, I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Kigoma Vijijini, Kigoma. Hello Mwinyimkuu, my name is Jefferson and I'm here to help. What's on your mind today? I've been having some trouble with my friends at school. They have been excluding me from activities and not inviting me to hang out with them. I'm sorry to hear that, Mwinyimkuu. It must be really tough to feel left out like that. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, whenever we have group projects or games, they always choose to work with each other and leave me out. It makes me feel really lonely and sad. That does sound hurtful, Mwinyimkuu. Have you tried talking to your friends about how you feel? I tried, but they just brush it off and say I'm overreacting. I don't know what to do anymore. I understand how frustrating that must be. It's important to remember that you deserve to be treated with kindness and respect by your friends. Have you thought about talking to a teacher or counselor at your school about what's been happening? I haven't, but maybe that's a good idea. I just don't want to cause more problems. Speaking up about how you're feeling is not causing problems, Mwinyimkuu. It's important to advocate for yourself and seek support when you need it. Remember, you deserve to feel included and valued by your friends. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about or any other ways I can support you? Thank you, Jefferson. I feel a bit better now. I think I'll talk to my teacher about what's been going on. Thank you for listening to me. You're welcome, Mwinyimkuu. Remember, the Child Helpline is always here for you whenever you need someone to talk to. Take care and don't hesitate to reach out if you need support in the future.

Hello, is this the child helpline? I need someone to talk to. Yes, this is Diana from the child helpline. How can I help you today? My name is Nasra, I'm 10 years old, and I live in Iringa Mjini. I've been feeling really anxious and stressed lately. I'm sorry to hear that, Nasra. Can you tell me more about what's been causing you to feel this way? Well, my family has been going through a lot of changes recently. My parents have been arguing a lot, and I'm scared that they might get a divorce. It's been really hard for me to focus on school and I can't sleep at night. It sounds like you're going through a tough time, Nasra. It's normal to feel anxious when there's instability in your family. Have you tried talking to your parents about how you're feeling? I've tried, but they just tell me not to worry and that everything will be fine. But I can't help feeling stressed all the time. It's important to remember that it's okay to feel this way, Nasra. It's not your fault and you're not alone. Have you thought about any ways to cope with your anxiety? I've tried taking deep breaths and talking to my friends, but it doesn't seem to help much. I just feel so overwhelmed. I understand, Nasra. It's important to remember that you can always reach out for help when you need it. Have you talked to any adults you trust about how you're feeling? Not really, I'm scared they won't understand. But talking to you has made me feel a little better. I'm glad I could help, Nasra. Remember, it's okay to ask for help and there are people who care about you. If you ever need to talk again, don't hesitate to call us. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about? No, thank you, Diana. Just talking to you has made me feel a lot better. Thank you for listening to me. You're welcome, Nasra. Take care of yourself and remember that you're not alone. Goodbye.

Hello, is this the child helpline? I need someone to talk to. Yes, this is Angolwisye from the child helpline. How can I help you today? My name is Doris, I'm 12 years old, and I'm from Njombe, Iringa. I'm feeling really sad and neglected at home. I'm sorry to hear that, Doris. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? My parents are always busy with work and they never have time for me. They don't ask how my day was or if I need help with school. I feel like I'm all alone. It sounds like you're going through a tough time, Doris. It's important to know that you're not alone and that there are people who care about you. I don't feel like anyone cares about me. I try to talk to my parents, but they brush me off or tell me to stop bothering them. It's not right for you to feel neglected like this, Doris. You deserve to feel loved and supported by your family. Have you tried talking to anyone else about how you're feeling? I haven't told anyone else. I was too scared to speak up. But I couldn't keep it all inside anymore. I'm glad you reached out to us, Doris. It takes courage to ask for help. We can work together to figure out ways to help you feel better and supported. Have you thought about talking to a teacher or a school counselor about what's been going on at home? I haven't, but I think that's a good idea. I go to the Secondary School in our town, maybe I can talk to a teacher there. That's a great step, Doris. Your teachers are there to support you and help you through difficult times. Remember, you deserve to be heard and cared for. You are important and your feelings matter.

Hello, is this the child helpline? I need someone to talk to. Yes, this is Irine from the child helpline. How can I help you today? I'm Luciana, I'm 10 years old, and I'm calling from Sumbawanga Vijijini in Rukwa. I've been feeling really sad and lonely lately. I'm sorry to hear that, Luciana. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? Well, my friends at school have been ignoring me and leaving me out of things. They don't want to play with me anymore, and it makes me feel really bad about myself. That sounds really tough, Luciana. It's never easy when friends treat you like that. Have you tried talking to them about how you feel? I did, but they just laughed and called me names. I don't know what to do anymore. It's important to remember that you are not alone, Luciana. There are people who care about you and want to help. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I found this helpline number. I'm glad you reached out, Luciana. It takes courage to ask for help. Remember, it's okay to feel sad sometimes, but it's important to talk to someone about it. You are valued and loved, no matter what others may say or do. Thank you, Irine. I feel a little better now. I'll try to be brave and talk to someone about how I'm feeling. That's great to hear, Luciana. Remember, you can always call us back if you need to talk. Take care of yourself, okay? Okay, thank you. Goodbye.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Esther speaking, how can I assist you today? Hello Esther, my name is Amina. I am calling about a child named Ambata. He is a 14-year-old boy from Kyerwa, Kagera. I am very concerned about his well-being. Thank you for reaching out, Amina. Could you please tell me more about what is happening with Ambata? Well, Esther, the issue is neglect. Ambata's parents are not around most of the time, and he is often left alone at home with no one to supervise him. He is not attending school regularly, and I am worried about his safety and overall development. I understand your concerns, Amina. It is important for children to have proper supervision and care. Have you tried talking to Ambata's parents about this situation? Yes, I have tried to speak with his parents, but they seem to be too busy with work to pay attention to Ambata's needs. I am not sure what else to do to ensure that he receives the care and support he deserves. Thank you for bringing this to our attention, Amina. We will take the necessary steps to ensure that Ambata is protected and supported. Can you provide me with any additional information about his situation? I will do my best to provide any information that can help. Thank you for listening and for your assistance, Esther. I just want to make sure that Ambata gets the help he needs to thrive and be safe. Thank you, Amina. Your concern for Ambata's well-being is truly admirable. We will follow up on this report and take the appropriate measures to support him. Thank you for reaching out to the Tanzanian child helpline.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Katalina speaking, how can I help you today? Hey, my name is Mike, I'm 16 years old, and I'm calling from Misungwi, Mwanza. Nice to meet you, Mike. How can I assist you today? I think I might be a victim of human trafficking. I've been forced to work long hours on a farm without pay. I'm so sorry to hear that, Mike. It's important that you reached out for help. Can you tell me more about the situation? I was promised a job opportunity here in Misungwi, but when I arrived, I was forced to work in harsh conditions without any breaks. I'm scared and I don't know what to do. That sounds like a serious case of labor trafficking, Mike. It's important that we get you the help you need. Do you know where you are currently located? Is there a landmark nearby that you can describe? I'm near the Town Hall in Misungwi. I don't have the exact address, but I can see the building from where I am. Thank you for providing that information, Mike. We will do everything we can to assist you. Can you please give me your phone number in case we get disconnected? Sure, my phone number is +255 7932 447369. Thank you, Mike. I will make sure to follow up with you. Please stay on the line while I connect you with the appropriate authorities to ensure your safety. You are not alone in this, and we are here to support you.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Asha speaking. How can I help you today? Hi Asha, my name is Bibi. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Mkoani, Kusini Pemba. Nice to meet you, Bibi. How can I assist you today? Well, Asha, I'm feeling really scared and upset. There was a big storm last night and it caused a lot of damage in my village. Our house was damaged, and some of our neighbors got hurt. I'm so sorry to hear that, Bibi. It must have been a very frightening experience for you. Yes, it was. I can't stop thinking about the sound of the wind and the crashing of the trees. And seeing people injured... it's just too much for me. It's completely understandable to feel this way after witnessing such a traumatic event. Have you been able to talk to anyone about how you're feeling? Not really. My parents are busy trying to fix our house, and my friends are all dealing with their own problems. I just feel so alone. You're not alone, Bibi. That's why the child helpline is here. It's important to talk about your feelings and get the support you need to cope with what you've been through. Thank you, Asha. I'm really grateful for your help. I just don't know how to deal with all these emotions. It's okay, Bibi. It's normal to feel overwhelmed after a natural disaster like this. Would you like me to connect you with a counselor who can help you process your feelings and provide you with coping strategies? Yes, please. That would be really helpful. Thank you, Asha, for being there for me.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi there, my name is Darweshi. I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Nyamagana, Mwanza. Nice to meet you, Darweshi. I'm Cecil from the child helpline. What seems to be the issue today? Well, I have some questions about sexual and reproductive health. I've been hearing a lot of things at school and from my friends, and I'm not sure what's true and what's not. I'm glad you reached out to us, Darweshi. It's important to have accurate information about these topics. What specific questions do you have? I've been wondering about puberty and what changes to expect in my body. And also, how do I know if I'm ready for sexual activity? Those are great questions, Darweshi. Puberty is a natural process where your body goes through changes to become an adult. It's normal to experience growth spurts, changes in voice, and the development of sexual characteristics. As for readiness for sexual activity, it's important to understand consent, protection, and emotional readiness before engaging in any sexual activity. Thank you for explaining that, Cecil. I also wanted to ask about contraception and sexually transmitted infections. How can I protect myself from these risks? It's great that you're thinking about protection, Darweshi. Contraception methods like condoms can help prevent both pregnancy and STIs. It's important to always use protection and get tested regularly if you're sexually active. If you have any concerns or need more information, feel free to reach out to us anytime. Thank you, Cecil. I feel more informed now. I'll make sure to take care of myself and seek help if I need it.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Adelina speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Anyabwile. I'm 14 years old and I'm from Unguja Kaskazini A, Kaskazini Unguja. I really need help. What seems to be the problem, Anyabwile? I've been witnessing a lot of fighting between my parents at home. It's really scary and I don't know what to do. I'm sorry to hear that, Anyabwile. It sounds like you're experiencing domestic violence. It's important to know that you're not alone in this situation. Have you tried talking to anyone about what's been happening at home? No, I haven't. I don't know who to talk to. I just feel really scared and helpless. I understand how overwhelming this must be for you. It's brave of you to reach out for help. Have you thought about seeking support from a trusted adult or a counselor at your school? I'm too scared to talk to anyone in person about this. I don't want to get anyone in trouble. I want to assure you that seeking help is not about getting anyone in trouble, but it's about ensuring your safety and well-being. Is there a community center or a local organization in your area that you can reach out to for support? Yes, there's a community center nearby. I could try talking to someone there. Thank you for listening to me, Adelina. I feel a bit better knowing that there are people I can turn to for help. You're welcome, Anyabwile. Remember, you deserve to feel safe and supported. Don't hesitate to reach out to the community center or call us back if you need further assistance. Take care.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Feruzi speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Matilda. I'm calling about a child named Jaali. He's 11 years old and lives in Temeke, Dar es Salaam. Thank you for reaching out, Matilda. What seems to be the issue with Jaali? Well, Jaali has been making prank calls to emergency services and pretending there's a serious situation when there isn't. He's been doing this quite frequently and it's been causing a lot of unnecessary panic and wasting resources. I see, that is definitely a concerning behavior. Have you spoken to Jaali about this issue? Yes, I have tried to talk to him about it, but he doesn't seem to understand the seriousness of his actions. I'm worried that if he continues, it could lead to serious consequences. It's good that you're seeking help for Jaali. It's important to address this behavior before it escalates. Have you noticed any other concerning behaviors from Jaali? Yes, Jaali has also been seeking attention in other ways, such as disrupting class at school and exaggerating stories to get attention from his peers. It sounds like Jaali may be struggling with some underlying issues that are causing him to seek attention in negative ways. I can provide you with some resources and guidance on how to help Jaali address these behaviors. Thank you, I would appreciate any help and advice you can offer. I just want to make sure Jaali gets the support he needs to make better choices in the future. Of course, Matilda. We're here to support you and Jaali through this. Let's work together to help him overcome these challenges.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, this is Hellen from Iringa Vijijini. I'm 12 years old. Hello Hellen, I'm Yusuf from the child helpline. What seems to be the problem? I've been making prank calls to random numbers and I don't know why. I think I just wanted attention. I see, Hellen. Prank calling can be harmful and it's important to understand why you're doing it. Have you been feeling lonely or ignored lately? Yeah, sometimes I feel like no one pays attention to me at home. I thought making prank calls would make me feel better, but now I know it's wrong. It's good that you realize that, Hellen. It's important to find healthier ways to seek attention and communicate your feelings. Have you talked to anyone about how you've been feeling? No, I haven't. I didn't know how to bring it up. It's okay, Hellen. You can always talk to a trusted adult or a counselor about how you're feeling. They can help you find better ways to cope with your emotions. Is there someone at school or in your community that you trust? I think I can talk to my teacher at school. She's really nice and understanding. Thank you for listening, Yusuf. You're welcome, Hellen. Remember, it's always okay to ask for help when you need it. If you ever feel like making prank calls again, try to reach out to someone instead. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about? No, I think I'm okay now. Thank you for your help, Yusuf. You're welcome, Hellen. Take care and remember, we're here to help whenever you need us. Goodbye. Goodbye. Thank you.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Kumi speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Cosmas, I'm 12 years old, and I'm from Babati Vijijini in Manyara. I'm feeling really overwhelmed and I don't know what to do. I'm here to listen, Cosmas. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? I've been having these thoughts... thoughts of hurting myself. I feel like I can't handle all the stress and pressure anymore. I'm so sorry to hear that, Cosmas. It takes a lot of courage to reach out for help. Do you have a plan to hurt yourself? I... I've been thinking about taking pills. I just want all the pain to go away. It's important to remember that there are people who care about you and want to help. Have you told anyone else about these thoughts? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to talk to. But I saw the number for the Child Helpline at the Post Office and decided to call. I'm glad you reached out, Cosmas. You're not alone in this. We can work together to find ways to cope with these feelings. Have you thought about talking to a trusted adult about what you're going through? I'm scared they won't understand or that they'll be mad at me. It's understandable to feel scared, but it's important to remember that there are people who care about you and want to support you. Can you promise me that you won't do anything to hurt yourself before we figure out a plan together? I promise, Kumi. Thank you for listening to me.

Hello, this is the child helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Sadiki, I'm 12 years old, and I'm calling from Bukombe in Shinyanga. Nice to meet you, Sadiki. I'm Alicia, and I'm here to help. What can I assist you with today? I just wanted to know more about the child helpline. I've heard about it, but I'm not sure how it works. That's a great question, Sadiki. The child helpline is here to provide support and assistance to children like yourself who may be facing challenges or need someone to talk to. You can call us anytime you need help or advice. That's really good to know. So, if I have a problem or need to talk to someone, I can just call this number? Exactly, Sadiki. Whether you're feeling sad, scared, or just need someone to listen, you can call the child helpline. We're here to support you and provide guidance. Thank you, Alicia. I feel better knowing that there's someone I can talk to if I need help. Is there anything else I should know about the child helpline? You can also reach out to us through text or online chat if that's more comfortable for you. And if you ever need more specific help, we can refer you to other organizations or services in your area that can assist you further. That's really helpful, Alicia. Thank you for explaining everything to me. I'll keep this number handy in case I ever need to reach out for help. You're welcome, Sadiki. Remember, you're not alone, and we're here to support you whenever you need us. Take care, and don't hesitate to call if you need anything.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Radhi. How can I help you today? Hi Radhi, my name is Leokadia. I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Singida Mjini in Singida. I'm really struggling with some issues at home. I'm here to listen, Leokadia. What's been going on? Well, my parents have been fighting a lot lately. It's mostly about money. My dad lost his job a few months ago and now things are really tight at home. They argue all the time about bills and not having enough money. I'm sorry to hear that, Leokadia. It must be really tough for you to see your parents like that. Have you tried talking to them about how you feel? I've tried, but they just tell me not to worry and that they'll figure it out. But it's hard not to worry when I hear them shouting at each other every day. I just don't know what to do. It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed by all of this. It's not easy to see your parents going through a difficult time. Have you thought about reaching out to someone else for support? I haven't really talked to anyone about it. I didn't know who to turn to. That's why I decided to call the helpline today. I'm glad you reached out, Leokadia. It's important to talk about your feelings and get the support you need. We can help you find ways to cope with the situation at home and provide you with resources to help your family during this difficult time. Thank you, Radhi. I feel a bit better now that I've talked to someone about it. I'll try to talk to my parents again and see if we can work through this together. That's a positive step, Leokadia. Remember, you're not alone in this. We're here for you whenever you need to talk. Take care, and don't hesitate to call us again if you need further support.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Yahya from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Jamil, I'm 12 years old, and I'm calling from Nkansi in Rukwa. I'm having some trouble at school. I'm sorry to hear that, Jamil. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, there's this group of kids in my class who always make fun of me during the academic competitions. They call me names and laugh at me when I get answers wrong. That sounds really tough, Jamil. It's not fair for you to be treated that way. Have you tried talking to a teacher or an adult at school about what's been going on? I haven't, I'm too scared to tell anyone. I thought maybe I could handle it on my own, but it's been getting worse. It's important to remember that you don't have to deal with this alone, Jamil. Bullying is never okay, and it's important to reach out for help. Is there a teacher or counselor at your school who you trust and feel comfortable talking to? There's a teacher named Mr. Kassim who is really nice. Maybe I could talk to him. That sounds like a good idea, Jamil. Mr. Kassim can help you address the bullying and make sure you feel safe at school. Remember, you deserve to be treated with respect and kindness. Don't hesitate to reach out for support whenever you need it. Thank you, Yahya. I feel better knowing that I can talk to someone about this. You're welcome, Jamil. Remember, the child helpline is always here for you if you need someone to talk to. Take care, and stay strong. Oh, and if you ever need to visit our office, it's near the Mosque in town.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Kivuli. I am a 10-year-old boy from Babati, Manyara. Hello Kivuli, this is Gloria from the child helpline. How can I help you today? I am facing some issues at home. I feel like my sister gets treated better just because she is a girl. It's not fair. I'm sorry to hear that, Kivuli. It sounds like you are experiencing gender discrimination. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, my parents always give my sister more food and better clothes. They also let her go to school, but I have to stay home and help with chores. That does sound unfair, Kivuli. No one should be treated differently because of their gender. Have you tried talking to your parents about how you feel? Yes, but they just tell me that it's the way things are supposed to be. They say that boys and girls have different roles in the family. It's important for you to know that everyone deserves equal treatment, regardless of their gender. You have the right to speak up about how you feel. Have you thought about reaching out to someone else for help? I didn't know who to talk to until I found this helpline number. I'm glad I called. I'm glad you called too, Kivuli. We are here to support you. If you ever feel unsafe or need someone to talk to, you can always reach out to us at +255 7745 726365. We are located near Central Hospital in case you need to visit us in person. Thank you, Gloria. I feel better knowing that I have someone to talk to about this.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Kajakafwile, I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Bukoba Mjini, Kagera. Hello Kajakafwile, I'm Mwakisyala from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? I need help with a family issue. There's been a lot of conflict at home lately, and it's getting worse. I'm sorry to hear that, Kajakafwile. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? My parents have been arguing a lot, and it sometimes turns into physical violence. I'm scared and don't know what to do. That sounds really tough. It's important to know that you're not alone in this situation. Have you talked to anyone else about what's been happening at home? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I found out about the child helpline. I'm glad you reached out to us, Kajakafwile. It's brave of you to seek help. We can provide you with support and guidance on how to deal with the situation at home. Have you thought about contacting local authorities or organizations that can help with domestic violence? I haven't, but I'm willing to explore any options that can help improve the situation at home. Thank you for listening and offering your support, Mwakisyala. You're welcome, Kajakafwile. Remember, you have the right to feel safe and protected. We're here to support you every step of the way. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you need further assistance or guidance.

Hello, thank you for calling the Child Helpline. This is Justin speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Justin, my name is Diana. I'm 33 years old and I'm calling about a child named Afaafa who is 14 years old. She lives in Kiteto, Manyara. I'm really worried about her. What seems to be the problem, Diana? Well, Afaafa's parents are both struggling with alcoholism. They drink all the time and it's affecting her badly. She's been missing school, getting into trouble, and I'm afraid she might start drinking as well. I'm so sorry to hear that, Diana. It must be very difficult for Afaafa to witness her parents going through this. Have you tried talking to her parents about their alcoholism? Yes, I've tried talking to them but they don't seem to listen. They just keep drinking and neglecting Afaafa. It's important for Afaafa to have a supportive adult in her life during this difficult time. Have you spoken to her about how she's feeling and coping with the situation? Yes, I have. She feels scared and alone. She doesn't know who to turn to for help. It's great that she has you looking out for her, Diana. We can help connect Afaafa to counseling services and provide support for both her and her parents. It's important to address the root cause of the alcoholism in the family. Thank you, Justin. I just want what's best for Afaafa. I'll make sure to talk to her about reaching out for help. That's great to hear, Diana. Remember, you're not alone in this. We're here to support you and Afaafa every step of the way.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Fidelis speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Glory. I'm 12 years old and I'm from Wete, Kaskazini Pemba. I'm feeling really down lately and I don't know what to do. I'm sorry to hear that, Glory. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? Well, my parents have been arguing a lot lately and it's really affecting me. I feel like I'm always walking on eggshells around them. I can't concentrate at school and I just feel so sad all the time. It sounds like you're going through a tough time, Glory. It's okay to feel this way, but it's important to talk about it. Have you tried talking to anyone else about how you're feeling? No, I haven't. I don't know who to talk to. That's why I decided to call the helpline. I'm glad you reached out, Glory. It takes courage to ask for help. Have you noticed any physical symptoms like changes in your appetite or sleeping patterns? Yes, I've been having trouble sleeping and I don't feel like eating much. I just feel tired all the time. It sounds like you may be experiencing symptoms of depression, Glory. It's important to take care of yourself and seek support. Have you thought about talking to a counselor or a trusted adult about how you're feeling? I haven't, but I think I might feel better if I did. Thank you for listening to me, Fidelis. You're welcome, Glory. Remember, it's okay to ask for help and you're not alone in this. We're here to support you. Take care of yourself and reach out whenever you need to talk.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Adimu. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Elisia. I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Moshi Mjini in Kilimanjaro. I really need someone to talk to about my parents. Of course, Elisia. What seems to be the problem with your parents? Well, lately they have been arguing a lot, and it's really affecting me. They have very different parenting styles, and it's causing a lot of tension in our house. I'm sorry to hear that, Elisia. It must be difficult for you to witness your parents fighting. Can you tell me more about the differences in their parenting styles? Sure. My mom is very strict and always expects me to follow all the rules without question. On the other hand, my dad is more laid back and lets me have more freedom. It's like they're constantly contradicting each other, and I feel caught in the middle. It sounds like a challenging situation, Elisia. Have you tried talking to your parents about how their conflicts are affecting you? I've tried, but they just end up arguing more. I don't know what to do anymore. It's important for you to remember that their conflicts are not your fault, Elisia. You deserve to feel safe and supported in your home. Have you thought about seeking help from a trusted adult or counselor at school? I haven't, but I think I will. Thank you for listening and giving me some advice, Adimu. It really means a lot to me. You're welcome, Elisia. Remember, you're not alone, and there are people who care about you and want to help. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need support in the future.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Yahya, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Miriam, I'm 17 years old, and I'm calling from Mkoani in Kusini Pemba. I need help with something really urgent. Of course, Miriam. What seems to be the problem? I think my friend might be a victim of human trafficking. She told me she was being transported somewhere against her will, and I'm really worried about her safety. That sounds like a serious situation, Miriam. I'm glad you reached out to us. Can you provide me with more information about your friend's situation? She didn't give me much detail, but she mentioned that she was being taken to a different city and that she was scared. I tried calling her, but her phone is off now. It's good that you're looking out for your friend, Miriam. Human trafficking is a serious issue, and we need to act quickly. Do you know any specific details about the people who are transporting her? I'm not sure, but I think it might be someone she knows. She sounded really frightened when she called me. I'm afraid something bad might happen to her. Thank you for sharing that information, Miriam. We will do everything we can to help your friend. I will need to gather some more details from you so we can take the appropriate steps to assist her. Can you tell me more about your friend's appearance and the last location you know she was in? Sure, she's about my height, with long brown hair and brown eyes. The last time I saw her, she was near the market in town. I haven't heard from her since then. Thank you, Miriam. We will do our best to locate your friend and ensure her safety. Please stay on the line so we can gather more information and take immediate action.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Betty speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Betty, my name is Kombo. I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Unguja Kaskazini B, Kaskazini Unguja. Hello Kombo, how can I assist you today? I... I don't really know how to say this, but I think I've been a victim of sexual abuse. I'm really sorry to hear that, Kombo. Can you tell me more about what happened? There's this man in my community who has been touching me inappropriately. He's a lot older than me and I feel really uncomfortable around him. I'm so sorry you're going through this, Kombo. It's important that you know it's not your fault. Have you talked to anyone else about this? No, I haven't. I don't know who to trust. I feel scared and ashamed. It's completely understandable to feel that way, but it's important to speak up so we can help protect you. We can keep your information confidential. Have you considered talking to a trusted adult or reporting this to the authorities? I'm scared of what might happen if I tell someone. What if he hurts me or my family? Your safety is the most important thing, Kombo. We can work together to find a way to keep you safe. You deserve to be protected from harm. Would you be comfortable sharing more details with me so we can figure out the best course of action? I... I guess I could try. Thank you for listening, Betty. You're welcome, Kombo. I'm here to support you through this. Let's work together to ensure your safety and well-being.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Selemani, I'm 10 years old, and I'm calling from Bukoba Vijijini in Kagera. Hello Selemani, I'm Noelia from the child helpline. Hello, this is Omar calling from Chake Chake, Kusini Pemba. Hi Omar, this is Agripina from the child helpline. How can I help you today? I'm 11 years old and I'm having some trouble at school. Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Andengwisye speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Andengwisye, my name is Sabrina. Hello, is this the child helpline? I need someone to talk to. Hi there, this is Sara from the child helpline. You've called the right place. What's on your mind today? - Hello, Child Helpline, this is Sina speaking. How can I help you today? - Hi, my name is Paulina. I'm 15 years old, and I'm calling from Micheweni, Kaskazini Pemba. - Nice to meet you, Paulina. Hello, good afternoon. I'm calling about a child in need of help. Good afternoon, this is Mwashiuya from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Dorcas from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? My name is Margareth, I am 17 years old, and I am calling from Mkoani, Kusini Pemba. Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Jamil speaking, how can I assist you today? Unfortunately, there are limited resources in our village, but I will try to explore other options for him. Thank you for listening and offering your support, Jamil. Hello, Child Helpline, this is Christopher speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Queen, I'm 11 years old, and I'm calling from Muleba in Kagera. Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Modesta. I'm 13 years old and I'm calling from Mpwapwa, Dodoma. Hello Modesta, I'm Perpetua from the child helpline. Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Mzee, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Rabia. I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Mtwara Mjini in Mtwara. Hello, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Rebeka and I'm 10 years old. I'm feeling really anxious and stressed out. Hello Rebeka, my name is Masomakali and I'm here to help you. Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. My name is Severine, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Neema. I am 14 years old and I live in Hanang, Manyara. Hello, Child Helpline, this is Sara speaking. How can I help you today? Hi Sara, my name is Asha. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Kondoa in Dodoma. Nice to meet you, Asha. Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Flora, I'm 10 years old and I'm from Sengerema, Mwanza. Hello Flora, I'm Felix from the child helpline. What's on your mind today? Hello, hello, is anyone there? I really need someone to talk to. Hello, this is Baraka from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi Baraka, my name is Nelly. You're very brave, Nelly. We're here to support you every step of the way. Let's work together to ensure your safety and well-being.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Epifania speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Epifania, my name is Omar. Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Ambokile, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Justa and I'm 14 years old. I'm calling from Kyerwa, Kagera. I need help with something really serious. Of course, Justa. What seems to be the issue? I think there's some human trafficking happening in my village. There are people coming in trucks and taking young girls away. I'm really scared and I don't know what to do. I'm so sorry to hear that, Justa. Human trafficking is a very serious crime. I don't have any details like that, but I can tell you where they usually pick up the girls. It's near the market, behind the big tree. Thank you, Justa. Your information is very helpful. We will investigate this matter further and take action to stop this trafficking. In the meantime, please stay safe and do not approach any suspicious vehicles. You can call us anytime if you need help or feel threatened. Thank you so much, Ambokile. I feel a bit better knowing that someone is looking into this. I will be careful and I'll call you if I see anything else.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Mwakanjuki speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Geni. I'm 15 years old and I'm from Mwanga, Kilimanjaro. They're always arguing and it's making me really stressed out. I'm sorry to hear that, Geni. It must be really tough for you to deal with that.
