Thank you, Mwakanjuki. I really appreciate that. I just feel like I can't handle it anymore. It's okay to feel overwhelmed, Geni. It's important to take care of yourself during these stressful times. Have you thought about any coping strategies that might help you feel better? I haven't really thought about that. Do you have any suggestions? Maybe you could try talking to a school counselor or a trusted adult about what you're going through. It's important to have someone to talk to and lean on for support. That's a good idea. I'll try talking to my teacher about it. Thank you so much for your help, Mwakanjuki. You're welcome, Geni. Remember, we're here for you whenever you need someone to talk to. Take care of yourself and reach out if you need anything else.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Afaafa. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Justine. I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Arusha Mjini, Arusha. I need help. Of course, Justine. What seems to be the problem? There was a big storm last night, and our house got flooded. It was really scary. I'm so sorry to hear that, Justine. It must have been very frightening for you. Are you and your family okay? Yes, we're all safe, but we lost a lot of our belongings. The water came into our house so fast, and we didn't have time to save everything. I can imagine how upsetting that must have been for you. It's important to stay safe during natural disasters like storms and floods. Have you been able to find a safe place to stay for now? Yes, we are staying with our neighbors for the time being. But I'm worried about our house and all our things. Will we be able to go back soon? I understand your concern, Justine. It's important to prioritize your safety and well-being. It's best to wait until it's safe to return home. In the meantime, you can reach out to local authorities for assistance and support. They can help assess the damage and provide guidance on what to do next. Okay, thank you, Afaafa. I will talk to my parents about reaching out to the authorities. I just wanted to make sure we're doing the right thing. You're very welcome, Justine. Remember, it's important to stay strong and reach out for help when you need it. You can call the child helpline anytime you have questions or need support. Take care, and stay safe. Thank you, Afaafa. Goodbye.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Jefferson, how can I help you today? Hi Jefferson, my name is Salome. I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Kibiti, Pwani. Nice to meet you, Salome. How can I assist you today? I'm having a problem with bullying, Jefferson. It's been going on for a while now and I don't know what to do. I'm sorry to hear that, Salome. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, it started with some girls at school making fun of me and spreading rumors about me. But now, it's escalated to cyberbullying. They're posting hurtful things about me online and it's really getting to me. I can imagine how difficult that must be for you, Salome. Have you tried talking to anyone about this? I haven't. I feel really embarrassed and I don't want to make things worse. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, Salome. Bullying, whether in person or online, is never okay. Have you thought about talking to a trusted adult about what's been happening? I haven't, but I think I should. I just didn't know where to turn for help. I'm glad you reached out to us, Salome. We're here to support you and we can help you figure out the best way to address this situation. Would you like some guidance on how to talk to someone about what's been happening? Yes, please. I don't want this to continue and I want to feel safe at school and online. I'm here to help, Salome. Let's work together to find a solution to this bullying issue.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Asteria speaking, how can I assist you today? Hello Asteria, my name is Maimuna, I am 50 years old and I am calling about my child Tumaini. He is 13 years old and we live in Unguja Kaskazini A, Kaskazini Unguja. I am really worried about him lately. What seems to be the matter with Tumaini, Maimuna? He has been feeling very down and sad lately. He doesn't want to talk to anyone, he has lost interest in his favorite activities, and he is always tired. I think he might be depressed. I'm sorry to hear that, Maimuna. It's good that you are reaching out for help. Depression is a serious issue, especially in young children. Have you noticed any triggers or events that may have led to Tumaini feeling this way? Not really, Asteria. Tumaini has always been a sensitive child, and I have heard that depression can also be genetic. I have struggled with depression in the past, so I am worried that he may have inherited it from me. That is a valid concern, Maimuna. It is possible for depression to have a biological predisposition. It's important for Tumaini to receive the proper support and treatment. Have you considered seeking professional help for him? Yes, I have thought about taking him to see a counselor or therapist. I just want him to feel better and be happy again. That's a good step, Maimuna. It's important to address mental health issues early on. I can provide you with some resources and guidance on how to support Tumaini through this difficult time. Have you heard of the Post Office in our area? They have information on mental health services that may be helpful for Tumaini. Thank you, Asteria. I will definitely look into that. I just want my child to get the help he needs. You're doing a great job as a parent, Maimuna. Remember, it's okay to ask for help and support when dealing with mental health issues. We are here for you and Tumaini every step of the way.

Hello, Child Helpline, Kelvin speaking. How can I help you today? Hi Kelvin, my name is Conrad. I'm 10 years old, and I'm calling from Ulanga, Morogoro. Nice to meet you, Conrad. What's on your mind today? I... I don't know how to say this, but something bad happened to me. Some boys in my school have been touching me inappropriately and making me do things I don't want to do. I'm really sorry to hear that, Conrad. It sounds like you're experiencing sexual abuse. It's important for you to know that what those boys are doing is not okay. You have the right to feel safe and respected. But they keep threatening me and saying if I tell anyone, they'll hurt me even more. I don't know what to do. You did the right thing by reaching out for help, Conrad. It takes a lot of courage to speak up about something like this. No one has the right to make you feel uncomfortable or scared. It's important to talk to a trusted adult about what's been happening to you. Have you told anyone else about this? No, I was too scared. But I'm glad I called you. Thank you for listening to me, Kelvin. Of course, Conrad. I'm here to support you. You can call us anytime you need to talk or if you need help figuring out what to do next. And remember, you can also contact the police at 112 or the National Child Helpline at +255 7804 617234 for further assistance. Thank you, Kelvin. I feel a little better now that I've talked to someone about it. I'm glad to hear that, Conrad. Remember, you're not alone in this. We're here to help you through this difficult time. Take care of yourself, okay? Okay. Thank you, Kelvin. Goodbye.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Ambakisye. I'm 10 years old, and I live in Magharibi Unguja, Mjini Magharibi. Hi Ambakisye, this is Daniel from the child helpline. How are you feeling today? I'm not feeling very good, Daniel. I've been feeling really sad and lonely lately. I'm sorry to hear that, Ambakisye. Can you tell me more about what's been making you feel this way? Well, at school, the other kids don't really want to play with me. They always leave me out of games and activities, and it makes me feel really left out and alone. I can understand how that must be really tough for you, Ambakisye. It's important to remember that you are not alone and that there are people who care about you. Have you tried talking to your teachers or parents about how you're feeling? I haven't really talked to anyone about it. I didn't know who to talk to, so I decided to call the helpline. I'm glad you called, Ambakisye. It's important to talk about your feelings and not keep them bottled up inside. We can work together to find ways to help you feel better and more supported. Would you like to talk about some strategies to cope with these feelings of loneliness and sadness? Yes, that would be really helpful, Daniel. Thank you for listening to me and for being there for me. It means a lot to know that someone cares. You're welcome, Ambakisye. Remember, you are important and valued, and there are people who want to help you. Let's work together to find ways to overcome these challenges and feel better.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Fahamu. I'm 14 years old and I'm calling from Songea Vijijini, Ruvuma. Hello Fahamu, I'm Vivian from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? I'm calling because I need help. My parents fight a lot at home, and it's really scary. I'm sorry to hear that, Fahamu. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, my dad drinks a lot and when he's drunk, he gets really angry and he hits my mom. I try to protect her, but I feel so helpless. I'm so sorry you're going through this, Fahamu. It's not right for anyone to be hurting your mom or you. Have you talked to anyone about this before? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to talk to or where to go for help. You did the right thing by calling us, Fahamu. We're here to help you. It's important to remember that domestic violence is never okay, and there are ways to keep you and your mom safe. Have you talked to your mom about how you're feeling? Yes, I have. She told me that she's scared too, but she doesn't know what to do. She's afraid of what my dad might do if she leaves. It's understandable that she's scared, Fahamu. But it's important for both of you to be safe. I can connect you to organizations that can help your mom and provide support for you as well. Thank you, Vivian. I just want things to get better at home. We'll do our best to help you, Fahamu. You're very brave for reaching out for help. We're here for you every step of the way.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Fanana speaking, how can I assist you today? Hello Fanana, my name is Jaali and I'm calling about a child in need. His name is Kombo, he is 8 years old, and he lives in Kibiti, Pwani. Thank you for reaching out, Jaali. What seems to be the issue with Kombo? Well, Fanana, I've noticed that Kombo has been looking very weak and tired lately. His parents are struggling to provide enough food for the family, and I'm worried that Kombo is not getting the nutrition he needs to stay healthy. I see, Jaali. It's concerning to hear about Kombo's health. Nutritional health is crucial for a growing child. Have you noticed any specific signs of malnutrition in Kombo? Yes, Fanana. Kombo's clothes are starting to look loose on him, and he often complains of stomach pains. I think his family's financial situation is making it difficult for them to afford proper meals. I'm glad you reached out, Jaali. It's important to address these concerns early on. Have you tried talking to Kombo's parents about their struggles with providing enough food for the family? Yes, I have, Fanana. But they are also facing challenges in finding stable work. I'm not sure how to help them improve their situation. I understand, Jaali. The situation sounds tough, but there are resources available to support families in need. I can provide you with information on local organizations and programs that offer assistance with food and nutrition. There is a Post Office in Kibiti where you can find more information. Thank you, Fanana. I will make sure to pass on this information to Kombo's family. I appreciate your help in this difficult situation.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Eliana, how can I help you today? Hi Eliana, my name is Angosisye. I'm 13 years old and I live in Mkinga, Tanga. Nice to meet you, Angosisye. What's been going on that made you decide to reach out to us today? I've been feeling really down lately. My parents got divorced a few months ago and things have been really tough at home since then. I'm sorry to hear that, Angosisye. It must be really hard to go through such a major life change at your age. How have you been coping with everything? I've been trying to stay strong for my younger siblings, but it's been really tough. I feel like I have to be the responsible one now that my parents are no longer together. It's understandable that you would feel overwhelmed with all these new responsibilities on your shoulders. It's important to remember that it's okay to feel sad and to ask for help when you need it. I just feel so alone sometimes, like no one understands what I'm going through. You're not alone, Angosisye. We're here to listen and support you through this difficult time. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling? Not really. I didn't know who to talk to or where to turn for help. I'm glad you reached out to us. It's important to talk about your feelings and not keep them bottled up inside. We can work together to help you feel better and find ways to cope with everything that's been going on. Thank you, Eliana. I already feel a little bit better just talking to you.

Hey, hi there. Hello, this is Shani from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Jalali. I'm 12 years old, and I'm calling from Songea Mjini, Ruvuma. Nice to meet you, Jalali. What's on your mind today? I've been feeling really stressed out about school lately. I feel like I have to be perfect all the time. I understand how that can be overwhelming. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? Well, my parents always expect me to get top grades, and my teachers are always pushing me to do better. I feel like I can never make any mistakes. It sounds like you're under a lot of pressure to perform well academically. Have you talked to anyone about how you're feeling? Not really. I don't want to disappoint anyone, so I keep everything to myself. It's important to remember that it's okay to ask for help when you're feeling overwhelmed. Have you tried talking to your parents or a teacher about how you're feeling? No, I haven't. I'm afraid they'll think I'm not trying hard enough. It's important to communicate with the people who care about you. Maybe you could start by talking to a counselor at your school or a trusted adult at the Community Center. I never thought about that. Thank you for listening and giving me some advice, Shani. You're welcome, Jalali. Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need someone to talk to.

Hello, Child Helpline, Sheila speaking. How can I help you today? Hi Sheila, my name is Buyu. I'm a 14-year-old boy from Mkoani, Kusini Pemba. I'm calling because I need some help. Of course, Buyu. What's going on? Well, Sheila, I feel like my parents are neglecting me. They are always busy with work and never have time for me. I'm left alone at home most of the time, and I don't have anyone to talk to or play with. I'm sorry to hear that, Buyu. It sounds like you're feeling really lonely and neglected. Have you tried talking to your parents about how you're feeling? I have, Sheila, but they just brush me off and tell me to be independent. I understand they have to work, but I feel like they don't care about me at all. I can imagine how difficult that must be for you, Buyu. It's important for parents to provide emotional support and spend time with their children. Have you thought about reaching out to a trusted adult, like a teacher at your Secondary School, for support? I haven't, Sheila. I didn't know who to talk to until I found the child helpline number. I'm glad I called. I'm glad you reached out, Buyu. You deserve to feel cared for and supported. We can work together to come up with some solutions to help you feel less neglected. Would you like to talk about some ideas now? Yes, please, Sheila. Thank you for listening to me.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Zayn speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Ibada. I am 10 years old and I live in Kilosa, Morogoro. Nice to meet you, Ibada. What seems to be the issue you are facing today? I am calling because I am being neglected. My parents have not taken me to see a doctor for my cough and fever for over a week now. I am sorry to hear that, Ibada. It is important for you to receive medical attention when you are not feeling well. Have you tried talking to your parents about this? Yes, I have told them several times that I am not feeling well, but they keep saying that we cannot afford to go to the hospital. I understand how frustrating that must be for you, Ibada. But neglecting your health is not acceptable. Have you talked to anyone else about this issue? No, I was too scared to tell anyone. But I saw a poster at the police station about the child helpline, so I decided to call and ask for help. I am glad you reached out, Ibada. Your health is important, and we will do our best to help you. I will make sure to report this neglect to the appropriate authorities so that they can intervene and ensure you receive the medical care you need. Thank you, Zayn. I really appreciate your help. You're welcome, Ibada. Remember, it is important to speak up when you are not being taken care of properly. Don't hesitate to call us again if you need any more assistance. Take care.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Huruma speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Elimu. I'm 10 years old and I'm from Mafinga, Iringa. I'm feeling really stressed about school. Hi Elimu, it's nice to meet you. Can you tell me more about what's been stressing you out? Well, I have exams coming up soon and I'm really worried about not doing well. My parents always expect me to get good grades, and I'm scared I won't meet their expectations. I understand, exams can be really stressful. It's okay to feel anxious about them. Have you been feeling this way for a while? Yes, I've been feeling like this for a few weeks now. I can't concentrate on studying because I keep thinking about failing. It's important to remember that it's okay to feel anxious, but it's also important to take care of yourself. Have you talked to anyone about how you're feeling? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to talk to about it. It's great that you reached out to us. Talking about your feelings can help you feel better. Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it. Thank you, Huruma. I feel a bit better talking to you about it. I'll try to talk to my parents about how I'm feeling too. That's great to hear, Elimu. Remember, it's important to take care of yourself and not be too hard on yourself. You can always call us back if you need to talk more.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Ghubari speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is France. I'm 13 years old and I live in Unguja Kaskazini B, Kaskazini Unguja. Nice to meet you, France. What seems to be the problem? I think I am being neglected by my parents. They are always busy with work and never have time for me. They forget to give me food sometimes, and I have to fend for myself. I'm sorry to hear that, France. It must be really difficult for you. Have you tried talking to your parents about how you feel? Yes, I have tried to talk to them, but they just brush me off and tell me to stop complaining. I feel like they don't care about me at all. That sounds tough, France. You deserve to feel loved and cared for. It's important for parents to provide for their children's basic needs, including food, clothing, and attention. I know, but I don't know what to do. I feel so alone and neglected all the time. You are not alone, France. We are here to help you. We can work together to find a solution to your situation. Have you talked to any trusted adults or friends about what you are going through? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I found this helpline. I'm glad you reached out to us, France. We will do everything we can to support you and ensure your well-being. Let's work together to address this neglect and find a way to improve your situation.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline, this is Sabas speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi Sabas, my name is Yusuf, and I am calling about a missing child in Masasi Mjini, Mtwara. Her name is Terezia, she is 17 years old. I'm sorry to hear that, Yusuf. Can you provide me with more information about Terezia and when she went missing? Terezia has been missing for three days now. She ran away from home after an argument with her parents. We have been searching for her everywhere, but we haven't been able to find her. I understand how concerning this must be for you and her family. It's important to act quickly in these situations. Have you contacted the local authorities or any other organizations for assistance? Yes, we have informed the local police, but they haven't been able to locate her yet. That's why I decided to call the child helpline for further assistance. Thank you for reaching out to us, Yusuf. We will do everything we can to help locate Terezia. Can you provide me with her last known whereabouts or any landmarks that she might have mentioned? Terezia mentioned that she was planning to go to the mosque in the town center. That's the last place we think she might be. Thank you for sharing that information, Yusuf. We will coordinate with the local authorities and other organizations to search for Terezia around the mosque. Please keep your phone close in case we need to contact you for further details. Thank you, Sabas. I appreciate your help. If you need to reach me, you can call me on 07270 434241.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Victoria speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Victoria, my name is Jonathan. I'm 13 years old, and I'm calling from Nkansi, Rukwa. I have a problem with my school. What seems to be the issue, Jonathan? Well, my school has been denying me my right to education. They keep sending us home because they say they don't have enough teachers. But I really want to learn and get an education. I'm so sorry to hear that, Jonathan. Every child has the right to education, and it's important that your school respects that right. Have you tried talking to anyone at the school about this issue? Yes, I've spoken to the headteacher, but they keep giving me excuses. I don't know what else to do. It's good that you've tried to address the issue directly. Since the school hasn't been responsive, I suggest we take this matter to the authorities. Have you considered speaking to someone at the local police station about the situation? I haven't thought about that. Do you think they can help? Yes, the police can assist in ensuring that your educational rights are not being violated. I can also provide you with guidance on how to approach the situation when you visit the police station. Thank you, Victoria. I'll go to the police station and see how they can help me. I really appreciate your support. You're welcome, Jonathan. Remember, you have the right to education, and we are here to help you ensure that right is respected. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need further assistance.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Florence from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi Florence, my name is Justine. I am a 43-year-old woman calling about my daughter Jacqueline, who is 12 years old. We live in Kalambo, Rukwa. I am concerned about her lately. What seems to be the issue with Jacqueline? She has been having some friendship issues at school. It seems like her social group has changed, and she is feeling left out and lonely. I'm sorry to hear that. It must be tough for her to navigate through these changes. Have you talked to Jacqueline about how she is feeling? Yes, I have tried talking to her, but she is not very open about it. I want to help her, but I don't know how to approach the situation. It's great that you are reaching out for help. Sometimes children find it easier to talk to someone outside of their family. Have you noticed any specific incidents or behaviors that have triggered these friendship issues? Well, Jacqueline mentioned that her friends have started excluding her from activities and conversations. She used to be very close to them, but now she feels like an outsider. I see. It's important to validate Jacqueline's feelings and let her know that it's okay to feel this way. Encourage her to express her emotions and thoughts. Is there a trusted adult at school that Jacqueline can talk to about this? I'm not sure, but I will definitely look into it. Thank you for the advice, Florence. I will try to have a more open conversation with Jacqueline and see how we can address these friendship issues. You're welcome, Justine. Remember, the child helpline is here to support you and Jacqueline. If you need further assistance, don't hesitate to reach out. Is there anything else I can help you with? No, that's all for now. Thank you for your time and advice, Florence. Have a great day. You too, Justine. Take care.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Naima speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Asili. I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Rombo in Kilimanjaro. Nice to meet you, Asili. What's on your mind today? Well, I've been struggling with some relationship issues lately. I recently got into my first relationship and it's been really challenging. I understand, relationships can be complicated. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? Yeah, so I feel like my girlfriend and I are having a lot of misunderstandings. We argue a lot and sometimes it feels like we're not on the same page. It's normal to have disagreements in a relationship, Asili. Communication is key in resolving conflicts. Have you tried talking to your girlfriend about how you feel? I have, but sometimes it feels like we're not really listening to each other. I want to make things work, but I'm not sure how to improve our communication. It's great that you want to work on your relationship, Asili. Maybe you could try to have a calm and honest conversation with your girlfriend about your concerns. It's important to listen to each other and try to understand each other's perspectives. That makes sense. I'll try to have a more open and honest conversation with her. Thank you for your advice, Naima. You're welcome, Asili. Remember, it's okay to seek help when you're facing challenges in your relationship. Feel free to call us anytime if you need further support. Take care.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Kafil, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Enzi. I'm 13 years old and I'm calling from Kilwa, Lindi. Nice to meet you, Enzi. What seems to be the problem today? I feel like I'm being neglected by my parents. They don't pay any attention to my education. I'm sorry to hear that, Enzi. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, my parents are always busy with work and they never have time to help me with my schoolwork. I'm falling behind in my classes and I don't know what to do. That must be really tough for you, Enzi. Have you tried talking to your parents about how you feel? Yes, but they just tell me to figure it out on my own. I feel like they don't care about me or my education. It's important for parents to support their children's education. Have you talked to any teachers or other adults about your situation? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to for help. That's why the child helpline is here, Enzi. We can help connect you with resources and support to improve your situation. Would you like me to assist you in finding someone to talk to about your education? Yes, please. I really want to do well in school, but I can't do it alone. Don't worry, Enzi. We will do our best to help you. Let's start by finding a trusted adult or organization in your community that can provide you with the support you need. Thank you for reaching out to us today.

Hello, good afternoon. How can I help you today? Good afternoon. My name is Raha, and I am calling about my niece, Rabia. She is 15 years old and lives in Kalambo, Rukwa. Hello Raha, I am Selemani from the child helpline. What seems to be the issue with Rabia? Well, Rabia has been struggling with getting enough nutritious food. Her parents passed away a few years ago, and she lives with her grandmother who is unable to provide for all her needs. I see, that must be really difficult for Rabia. It's important for her to have a balanced diet to stay healthy and grow properly. Is there any support available in your community for families in need? Unfortunately, there aren't many resources available in our area. Rabia's grandmother does her best, but it's hard for her to make ends meet. I understand. It's great that you reached out for help. We can provide some information on local organizations or programs that may be able to assist with food support for Rabia. Additionally, we can also look into educational materials that could benefit her studies. That would be really helpful. Rabia is a bright student, but she lacks the necessary resources to excel in school. Any assistance in that area would be greatly appreciated. I will make sure to gather all the necessary information and resources for Rabia. Thank you for reaching out, Raha. We are here to support you and Rabia through this difficult time. Thank you so much, Selemani. Your help means a lot to us.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Cesilia speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Haki, I'm 14 years old and I'm calling from Rorya, Mara. Nice to meet you, Haki. How can I support you today? I've been feeling really lonely lately. I live in a remote area and there aren't many kids my age around here. I'm sorry to hear that, Haki. It must be tough feeling isolated like that. Yeah, it's been hard. I miss having friends to hang out with and talk to. Loneliness can be really difficult to deal with, especially when you're in a place where you don't have many people around you. Exactly, it's like I'm stuck here with no one to connect with. Have you tried reaching out to anyone in your community, like maybe a neighbor or a relative? I've tried, but most of them are busy with their own lives. I just feel like I don't fit in here. It's important to remember that it's not your fault, Haki. Is there anything you enjoy doing that could help you feel less lonely, like a hobby or an activity? I like playing soccer, but there aren't many kids around here who are interested in it. It sounds like you're really passionate about soccer. Is there a way you could maybe start a small group or club for kids who enjoy playing? That's a good idea, I never thought about that. Maybe I can try to organize something like that. I'm glad I could help, Haki. Remember, you're not alone and there are always options to help you feel more connected. Don't hesitate to reach out to us if you ever need to talk again. Thank you, Cesilia. I feel better already just talking to you.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Shangazi, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Mary. I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Chake Chake in Kusini Pemba. I have some questions about puberty and development. Of course, Mary. I'm here to help. What specific concerns do you have about puberty and development? Well, I've noticed some changes in my body lately, and I'm not sure if they're normal. I feel like my breasts are growing, and I've started getting my period. I'm feeling a bit confused and worried. It's completely normal to feel that way, Mary. Puberty is a natural process that everyone goes through. It's great that you're reaching out for information and support. Your body is going through changes to prepare for adulthood, and it's important to take care of yourself during this time. I understand, but I feel a bit overwhelmed. I don't know how to handle these changes or if they're happening at the right time. It's okay to feel overwhelmed, Mary. It's important to talk about these changes and seek guidance. Have you spoken to anyone about these feelings before? No, this is the first time I'm talking about it. I didn't know who to ask or where to go for help. I'm glad you reached out to us. It's important to have these conversations and seek support. Remember, puberty is a natural part of growing up, and it's okay to have questions and concerns. Would you like me to provide you with more information about puberty and how to take care of yourself during this time? Yes, please. I would appreciate any guidance you can offer. Thank you for listening and helping me understand this better.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Seghen, how can I help you today? Hi Seghen, my name is Hamida and I am 12 years old. I'm calling from Singida Vijijini in Singida. Hello Hamida, how can I assist you today? I think something bad is happening in my village. There are people who come and take children away in trucks, and they never come back. That sounds very concerning, Hamida. It's important to make sure that children are safe and protected. Can you tell me more about what you've seen? Yes, I saw a group of children being loaded into a truck one night. They were crying and seemed very scared. I think they were being taken away somewhere far. I'm sorry to hear that, Hamida. It sounds like a very serious situation. Do you know if anyone in the village has reported this to the authorities? No, nobody wants to talk about it. They are afraid of the people who are taking the children away. It's important to speak up about these things, Hamida. Human trafficking is a very serious crime, and it's important to protect children from being exploited. I will make sure to report this to the appropriate authorities so they can investigate further. Thank you, Seghen. I just want to make sure that the children in my village are safe and that this doesn't happen again. You did the right thing by reaching out for help, Hamida. Remember, you can always call the child helpline if you need assistance or if you see anything suspicious in the future. We are here to help you and protect children from harm.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Sajida, I'm 13 years old and I'm from Nachingwea, Lindi. Hello Sajida, this is Matilda from the child helpline. How are you feeling today? I'm feeling really scared and alone. My parents passed away a few years ago, and I've been living with my aunt and uncle ever since. But now they don't want me anymore, and they told me I have to leave. I'm so sorry to hear that, Sajida. It must be really difficult for you. It sounds like you're going through a tough time. Yeah, I don't know what to do. I have no one else to turn to. You're not alone, Sajida. We're here to help you. Can you tell me more about your situation? My aunt and uncle have been treating me badly for a while now. They don't provide for me like they used to, and they always yell at me for no reason. I feel like I'm a burden to them. It's not your fault, Sajida. You deserve to be treated with love and respect. Have you tried talking to anyone else about what's been happening? I haven't told anyone. I didn't know where to go for help until I found this number. I'm glad you reached out to us, Sajida. We can help connect you with organizations that provide support for children in situations like yours. You deserve to be in a safe and caring environment. Thank you, Matilda. I feel a little better knowing that someone cares about me. You're welcome, Sajida. We're here for you whenever you need us. Don't hesitate to call back if you need more support.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Kamili speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Ambokile, I'm 31 years old and I'm calling about Mwanyambi, a child from Magharibi Unguja, Mjini Magharibi. Nice to meet you, Ambokile. How can I help you with Mwanyambi today? I have some questions about her nutrition. I want to make sure she's eating well and getting all the nutrients she needs. Of course, that's great that you're concerned about Mwanyambi's nutrition. What specific questions do you have? Well, I'm not sure if I'm feeding her the right foods. What kind of foods should I be giving her to ensure she's healthy and growing well? It's important to provide Mwanyambi with a balanced diet that includes fruits, vegetables, proteins, and carbohydrates. Are you currently able to provide her with these types of foods? Yes, I try to give her a variety of foods, but I want to make sure I'm doing it right. That's great to hear. It's also important to make sure she's drinking plenty of water and avoiding sugary drinks. If you have any more questions or need further guidance, feel free to reach out to us at the child helpline anytime. You can also visit your nearest police station for more information on child nutrition resources. Thank you so much for your help, Kamili. I'll make sure to follow your advice and continue to provide Mwanyambi with a healthy diet. You're welcome, Ambokile. If you have any more questions in the future, don't hesitate to call us at +255 7106 830400. Have a great day!

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. My name is Endesha, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Aziza. I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Unguja Kaskazini B, Kaskazini Unguja. I have some concerns about my little sister's growth and development. She's not growing as fast as other kids her age and I'm worried about her nutrition. I'm sorry to hear that, Aziza. It's great that you're looking out for your sister. Can you tell me a bit more about her diet and eating habits? Well, she's a picky eater and doesn't like fruits and vegetables much. She mostly eats rice and beans, and sometimes she skips meals because she says she's not hungry. I've tried to talk to my parents about it, but they don't seem to think it's a big deal. It's understandable that you're concerned, Aziza. It's important for children to have a balanced diet to support their growth and development. Have you noticed any other changes in your sister's behavior or health recently? Yes, she seems tired all the time and gets sick more often than before. I'm worried that she's not getting enough nutrients to support her growth. Is there anything I can do to help improve her diet and nutrition? I can provide you with some information and tips on how to encourage your sister to eat a more balanced diet. It's important to involve your parents in this conversation as well, so they can support and help make changes at home. Would you like me to provide you with some resources and guidance on child nutrition? Yes, please. I really want to help my sister get the nutrients she needs to grow and be healthy. Thank you for your help, Endesha.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Sanyu speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Afua. I'm 13 years old and I'm calling from Kati Unguja, Kusini Unguja. Nice to meet you, Afua. What seems to be the problem? Well, I have a confession to make. I've been making prank calls to the child helpline. Oh, I see. Can you tell me why you've been doing that? I don't know, I guess I was just curious to see if anyone would pick up or how you would respond. I understand, Afua. Prank calls are not a good way to test a service. We are here to help children who are in real need of support. Making prank calls can tie up the line and prevent someone who really needs help from getting through. I'm really sorry, Sanyu. I didn't think about it that way. I won't do it again. I appreciate you being honest with me, Afua. It's important to remember that the child helpline is a safe space for children to seek help and support. If you ever have a real problem or need someone to talk to, you can always call us. Thank you, Sanyu. I'll keep that in mind. I'm sorry for wasting your time with my prank calls. No problem, Afua. I'm glad we had this conversation. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about or ask? No, that's all for now. Thank you for listening and for your understanding. You're welcome, Afua. Take care and remember, we're here for you if you ever need us.

Hello, Child Helpline, how may I help you today? Hi, my name is Edita, I'm 15 years old, and I'm calling from Kalambo, Rukwa. Hello Edita, I'm Gift from the child helpline. What's on your mind today? I'm really struggling with domestic labor at home. I feel like I'm being exploited. I'm sorry to hear that, Edita. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, I have to do all the housework, take care of my younger siblings, and even work in the fields sometimes. That sounds like a lot for someone your age. Have you tried talking to your family about how you feel? Yes, but they just tell me it's my duty as the oldest child. Child labor is never okay, Edita. You have a right to be protected from exploitation. Have you thought about reaching out to any local organizations for help? I didn't know where to turn until I heard about the child helpline. Can you help me? Of course, we can. We can connect you with resources and support to address your situation. Is there a safe place you can go to if you need to leave home? I think I could stay with my aunt near Central Hospital. She might be able to help me. That's a good idea, Edita. We can also help you report the exploitation and get the support you need. You're not alone in this. Thank you, Gift. I feel better knowing there are people who care about me and want to help. You're welcome, Edita. We're here for you whenever you need us. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need anything else.

Hello, good afternoon. My name is Kajakafwile, and I am calling about a child named Adelaida from Kyerwa, Kagera. I heard about the child helpline and wanted to inquire about some information. Hello Kajakafwile, I'm Joseph from the child helpline. How can I assist you today regarding Adelaida? Thank you, Joseph. I am wondering if you could provide me with some referral information for Adelaida. She is a 10-year-old girl living in a difficult situation, and I am trying to find help for her. I understand, Kajakafwile. I will do my best to assist you. Can you tell me more about Adelaida's situation and what specific help you are looking for? Adelaida is a bright and kind child, but she is currently living in a vulnerable environment due to family issues. I am concerned about her well-being and want to ensure she receives the support she needs. I heard about the child helpline and thought it would be a good place to start in finding resources for her. Thank you for reaching out, Kajakafwile. I can provide you with information on local organizations and services that may be able to assist Adelaida. In Kyerwa, there are shelters and community centers that offer support to children in need. I can also connect you with social workers who can assess the situation and provide further assistance. That would be very helpful, Joseph. Adelaida deserves a safe and nurturing environment, and I will do everything I can to ensure she receives the help she needs. Thank you for your assistance and guidance. You're welcome, Kajakafwile. I will provide you with the necessary information and support to help Adelaida. If you have any more questions or need further assistance, please don't hesitate to reach out to us. Remember, you can also visit the Central Hospital in Kyerwa for immediate assistance in case of emergencies. Thank you for caring for Adelaida and taking the initiative to seek help for her.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Juma, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Aailyah. I'm 11 years old and I live in Iringa Vijijini, Iringa. Nice to meet you, Aailyah. What can I help you with today? I... I don't know how to say this, but I think I'm being sexually abused by someone in my family. I'm so sorry to hear that, Aailyah. It's brave of you to reach out for help. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? It's my uncle. He comes to our house when my parents are at work and does things to me that make me feel uncomfortable. That must be really hard for you, Aailyah. It's important that you know this is not your fault. Have you told anyone about what's been happening? No, I've been too scared to say anything. But it's been going on for a while now, and I don't know what to do. I'm glad you found the courage to talk to me about this, Aailyah. It's important that you know you are not alone in this. We can help you get the support you need to keep you safe. Can you tell me more about your family situation and if there are any other adults you trust? My parents work at the Central Market all day, so they're not home when it happens. I don't really have anyone else to talk to about this. I understand, Aailyah. We are here to support you through this difficult time. We can help you report what's happening and make sure you are safe. You've taken a big step in reaching out for help, and we will do everything we can to protect you.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Claudia speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Claudia, my name is Agatha. I'm 13 years old and I'm calling from Malinyi, Morogoro. Nice to meet you, Agatha. What seems to be troubling you today? I've been feeling really down lately. My parents are always criticizing me and making me feel like I'm not good enough. They constantly belittle me and nothing I do seems to make them happy. I'm sorry to hear that, Agatha. It sounds like you may be experiencing emotional or psychological abuse. It's important to remember that you deserve to be treated with respect and kindness. I know, but it's just so hard to deal with it every day. I feel like I can't do anything right and it's really affecting my self-esteem. You're not alone, Agatha. It's brave of you to reach out for help. Have you tried talking to anyone else about what you're going through? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I found this helpline. I'm glad you decided to call us. Remember, it's not your fault that you're being treated this way. You deserve to feel safe and loved in your own home. Thank you, Claudia. I feel a little better just talking to you about it. I'm here to support you, Agatha. If you ever need to talk or if things get worse, don't hesitate to reach out to us again. I will, thank you so much for listening to me. You're welcome, Agatha. Take care of yourself and stay strong.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Elina speaking. How can I help you today? Hey, my name is Selemani, I'm 14 years old and I'm calling from Mbarali, Mbeya. Hi Selemani, nice to meet you. What seems to be the issue today? I've been having some problems with my friends at school. They've been excluding me from things and I don't know why. That must be really tough. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Yeah, so we used to hang out together all the time, but recently they've been leaving me out of things like group projects and lunchtime activities. It's like they don't want me around anymore. I'm sorry to hear that, Selemani. It sounds like you're feeling left out and alone. Have you tried talking to your friends about how you're feeling? I've tried, but they just brush it off and act like nothing's wrong. I don't know what to do. It's important to remember that it's not your fault if your friends are acting this way. Have you thought about finding new friends who treat you with respect and kindness? I haven't really thought about that, but maybe that would be a good idea. It's just hard to imagine not being friends with them anymore. I understand, change can be scary. But sometimes it's necessary to surround yourself with people who truly care about you. Remember, you deserve friends who value you for who you are. Thank you, Elina. I feel a bit better talking about this with you. I'll try to think about what to do next. I'm glad I could help, Selemani. Remember, you can always call us if you need someone to talk to. Take care of yourself.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Jon speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Jon, my name is Elly and I'm calling about my son Collins. He's 7 years old and we live in Mbarali, Mbeya. I'm really concerned about the academic pressure he's facing. I'm sorry to hear that, Elly. Can you tell me more about what's been going on with Collins? Well, Collins has always been a good student, but lately, he's been putting a lot of pressure on himself to be perfect. He gets upset when he makes even a small mistake and he's always worried about not getting good grades. I see, that does sound like a lot of pressure for a young child. Have you noticed any changes in his behavior or mood because of this? Yes, he's been more anxious and irritable lately. He used to love going to school, but now he's always worried about not doing well enough. I'm afraid this pressure is taking a toll on his mental health. It's understandable that you're worried about Collins. It's important to address this issue before it escalates further. Have you talked to his teachers or school counselors about this? Yes, I have, but I wanted to reach out for more support. I want to help Collins manage his perfectionism and academic pressure in a healthy way. That's a great step, Elly. Let's work together to find some strategies to support Collins and help him navigate through this challenging time. Have you considered seeking professional help or counseling for him? Thank you, Jon. I will look into that. I appreciate your support and guidance in helping my son. Oh, and by the way, did you know that our town is known for St. Mary's Church? Yes, I've heard of St. Mary's Church in Mbarali. It's a beautiful landmark in your town. Thank you for sharing that with me, Elly. Let's focus on finding ways to support Collins and help him overcome this academic pressure.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Martina speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Martina, my name is Filbert. I am calling about a child named Adika who is 10 years old. We live in Kigoma Ujiji, Kigoma. I am really concerned about Adika's safety and well-being. I'm sorry to hear that, Filbert. Can you tell me more about what's been going on with Adika? Well, recently there has been a lot of violence in our community. Adika has been exposed to it multiple times and it's really taking a toll on him. He's been having trouble sleeping and is constantly anxious and scared. I can understand why you're worried about Adika. It must be really hard for him to witness such violence at such a young age. Have you talked to him about how he's feeling? Yes, I have tried talking to him, but he doesn't open up much. He just keeps saying he's fine, but I can see the fear in his eyes. It's important for Adika to have a safe space to talk about his feelings and fears. Is there anyone else in the community who can support him? I'm not sure. That's why I called the helpline. I was hoping to get some guidance on how to help Adika cope with the violence he's been exposed to. Thank you for reaching out, Filbert. We can provide some resources and guidance on how to support Adika through this difficult time. It's important for him to feel safe and supported. Let's work together to help him heal from this traumatic experience.

Hello, Child Helpline. This is Nasra speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Upendo. I'm 10 years old, a girl from Arusha Mjini. Hello, Upendo. How can I assist you? I've been making prank calls to people in my neighborhood, and I think it's getting out of hand. I see. Can you tell me more about why you've been making these prank calls? I guess I've been feeling a bit lonely lately, and I thought making these calls would give me some attention. It's understandable to feel lonely sometimes, but making prank calls isn't the best way to seek attention. Have you talked to anyone about how you're feeling? Not really. I didn't know who to talk to about it. That's okay, Upendo. You can always reach out to the child helpline like you did today. We're here to listen and support you. Have you thought about other ways to cope with your feelings of loneliness? I haven't really thought about it. Do you have any suggestions? You could try talking to a trusted adult about how you're feeling, or maybe join a club or activity where you can meet new friends. It's important to find healthy ways to connect with others and feel less alone. Thank you, Nasra. I'll try to find other ways to cope with my feelings instead of making prank calls. I'm glad to hear that, Upendo. Remember, you can always call us if you need someone to talk to. Our phone number is +255 7899 576241. Thank you, Nasra. Goodbye.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Beatrice, how can I help you today? Hi Beatrice, my name is Ambonisye. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Ukerewe, Mwanza. It's nice to meet you, Ambonisye. How are you feeling today? I'm feeling really lonely and isolated, Beatrice. I don't have any friends to play with and my family seems distant. I'm sorry to hear that, Ambonisye. It must be tough feeling that way. Can you tell me more about why you feel lonely and isolated? Well, my parents are always busy with work and my siblings are older than me, so they don't really want to spend time with me. I spend a lot of time by myself at home. That does sound tough, Ambonisye. It's important to have people to talk to and spend time with. Have you tried talking to your family about how you're feeling? I've tried, but they just tell me to go play by myself or watch TV. I don't feel like they understand how I'm feeling. It sounds like you're really struggling with feeling disconnected from your family, Ambonisye. Have you thought about talking to someone at school or a teacher about how you're feeling? I haven't, but maybe that's a good idea. I just want to feel like I belong and have someone to talk to. I'm glad you called, Ambonisye. Remember, you're not alone and there are people who care about you. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need someone to talk to.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Yaro, I'm 16 years old and I'm calling from Musoma Vijijini, Mara. Hello Yaro, this is Cornelius from the child helpline. How are you feeling today? I'm feeling really stressed out and anxious. I have my final exams coming up soon and I just can't seem to concentrate or study properly. I'm sorry to hear that, Yaro. It's completely normal to feel anxious about exams, but it's important not to let it overwhelm you. Have you been feeling like this for a while? Yes, I've been feeling this way for a few weeks now. I keep worrying about failing and disappointing my family. It's understandable to feel pressure to do well, but it's also important to take care of yourself and your mental health. Have you tried any techniques to help you relax and focus? I've tried taking deep breaths and going for walks, but nothing seems to help. I just feel so overwhelmed all the time. It sounds like you're experiencing academic performance anxiety, Yaro. It's important to remember that your worth is not defined by your grades. Have you spoken to anyone about how you're feeling? No, I haven't really talked to anyone about it. I didn't want to burden my family with my problems. It's important to reach out for support when you're feeling overwhelmed. You can always talk to a counselor at school or reach out to the child helpline whenever you need someone to talk to. We're here to support you, Yaro.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Jenifer speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Jenifer, my name is Sofia. I'm calling about a child named Jaali who is 12 years old from Buhigwe, Kigoma. There has been a natural disaster in their area and I'm worried about his safety. I'm sorry to hear that, Sofia. Can you provide me with more details about the situation Jaali is facing? Yes, there was a heavy rainfall in Buhigwe last night, causing flooding and landslides in the area. Jaali's family home was affected, and they were forced to evacuate to a nearby shelter. Jaali is feeling scared and anxious about the situation. I understand, Sofia. It must be a difficult time for Jaali and his family. Is everyone safe and accounted for at the shelter? Yes, they are safe for now, but the shelter is overcrowded, and they are in need of basic necessities like food, water, and blankets. Jaali's family also needs assistance in getting medical attention as his younger sister has a fever. I see. Have they been able to reach out to any emergency response services or organizations for help? They tried contacting the Central Hospital, but the lines were busy, and they couldn't get through. That's why I decided to call the helpline for assistance. Thank you for reaching out, Sofia. I will make sure to connect Jaali's family with the appropriate emergency response services and organizations to provide them with the help they need. Please assure Jaali that help is on the way. Thank you, Jenifer. I appreciate your assistance in this difficult time.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi there, my name is Mwakipesile, I'm 15 years old, and I'm calling from Songea Vijijini in Ruvuma. Nice to meet you, Mwakipesile. My name is Frederick, and I'm here to listen and help. What's on your mind today? I've been having some trouble with school lately. I've been skipping classes because my family is struggling financially, and I need to help out by working. I'm sorry to hear that, Mwakipesile. It must be tough juggling work and school at such a young age. Have you talked to anyone about this issue before? Not really. I don't want to burden my family with my problems. But I know education is important, and I want to go back to school. I just don't know how to make it work. It's good that you recognize the importance of education, Mwakipesile. Have you thought about reaching out to your teachers or school counselor for support? I haven't, but maybe that's a good idea. Do you think they could help me find a solution that allows me to continue my education while also helping my family financially? Absolutely, Mwakipesile. Your teachers and school counselor are there to support you and help you succeed. They may be able to provide resources or connect you with organizations that can assist with your situation. Thank you, Frederick. I'll definitely consider talking to them. I really appreciate your advice and support. You're welcome, Mwakipesile. Remember, you are not alone in this. If you ever need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to reach out to us at the Child Helpline. Take care, and best of luck with your education and family responsibilities. Thank you, Frederick. Goodbye. Goodbye, Mwakipesile. Take care.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Lucia speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Lucia, my name is Akuji. I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Mpwapwa, Dodoma. Nice to meet you, Akuji. How can I help you today? I need help with something. My family has been struggling with substance abuse for a while now. I'm sorry to hear that, Akuji. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? My older brother and my dad both drink a lot. It's affecting our family and making things really difficult at home. I can understand how challenging that must be for you. Have you talked to anyone about this issue before? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to for help. You did the right thing by reaching out to us. It's important to talk about these things. Is there anyone else in your family who is aware of the situation? My mom knows about it, but she doesn't really do anything to stop them. She says they're functional addicts and that they can handle it. It's good that your mom is aware, but it's important for your family to address the issue and seek help. Substance abuse can have serious consequences. Have you noticed any changes in your family dynamics because of this? Yes, things have been really tense at home. My brother and dad get into arguments a lot, and my mom and I feel like we're walking on eggshells all the time. I'm sorry to hear that, Akuji. It's important for you to know that you're not alone in dealing with this. There are resources and support available to help you and your family through this difficult time. Would you like me to provide you with some information on where you can get help?

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Radhi speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Radhi, my name is Florentina. I'm 26 years old and I'm calling about a child named Eliza who is 10 years old from Ngara, Kagera. Hello Florentina, thank you for reaching out. What seems to be the issue with Eliza? I'm concerned about gender-based violence and discrimination that Eliza is facing at home. She is constantly being told by her parents that she can't do certain things because she is a girl. They also prioritize her brother over her when it comes to education and opportunities. I'm so sorry to hear that Eliza is going through this. Gender-based violence and discrimination are serious issues that need to be addressed. It's important for children to feel valued and treated equally regardless of their gender. Yes, exactly. I want to make sure that Eliza gets the support she needs to overcome these challenges and feel empowered. We can definitely help with that. It's important for Eliza to know that she deserves to be treated with respect and have the same opportunities as her brother. We can provide her with counseling and support services to help her navigate through this difficult situation. That would be great. Thank you so much for your help, Radhi. I just want to see Eliza happy and thriving. You're welcome, Florentina. We are here to support Eliza and other children facing similar issues. Thank you for reaching out and advocating for her well-being.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. My name is Sofia, how can I help you today? Hi Sofia, my name is James. I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Handeni, Tanga. Nice to meet you, James. How can I assist you today? I have some questions about sexual identity and reproductive health. Of course, James. Feel free to ask me anything. Well, I've been feeling confused about my sexual orientation lately. I'm not sure if I like girls or boys, and it's been bothering me. It's completely normal to have questions about your sexual identity at your age, James. It's important to explore your feelings and emotions without judgment. Have you talked to anyone about these feelings before? Not really, I haven't felt comfortable discussing it with anyone I know. That's why I decided to call the helpline. I'm glad you reached out to us, James. It's important to have a safe space to talk about these things. Have you noticed any specific feelings or attractions towards either gender? I think I've had crushes on both boys and girls, but I'm not sure what that means for me. It's okay to have feelings for both genders, James. It's important to remember that sexuality is a spectrum, and there is no right or wrong way to feel. Have you considered talking to a counselor or a trusted adult about these feelings? I haven't, but I think I will now. Thank you for listening and helping me, Sofia. You're welcome, James. Remember, it's important to prioritize your mental and emotional well-being. If you ever need to talk more, feel free to call us back anytime.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Mwinyikondo from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Rhoda, I'm 12 years old, and I'm calling from Nkansi, Rukwa. I'm having a problem at school. I'm here to listen, Rhoda. What's going on? Well, there are some girls in my class who have been excluding me from their group. They make fun of me and don't let me join in their games during break time. It's been going on for a while now, and it's really making me sad. I'm sorry to hear that you're going through this, Rhoda. Bullying and social exclusion are serious issues. Have you tried talking to a teacher or a trusted adult about what's been happening? Yes, I have told my teacher, but she said that she would talk to the girls, but nothing has changed. I don't know what to do anymore. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, Rhoda. It takes courage to speak up about bullying, and I'm glad you reached out to us. We can work together to find a solution. Have you tried making friends with other students in your class who are kind and supportive? I've been trying, but it's hard when the other girls keep excluding me. I just want to feel like I belong. I understand, Rhoda. It's not easy, but please know that you are important and deserve to be treated with respect. Let's work together to find ways to address this issue. Would you like to explore some strategies to help you cope with the situation at school? Yes, please. Thank you for listening and for your help, Mwinyikondo.

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Josphat, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Monika. I'm 11 years old, and I'm calling from Wete, Kaskazini Pemba. Nice to meet you, Monika. How are you feeling today? I'm not feeling very good, Josphat. I've been feeling really sad and lonely lately. I'm sorry to hear that, Monika. Can you tell me a little bit more about what's been going on? Well, my family recently moved to a new town, and I had to leave all my friends behind. I miss them a lot, and I'm having a hard time adjusting to my new school and surroundings. It sounds like you've been through a major life change, Monika. It's completely normal to feel sad and lonely when you're going through something like that. I know, but I just can't seem to shake this feeling of sadness. I feel like I don't have anyone to talk to about it. I'm glad you reached out to us, Monika. You're not alone, and we're here to listen and support you. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to talk to. It's okay, Monika. You can always call us whenever you need someone to talk to. We're here to help you through this difficult time. Have you thought about talking to a counselor at your school or the District Hospital about how you're feeling? I haven't, but maybe I will. Thank you for listening to me, Mfalme. You're welcome, Asante. You're very brave for speaking up about what's happening. I'll make sure you get the help you need. Please remember that you can call us anytime at 07278 916059.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Nen, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Jacob, I'm 13 years old and I'm calling from Moshi Vijijini in Kilimanjaro. Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Msafiri speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Emmanuel, I'm 25 years old and I'm calling about a child named Edisa. Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Bakari speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Bakari, my name is Adin. I'm 12 years old and I live in Bukoba Mjini, Kagera. Thank you, Bakari. I feel a little better now that I've talked to you. I'm glad to hear that, Adin. Remember, we're here for you whenever you need us. Take care of yourself and stay safe.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Dativa, how can I assist you today? Hi Dativa, my name is Florian and I'm a 14-year-old boy from Same, Kilimanjaro. Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Fidelis. I'm 10 years old, and I'm calling from Kigoma Vijijini in Kigoma. Hello Fidelis, my name is Mariamu, and I'm here to help you. I feel better knowing that I can talk to someone about this. I'll try to talk to my parents about what's been going on. That's great to hear, Fidelis. Oh, and if you ever find yourself near Central Hospital, look out for the big red sign!

Hello, thank you for calling the child helpline. This is Jamil, how can I assist you today? Hi Jamil, my name is Natalia. I'm calling about a child from Lindi Mjini named Alfajiri. She's 11 years old and experiencing some difficulties at home. I'm sorry to hear that, Natalia. Can you tell me more about what's going on with Alfajiri? Is there a nearby landmark in Lindi Mjini where we can meet to discuss this further? Yes, we can meet at the Mosque in the center of town. Thank you for your help, Jamil. Alfajiri deserves to live in a safe and loving environment.

Hello, good afternoon. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Rebeca. I'm calling about a young girl named Shani. She's 15 years old and she lives in Kibaha, Pwani. Remember, it's important for Shani to know that she deserves to be treated with respect and fairness. We're here to support her through this difficult time. Thank you, Fidelis. I will talk to Shani and make sure she knows that she doesn't have to suffer in silence.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Bahari, I'm 13 years old and I'm calling from Mbinga, Ruvuma. Hello Bahari, I'm Bertha from the child helpline. I just feel so overwhelmed. It's great that you're trying different ways to cope. Have you thought about talking to a trusted adult or a counselor at school about how you're feeling? I haven't really considered that. I didn't think anyone would understand. It's important to remember that there are people who care about you and want to help. You don't have to go through this alone, Bahari. Would you like me to help you find a counselor or someone to talk to about your anxiety? Yes, that would be really helpful. Thank you for listening to me, Bertha. Of course, Bahari. Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it. You're not alone in this. Take care of yourself, okay? Thank you, Bertha. I will.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Leticia. I'm 12 years old and I'm calling from Kigamboni, Dar es Salaam. Hello Leticia, my name is Clementina and I'm here to listen and support you. What seems to be troubling you today? Well, Clementina, I'm really worried about my family. Thank you, Clementina. I feel a little better knowing that I have someone to talk to about this. It means a lot to me. I'm glad to hear that, Leticia. Remember, it's okay to feel the way you do and it's important to take care of yourself. We can figure out a plan together to support you through this difficult time. You're not alone in this.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Daniel, how can I help you today? Hi Daniel, my name is Cosmas. I'm 15 years old and I'm calling from Mvomero, Morogoro. Hey there, how can I help you today? Hello, this is Ambata from the child helpline. What's your name and how can I assist you? Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Buruji speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Buruji, my name is Adelina. I can provide you with information on local resources and support services that can assist you with managing your health condition. Let's work together to ensure you receive the care you need.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Aurelia speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Lilian, I'm 13 years old, and I'm from Same, Kilimanjaro. Hello, Child Helpline, this is Asia speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Beatrice, I'm 13 years old, and I'm calling from Mbinga, Ruvuma. Nice to meet you, Beatrice. It's important for parents to support their children, not just put pressure on them. Have you thought about talking to a teacher or school counselor about what you're going through? Goodbye, Beatrice.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Alasiri, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Susana. I'm 12 years old and I live in Mbeya Vijijini, Mbeya. Yes, but they just tell me that it's tradition and that I should accept it. I don't want to accept it, I want to go to school like my brother. I understand how frustrating that must be, Susana. It's important for you to know that this kind of gender discrimination is not acceptable. You have the right to education and we can help you explore options to address this issue. Thank you, Alasiri. I didn't know who else to talk to about this. It's good to know that there are people who care about girls like me. You're welcome, Susana. Remember, you have the right to speak up and seek help. We're here to support you.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Dina speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Hidaya. I'm calling about a child named Abasi. He's only 9 years old and he lives in Mafinga, Iringa. Thank you for reaching out, Hidaya. Can you tell me more about what's going on with Abasi? Well, Abasi has been working in hazardous conditions at a local quarry. He's been forced to carry heavy loads and work long hours in the sun. It's really worrying me. I'm sorry to hear that. Child labor in hazardous conditions is a serious issue. Has Abasi been injured or harmed in any way? Yes, he's come home with cuts and bruises several times. Have you tried talking to anyone about this issue, like his parents or local authorities? I've spoken to his parents, but they say they have no choice but to send him to work to help with the family's income. I'm worried that Abasi's health and safety are at risk. Thank you for reaching out, Hidaya. We will do everything we can to help Abasi. I will escalate this issue to our team who deals with child labor cases. We will make sure to follow up and take the necessary steps to protect Abasi. Thank you so much, Dina. I just want to make sure Abasi is safe and can have a chance at a better future. You're doing the right thing by reaching out for help, Hidaya. We are here to support you and ensure that Abasi's rights are protected. Thank you for speaking up for him.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Pamela speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi Pamela, my name is Masomakali. I am a 10-year-old boy from Kwimba, Mwanza. I need help with something. Of course, Masomakali. What seems to be the problem? I think I am being exploited for domestic labor at home. My parents make me work long hours doing chores and taking care of my younger siblings. Yes, I have tried, but they say that it is my duty to help out at home. They don't listen to me when I tell them that I am tired and need time to play and study. I understand how difficult that must be for you, Masomakali. It's important for children to have time for themselves, for play, and for education. Have you spoken to anyone else about this issue? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to for help until I heard about the child helpline. I'm glad you reached out to us, Masomakali. We are here to help you. We can discuss your situation further and come up with a plan to address the issue of child labor and domestic labor exploitation in your home. You have the right to be protected from these harmful practices. Thank you, Pamela. I feel relieved knowing that there is someone who can help me.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Josphat. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Glory. I'm a 10-year-old girl from Nyasa, Ruvuma. I'm feeling really anxious and stressed lately. Hey Glory, it's okay to feel that way sometimes. Can you tell me more about what's been making you feel anxious and stressed? Well, I get really nervous when I have to talk to new people or when I have to do presentations in front of my class. I start sweating and my heart races really fast.
