Mwakamba needs access to education, healthcare, and emotional support. He is feeling lost and alone after losing his parents, and he needs guidance to help him navigate this challenging period in his life. I understand the importance of providing Mwakamba with the necessary support. We will work with our partners to ensure he receives the assistance he needs. Thank you for reaching out to us, Ambilikile. Thank you for your help, Mzee. I just want to make sure that Mwakamba receives the care and support he deserves during this difficult time. You're doing the right thing by seeking help for Mwakamba. We will do our best to ensure he receives the support he needs. If you have any further concerns or questions, please don't hesitate to reach out to us.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian Child Helpline. This is Hanifa speaking, how can I assist you today? Hello Hanifa, my name is Motogusinile. I am 46 years old and I am calling from Mpwapwa, Dodoma. I am concerned about a child named Florentina who is 6 years old. Thank you for reaching out, Motogusinile. Can you please tell me more about what is happening with Florentina? Well, Hanifa, Florentina is being forced to work long hours doing domestic chores in a nearby household. She is just a child and should not be subjected to such labor. I see, that is indeed a serious issue. Child labor, especially domestic labor exploitation, is illegal and harmful to the well-being of children. Have you tried talking to the household where Florentina works? Yes, I have tried to speak to them, but they do not listen. They insist that Florentina is helping her family by working there. I understand your frustration, Motogusinile. We will need to take action to protect Florentina. Can you provide me with more details about the household where she is working? The household is located near St. Mary's Church in Mpwapwa. It is a large house with a garden and a gate. Florentina works there from early morning until late at night, without any breaks. Thank you for sharing that information, Motogusinile. We will investigate the situation and take the necessary steps to ensure Florentina's safety and well-being. Your call is important in protecting children like Florentina from exploitation. Thank you for speaking up. Thank you, Hanifa. I just want to make sure that Florentina is safe and able to enjoy her childhood without being forced to work. Your help is greatly appreciated.

Hello, Child Helpline, this is Yusuf speaking. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is John. I'm 13 years old and I'm calling from Masasi, Mtwara. Nice to meet you, John. What can I assist you with today? I've been having some problems with school. I haven't been going regularly because my family is struggling financially. I'm sorry to hear that, John. It must be tough for you. Can you tell me more about why you're missing school? My parents can't afford to buy all the things I need for school, like books and uniforms. So, sometimes I have to stay home to help them with work. It sounds like you're facing some challenges at home. Have you spoken to your teachers or school counselor about this? No, I haven't. I'm too embarrassed to tell them that I can't afford everything. I don't want them to think I'm not trying. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, John. Many children face similar difficulties. Have you thought about reaching out for help? I didn't know where to turn, so I decided to call the child helpline. I just want to find a way to go to school regularly without feeling like a burden to my family. You're very brave for reaching out, John. We can work together to find a solution that works for you and your family. Let's start by exploring some options for financial assistance and support services in your area. Thank you, Yusuf. I appreciate your help. I really want to continue my education and make my family proud.

Hello, this is the Tanzanian child helpline, my name is Russom. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Oresta, I'm 14 years old and I'm calling from Songea Vijijini, Ruvuma. I'm feeling really worried about something. What's on your mind, Oresta? You can talk to me about anything. Well, I've been feeling a lot of pressure from my friends to try smoking and drinking. They say it's cool and fun, but I'm not sure if I should do it. I'm glad you reached out to us, Oresta. It's totally normal to feel pressured by your friends, but experimenting with substances can be really dangerous. Have you ever tried smoking or drinking before? No, I haven't. But I'm afraid that if I say no to my friends, they'll make fun of me or stop hanging out with me. It's important to remember that true friends will respect your choices and not pressure you into doing something that makes you uncomfortable. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling? Not really, I didn't know who to turn to. But I'm glad I called you. I don't want to do something I'll regret later. I'm really proud of you for reaching out, Oresta. It takes a lot of courage to talk about these things. Remember, you have the right to make your own choices and do what's best for you. Is there anything else you want to talk about? No, I think I feel better now. Thank you for listening to me, Russom. You're welcome, Oresta. Remember, you can always call us back if you need to talk. Take care of yourself, okay? Thank you, Russom. Goodbye.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Marwa speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Marwa, my name is Aailyah. I'm a 10-year-old girl from Kati Unguja, Kusini Unguja. I've been feeling really anxious and stressed lately. I'm sorry to hear that, Aailyah. Can you tell me more about what's been making you feel this way? Well, I have this really bad separation anxiety whenever my mom leaves for work. I start worrying about what might happen to her and I can't focus on anything else. That sounds really tough, Aailyah. It's normal to feel worried when someone you love is away. Have you talked to your mom about how you're feeling? Yes, I have. She always reassures me that she'll be okay and that she'll come back home soon. But I still can't shake off this feeling of anxiety. It's great that you're able to talk to your mom about your feelings. Have you tried any calming techniques when you start feeling anxious? Not really. What kind of techniques can I try? You can try deep breathing exercises or mindfulness techniques to help calm your mind when you start feeling anxious. You can also try distracting yourself with activities you enjoy, like drawing or playing with friends. That sounds like a good idea, Marwa. I'll try those techniques next time I start feeling anxious. Thank you for listening and for your advice. You're welcome, Aailyah. Remember, you can always call us at the child helpline if you need someone to talk to. Our phone number is +255 7808 939589. And if you ever feel overwhelmed, you can also talk to a trusted adult or a counselor at your school.

Hello, this is the child helpline, my name is Diana. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Wasaki, I'm 15 years old and I'm from Shinyanga Mjini, Shinyanga. I'm calling because I feel like I'm being neglected when it comes to my education. I'm sorry to hear that, Wasaki. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, my parents don't seem to care about my education. They never ask about how school is going or if I need any help with my studies. They're always too busy with their own things to even notice me. That must be really tough for you, Wasaki. Have you tried talking to them about how you feel? I've tried, but they just brush it off and tell me to focus on my own studies. But how can I focus when I feel like no one is there to support me? I understand how frustrating that must be. Education is so important, and it's not fair that you feel like you're not getting the support you need. Have you talked to any teachers or other adults about this? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I found the child helpline number. I just want someone to listen to me and help me figure out what to do. I'm glad you reached out to us, Wasaki. You deserve to have a supportive environment for your education. Let's work together to come up with a plan to address this neglect and help you succeed in school.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Conrad speaking, how can I help you today? Hi Conrad, my name is Seghen. I'm 17 years old and I'm calling from Micheweni, Kaskazini Pemba. Nice to meet you, Seghen. How can I assist you today? I need help with something really serious. I think my friend is being lured into human trafficking. That's a very serious issue, Seghen. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, my friend has been approached by someone promising her a job in the city. They said she could make a lot of money and have a better life. That sounds like a common tactic used by human traffickers to deceive their victims. It's important that we take action to protect your friend. Have you talked to her about this? Yes, I tried to warn her about the dangers of falling for these promises, but she doesn't believe me. She thinks it's a great opportunity for her to escape poverty. I understand how difficult this situation must be for you, Seghen. It's important that we involve the authorities in this matter. Have you considered reporting this to the police station in your area? I haven't thought about that, but I will definitely do that. Thank you for your help, Conrad. You're welcome, Seghen. Remember, it's important to prioritize your friend's safety above all else. Don't hesitate to reach out to us again if you need further assistance. Thank you, Conrad. Goodbye.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Geni speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Saada, I'm 13 years old and I'm from Kigoma Ujiji, Kigoma. I'm calling because I'm having some problems at home. I'm sorry to hear that, Saada. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? Well, my parents have been arguing a lot lately, and it's really affecting me. I feel scared and sad all the time. I don't know what to do. I understand how difficult that must be for you, Saada. It's important to remember that it's not your fault and that there are people who can help. Have you tried talking to someone you trust about how you're feeling? I haven't really talked to anyone about it. I don't know who to turn to. You can always reach out to the child helpline, like you did today. We're here to listen and support you. It's important to take care of yourself during these tough times. Have you tried finding a safe space to go to when things get too overwhelming? I like to go to St. Mary's Church when I need some time alone. It helps me feel calm and peaceful. That's great to hear, Saada. It's important to have a safe space where you can go to when you need a break. Remember, you're not alone in this. We're here to support you and help you through this difficult time. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about? Thank you, Geni. Just talking to you has made me feel a little better. I'll try to take care of myself and reach out for help when I need it. I'm glad I could help, Saada. Remember, you're strong and resilient. Don't hesitate to call us anytime you need someone to talk to. Take care of yourself.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Mike from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi Mike, my name is Filbert. I'm 12 years old and I live in Kinondoni, Dar es Salaam. Nice to meet you, Filbert. What's on your mind today? I'm really worried about my friends at school. Some of them have started skipping classes and I'm afraid they might drop out. That sounds like a serious issue, Filbert. Can you tell me more about what's going on? Well, some of my friends have been struggling with their schoolwork and they just don't seem interested in going to school anymore. They hang out on the streets instead of going to class. It's important to make sure your friends stay in school and get the education they need. Have you tried talking to them about this? Yeah, I've tried talking to them but they don't listen to me. I'm not sure what else to do. It's good that you're concerned about your friends. Maybe we can come up with a plan together to help them stay in school. Have you talked to a teacher or a trusted adult about this? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to talk to. Can you help me figure out what to do? Of course, Filbert. Let's brainstorm some ideas together on how we can help your friends. Maybe we can talk to a teacher or a school counselor to get them the support they need. Thank you, Mike. I feel better knowing that there's someone I can talk to about this. You're welcome, Filbert. Remember, you're not alone in this. We're here to help you and your friends through this tough time.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Bahari speaking, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Ipyana. I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Mbozi, Mbeya. Nice to meet you, Ipyana. What seems to be troubling you today? I've been feeling really stressed out lately. My friends at school keep pressuring me to cheat on our exams. I'm sorry to hear that, Ipyana. Peer pressure can be really tough to deal with. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, my friends keep telling me that everyone else is cheating, so I should too. They say it's the only way to get good grades. I understand how difficult that must be for you. It's important to remember that cheating is not the right way to succeed in school. Have you talked to anyone at school about this issue? No, I'm too scared to tell my teachers or my parents. I don't want my friends to be mad at me. Ipyana, it's important to prioritize your own values and integrity over what your friends are pressuring you to do. It's okay to seek help and support from adults you trust, like your teachers or parents. They can help you navigate this situation in a healthy way. But what if my friends get mad at me for telling on them? It's important to prioritize your own well-being and academic integrity, Ipyana. Your friends may be upset at first, but in the long run, they will respect you for standing up for what is right. Remember, cheating is not the answer. You can always come to the child helpline for support and guidance whenever you need it. Thank you, Bahari. I feel a little better now. I will try to talk to my teacher about what's been happening. That's great to hear, Ipyana. Remember, you are not alone in this. Take care of yourself and remember that you can always reach out for help. Is there anything else you would like to talk about today? No, thank you for listening and for your advice, Bahari. Goodbye. Goodbye, Ipyana. Take care and remember that we are here for you whenever you need us.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Mwakisyala. I'm 10 years old and I live in Morogoro Mjini. Hello Mwakisyala, my name is Yusra and I'm here to help you. What's on your mind today? I'm really scared and I don't know what to do. I think someone online is trying to do bad things to me. I'm so sorry to hear that, Mwakisyala. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, there's this person I met in a chatroom who keeps asking me to do things that make me uncomfortable. They want me to send them pictures of myself, and they say really inappropriate things. That sounds really frightening, Mwakisyala. It's important to remember that you don't have to do anything that makes you feel unsafe or uncomfortable. Have you told anyone else about this? No, I was too scared to tell anyone. But I didn't know what else to do, so I called the helpline. You did the right thing by reaching out for help, Mwakisyala. It's never okay for someone to make you feel that way. We're here to support you and help keep you safe. Can you tell me if this person has been threatening you in any way? No, they haven't threatened me, but I'm still really scared. I don't want them to keep bothering me. I understand, Mwakisyala. We take these situations very seriously, and we will do everything we can to help you. I'm going to connect you with someone who can help further. Can you please stay on the line while I do that? Yes, thank you so much for listening to me. I really appreciate your help.

Hi, um, hello? Hello, this is Noah from the child helpline. How can I help you today? My name is Denis, I'm 10 years old, and I'm a girl from Buhigwe, Kigoma. Nice to meet you, Denis. What's on your mind today? I've been feeling really lonely lately. I'm sorry to hear that, Denis. Loneliness can be tough. Can you tell me more about why you're feeling this way? Well, Buhigwe is a small village and there aren't many kids my age to play with. I feel like I'm always by myself. I understand how that can make you feel isolated. Have you tried talking to your family about how you're feeling? Yeah, but my siblings are all older than me and they have their own friends. I just feel like I don't fit in. It's important to remember that you're not alone, Denis. There are people who care about you and want to help. Have you thought about joining any clubs or activities in your village? I've tried, but there aren't many options here. I see. Have you ever been to the Central Hospital in Kigoma? It's a well-known landmark in the area. They may have resources for children your age to connect with others. No, I've never been there. I'll ask my parents if we can go. That's a great idea, Denis. Remember, it's okay to feel lonely sometimes, but there are always ways to reach out and connect with others. You can always call us back if you need someone to talk to. Thank you, Noah. I feel better already. You're welcome, Denis. Take care of yourself, okay?

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline, this is Anza speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi Anza, my name is Edena and I'm 17 years old. I'm calling from Urambo, Tabora. I have a problem with school dropouts and truancy in my community. That sounds like a serious issue, Edena. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, many children in my area are dropping out of school because they don't see the value in education. Some of them come from struggling families who can't afford to send them to school, while others are discouraged by the poor quality of education they receive. I see, that must be really tough to witness. Have you tried talking to anyone in authority about this issue? Yes, I've spoken to some teachers and community leaders, but it feels like nothing is being done to address the root causes of the problem. The children who drop out end up on the streets, engaging in risky behaviors and getting into trouble. It's heartbreaking to hear that, Edena. You're doing a great job by reaching out for help. We can work together to find solutions and support for these children in need. Have you thought about starting a community initiative or reaching out to NGOs for assistance? I haven't thought about that, but it sounds like a good idea. I will try to gather some like-minded individuals in my community to come up with a plan to tackle this issue more effectively. Thank you for your advice, Anza. You're welcome, Edena. Remember, you're not alone in this. Feel free to call us anytime for support or guidance. Take care and stay strong in your efforts to make a positive change in your community.

Hello, Child Helpline. This is Noah speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Mwakamba. I'm 25 years old and I am calling about a child named Msafiri from Nachingwea, Lindi. Thank you for reaching out, Mwakamba. Can you tell me more about what's going on with Msafiri? Well, Msafiri is only 10 years old, and he has been facing some ongoing threat situations in his community. There have been some conflicts between different groups, and he has been caught in the middle of it. I'm sorry to hear that. It's important to ensure that children like Msafiri are safe and protected. Have you noticed any specific incidents or behaviors that are concerning? Yes, there have been instances where Msafiri has been threatened by older children in the neighborhood. They have been pressuring him to join their group, and he is scared to refuse because he fears retaliation. That sounds like a very challenging situation for a young child to be in. It's important to address these threats and ensure that Msafiri is safe. Have you spoken to anyone in the community about this issue? I have tried to talk to some of the community leaders, but they have not taken the issue seriously. I am worried about Msafiri's safety and well-being. I understand your concerns, Mwakamba. We will do everything we can to help Msafiri and ensure that he is safe. Thank you for reaching out to us. We will follow up on this matter and take the necessary steps to protect Msafiri.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Mwipopo speaking. How can I assist you today? Hi, my name is Anna. I'm 36 years old and I'm calling about a child named Edita who is 10 years old. We are from Wete, Kaskazini Pemba. Thank you for reaching out, Anna. Can you tell me a bit more about the situation with Edita? Well, Edita has been experiencing some conflict situations at home. Her parents have been arguing a lot lately, and it's really affecting her emotionally. I'm sorry to hear that. It must be tough for Edita to witness her parents fighting. Have you noticed any changes in her behavior or mood because of this? Yes, she has been more withdrawn and quiet lately. She used to be so lively and outgoing, but now she seems sad and anxious all the time. It's important to address these issues early on to prevent any long-term effects on Edita's well-being. Have you talked to her parents about the situation? I have tried to speak to them, but they don't seem to listen. They are too caught up in their own arguments to see how it's affecting Edita. I understand. It can be challenging to navigate conflict situations, especially when children are involved. I can provide you with some resources and support to help Edita cope with this situation. Would you like me to do that? Yes, please. Any help would be greatly appreciated. Thank you for being here for us. Of course, Anna. I will do my best to support you and Edita through this difficult time. Please feel free to reach out to us at any time. You can also contact us at +255 7243 308465. Is there a landmark near your location that I can use to better assist you? Yes, we are near St. Mary's Church in Wete. Thank you for your help, Mwipopo.

Hello, Child Helpline, how can I help you today? Hi, my name is Tina. I'm 10 years old and I'm calling from Unguja Kaskazini B, Kaskazini Unguja. Nice to meet you, Tina. I'm Cosmas from the child helpline. What seems to be the issue today? I have a problem with some of my friends at school. They keep talking about running away from home and I'm worried they might actually do it. That does sound concerning, Tina. It's important to talk about these things. Have you tried talking to your friends about how you feel? Yes, I have, but they don't listen. They think it's cool to run away and be independent. It's understandable that you're worried about your friends. Running away from home can be dangerous. Have you told any adults about this? I haven't told anyone yet. I didn't know who to talk to about it. It's good that you reached out to us. We can help you figure out the best way to handle this situation. Have you noticed any specific reasons why your friends want to run away? They say they don't like being told what to do at home and they think they can have more fun on their own. It's important for your friends to understand the risks of running away and that there are better ways to solve problems. Have you thought about talking to a teacher or a school counselor about this? I haven't, but I will try to talk to someone at school about it. Thank you for listening and for your advice, Cosmas. You're welcome, Tina. Remember, it's always okay to seek help when you're worried about something. Take care and stay safe.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Hilary from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? My name is Constantine, I'm 17 years old, and I'm calling from Chemba, Dodoma. I need help with something really serious. Of course, Constantine. What's been happening? I've been experiencing physical abuse at home. My father comes home drunk almost every night and takes out his anger on me and my siblings. It's getting worse and I don't know what to do. I'm so sorry to hear that, Constantine. It's not okay for anyone to harm you like that. Have you tried talking to someone about this before? No, I haven't. I didn't know who to turn to until I heard about the child helpline at the Community Center. I'm glad you reached out to us. It's important that you speak up about what's happening. No one deserves to be treated like this. Have you thought about contacting the authorities or seeking help from a trusted adult? I'm scared to involve anyone else, but I can't keep living like this. I don't want my younger siblings to go through the same thing. Can you help me figure out what to do next? Absolutely, Constantine. We can work together to come up with a plan to ensure your safety and the safety of your siblings. Your well-being is our top priority. Let's start by discussing some options and resources available to you in your community. Thank you, Hilary. I feel a little better already knowing that I have someone to talk to about this.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Afua from the child helpline. How can I help you today? Hi, my name is Odilia. I'm 11 years old and I'm calling from Kibiti, Pwani. Nice to meet you, Odilia. What seems to be the problem? Well, I've been having some friendship issues. My best friend betrayed my trust and now I don't know what to do. I'm sorry to hear that, Odilia. Can you tell me more about what happened? We had a secret that we promised not to tell anyone, but she ended up telling everyone at school. I feel really hurt and betrayed. That must be really tough for you. Have you tried talking to your friend about how you feel? Yes, but she just laughed it off and said it was no big deal. I don't know if I can trust her anymore. It's important to have friends who respect your feelings and keep your secrets. Have you thought about talking to an adult you trust about this situation? I haven't, but maybe I should. I don't want this to affect me at school or at home. That's a good idea, Odilia. You can also try to make new friends who will treat you with respect and loyalty. Remember, it's okay to walk away from toxic friendships. Thank you, Afua. I feel better talking about this. I will try to talk to someone I trust and focus on building healthier relationships. I'm glad I could help, Odilia. Remember, you can always call us back if you need more support. Take care of yourself. Thank you, Afua. Goodbye. [Odilia hangs up the phone feeling relieved and supported, knowing she has options and resources to help her navigate her friendship issues.]

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Noelia speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Noelia, my name is John and I'm calling about a child named Veronica. She's 13 years old and from Kasulu, Kigoma. Hello John, thank you for providing that information. What seems to be the issue with Veronica? She's been having some friendship issues lately. It seems like her social group has changed and she's feeling left out. I'm sorry to hear that. It must be tough for Veronica to navigate through those changes. Can you tell me more about what's been happening? Well, Veronica used to be really close with a group of girls from her school. They would hang out together all the time. But recently, they've started excluding her and forming new cliques without her. That sounds like a challenging situation for Veronica. Have you talked to her about how she's feeling? Yes, she's been feeling really lonely and sad about it. She doesn't understand why her friends are treating her this way. It's important for Veronica to know that she's not alone in this. It's common for friendships to change as we grow older. Maybe we can brainstorm some ways to help her cope with this situation and maybe even make new friends. That would be really helpful. Veronica is a kind and caring girl, she doesn't deserve to feel this way. I just want to see her happy again. I understand your concern for Veronica, John. Let's work together to come up with some strategies to support her through this difficult time. Maybe we can encourage her to explore new activities or clubs where she can meet new people. And remind her that true friends will always stand by her side, no matter what. Thank you, Noelia. I really appreciate your help and support. I will talk to Veronica and suggest some of these ideas to her. You're welcome, John. Remember, the child helpline is always here for you and Veronica whenever you need us. Take care and keep us updated on how she's doing. Thank you, Noelia. Goodbye. Goodbye, John.

Hey, hi there. I'm Linda, and I'm calling from Unguja Kaskazini B in Kaskazini Unguja. I'm 11 years old. Hello Linda, this is Feruzi from the child helpline. How can I assist you today? I think I need help. I overheard some older girls at my school talking about getting jobs in the city, but they seemed really secretive about it. I'm worried it might be something dangerous. Thank you for sharing that with me, Linda. It's brave of you to reach out. It sounds like you might be talking about human trafficking, which is a serious issue. Can you tell me more about what you heard? Well, they were saying that they could make a lot of money quickly and that they had to leave the island for it. They were talking about getting new clothes and phones too. It just didn't sound right to me. I'm glad you trusted your instincts, Linda. It's important to be cautious about offers that seem too good to be true. Human trafficking, especially sex trafficking, is a serious crime where people are exploited and put in dangerous situations. Your safety is our priority. Do you have any more information about these girls or where they were planning to go? I only heard bits and pieces of their conversation, but I can try to find out more discreetly. I just don't want my friends to get hurt. That's very thoughtful of you, Linda. It's important to protect yourself and others from potential dangers. If you can gather more information without putting yourself at risk, that would be helpful. In the meantime, I can connect you with local authorities who can investigate further. Remember, you're not alone in this. We're here to support you.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline. This is Paulina speaking, how can I assist you today? Hi Paulina, my name is Saida. I'm calling about a child named Imara. She's a 17-year-old girl from Mkoani, Kusini Pemba. She's been missing for a few days now and I'm really worried about her. I'm sorry to hear that, Saida. Can you tell me more about what happened leading up to Imara going missing? Well, Imara has been having some issues at home and school recently. She's been feeling overwhelmed and has been avoiding talking about her problems. I think she finally reached a breaking point and decided to run away. It must be very distressing for you as her guardian. Have you tried contacting her friends or other family members to see if they know where she is? Yes, I've reached out to everyone I can think of, but no one has seen or heard from her. I'm really concerned for her safety out there on her own. I understand your concern, Saida. It's important to report Imara as a missing child to the local authorities as soon as possible. They can help with the search and ensure she is safe. Thank you, Paulina. I will make sure to do that right away. I just want Imara to know that she is loved and supported, no matter what she may be going through. That's a great attitude to have, Saida. Remember, the child helpline is here to support you and provide guidance through this difficult time. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need any further assistance. Thank you, Paulina. I appreciate your help and will keep you updated on any developments regarding Imara.

Hello, hi there! This is Hanifa calling from Bukoba Vijijini. Hello Hanifa, my name is Mwazighe and I'm here to help. How can I assist you today? I'm 16 years old and I'm calling because I'm really worried about my family. We live near St. Mary's Church in Kagera, and my parents have been struggling with substance abuse for a while now. I'm sorry to hear that, Hanifa. Substance abuse can have a big impact on families. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? Well, my parents both drink a lot and sometimes they even use drugs. It's like they can't function without it. They argue a lot and sometimes they become violent. I'm scared for my younger siblings and I don't know what to do. That sounds really tough, Hanifa. It's not easy to see your loved ones struggle with addiction. Have you tried talking to anyone about this issue before? I haven't really talked to anyone about it. I feel like I need to keep it a secret because I'm ashamed of what's happening in my family. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, Hanifa. It's not your fault and you deserve support. We can help you find resources and support to cope with this difficult situation. Thank you, Mwazighe. I didn't know where to turn to for help. I just want my family to get better and for us to be happy again. I'm glad you reached out, Hanifa. We can work together to find the best way to support you and your family. It's important to take care of yourself too. Let's figure out a plan to get you the help you need.

Hello, thank you for calling the Tanzanian child helpline, this is Calvin speaking. How can I assist you today? Yes, hello Calvin. My name is Aoko, I am 36 years old, and I am calling about a child named Darweshi from Kakonko, Kigoma. Thank you for providing that information, Aoko. What seems to be the issue with Darweshi? Well, Calvin, I am concerned about Darweshi's physical health. He has been complaining of stomach pains and headaches for the past few weeks, and I am worried it may be affecting his overall well-being. I see, it's important to address physical health concerns promptly. Have you taken Darweshi to see a healthcare provider? Yes, we have visited a local clinic, but they were not able to pinpoint the cause of his symptoms. I'm starting to think there may be a connection between his mental health and physical symptoms. That's a valid point, Aoko. It is not uncommon for mental health issues to manifest as physical symptoms in children. Have there been any recent changes or stressors in Darweshi's life that could be contributing to his symptoms? Darweshi has been acting more withdrawn lately, and he has mentioned feeling anxious about school and making friends. I think the stress and anxiety he is experiencing may be manifesting as stomach pains and headaches. I appreciate you sharing that with me, Aoko. It's important to address both the physical and mental aspects of Darweshi's well-being. I can provide you with some resources and guidance on how to support him through this challenging time. Thank you for reaching out to the child helpline for assistance.

Hello, welcome to the child helpline, this is Sabina. How can I help you today? Hi Sabina, my name is Peter, I'm 11 years old, and I'm calling from Ruangwa, Lindi. Nice to meet you, Peter. What's on your mind today? I've been feeling really sad and I've been having thoughts of hurting myself. I'm sorry to hear that, Peter. It's brave of you to reach out for help. Can you tell me more about what's been going on? Well, I've been having a hard time at school. I'm struggling with my grades and I feel like I'm letting my family down. I don't know what to do. It sounds like you're under a lot of pressure. It's okay to feel overwhelmed sometimes. Have you talked to anyone about these feelings before? Not really. I didn't want to worry my parents. It's important to remember that it's okay to ask for help when you're feeling this way. You're not alone, Peter. We're here to support you. Have you ever thought about hurting yourself? Sometimes I feel like things would be easier if I wasn't around. I'm glad you're talking to me about this, Peter. It's really important that we take these thoughts seriously. Have you ever acted on these thoughts or tried to harm yourself? No, I haven't done anything like that. That's good to hear. It's important to remember that there are people who care about you and want to help. Would you be willing to talk to a counselor or someone at your school about what you're going through? I think so. I don't want to feel like this anymore. That's a positive step, Peter. I can help you find resources in your area that can provide support. You're not alone in this, and there are people who want to help you through this difficult time.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Edna, I'm here to help. I'm Masopakyindi, a boy from Karatu in Arusha. I'm 10 years old and I need help. There's a problem with bullying at school, but it's not just happening there. It's also online. Some kids are sending me mean messages on social media. It's really hurting me, Edna. I don't want to tell my parents because I don't want them to worry, but I think they should know. Do you think it would help if I told a teacher? Or maybe an imam from the mosque? What can I do to make them stop, Edna? I just want to be left alone and feel safe again. I'm really sorry that you're going through this Masopakyindi. It's not fair that you have to deal with bullying both at school and online. You've done the right thing by reaching out for help. Let's think about what we can do together. One option is to talk to a teacher or an imam about what's happening. They might be able to help stop the bullying and make sure you feel safe at school and in your community. Another option is to block the people who are sending you mean messages online. You don't have to put up with that kind of behavior. If they keep messaging you, save the evidence and show it to a trusted adult. They can help you report the bullying to the social media platform. Remember, Masopakyindi, it

Hello, you've reached the child helpline. I'm Kwasi. How can I assist you today? Hi there, it's Ali from Meatu, Shinyanga. I'm a boy and I'm 11 years old. I understand your concerns, Ali. But it's important to remember that you deserve to be treated with kindness and respect. If you feel unsafe at home, there are people who can help. Are there any neighbors or friends you could confide

She promises to take immediate action, starting with contacting their service provider and involving Editha in open discussions about her emotions and safety moving forward. As the conversation concludes, Jasmin thanks Francisca once more and assures her that they will work together to ensure Editha's well-

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is Jonathan, I'm here to help. I'm Rabia, a 14-year-old boy from Chamwino, Dodoma. There's something troubling me and I don't know what to do. A few days ago, some men approached me near the Post Office and promised me a job in the city. They said I could earn a lot of money. Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, this is here to help. I'm Busu from Arumeru Mashariki, Arusha. I'm a 12-year-old boy and I need some advice. I've been feeling overwhelmed with schoolwork lately. The pressure is making me anxious about my future. I don't know if I can keep up. I understand, Busu. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot right now. Let's talk about how we can manage your academic pressure and help reduce your anxiety. Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that it's okay to feel overwhelmed sometimes. Many students face similar challenges. Thank you, Bora. That makes me feel better already. I've been worrying a lot about my grades because everyone around me seems to be doing so well. But I struggle with understanding some subjects, especially math and science. It's common to compare ourselves to others, but it's essential to focus on your own progress rather than comparing yourself to others. Let's start by identifying the areas where you are having trouble. Have you discussed these issues with your teachers? They may be able to offer additional resources or tutoring to help you catch up. I haven't really talked to my teachers about it, Bora. I guess I was afraid they would think I'm not smart enough. But now that I mention it, there is a teacher named Mwanga at the Secondary School near my home who I trust and get along well with. I could talk to him about my concerns. That's a great first step, Busu! Speaking to your trusted teacher can help you understand the subjects better and develop a plan to improve your grades. It also shows that you are proactive in addressing your challenges. I appreciate your advice, Bora.

Hello, is this the child helpline? Yes, you've reached the right place. I'm Adla here to help. What seems to be the problem today? I'm Queen, a 12-year-old girl from Iramba, Singida. My family... things have been getting worse at home. There's domestic violence and my father is becoming more aggressive every day. I don't feel safe anymore. Oh dear, I'm really sorry to hear that Queen. It's very important for you to know that what you're experiencing isn't your fault. I can see how difficult this must be for you. Can you tell me more about the situation at home? Is there a specific incident that stands out? Yes, Adla. Last night, he came back drunk and started arguing with my mother. He raised his hand towards her and I tried to intervene. He pushed me away angrily. I'm scared for both of us. I'm really concerned about your safety, Queen. Have you considered reaching out to a trusted adult or authority figure? A teacher, school counselor, or even a local police officer could provide assistance. Is there someone like that in your life? There is a teacher at my school who I trust, but I've been too scared to tell her about this. I don't want my father to find out and retaliate against me or my mother. What should I do, Adla? It takes courage to seek help, Queen. I would encourage you to talk to your trusted teacher as soon as possible. If it feels too risky to discuss in person, consider writing a letter detailing what's been happening at home and giving it to her. Remember, there are people who care about your wellbeing and want to help. Thank you for your advice, Adla

I understand that it may seem like there

Hello, you've reached the child helpline. I'm Christopher. How can I assist you today? Hi there, it's Sarki from Micheweni, Kaskazini Pemba. I need someone to guide me through this, to help me understand what's happening to me and how to make it better. I know I can't do it
